DIVISION 2. - VEHICLES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 204, §§ 1-15, adopted Jan. 23, 1996, repealed the former Div. 2, §§ 26-66-26-77, and enacted a new Div. 2 as set out herein. The former Div. 2 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. 108, §§ 1-12, adopted Feb. 6, 1979. 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 54. 
State Law reference- Abandoned vehicles, M.S.A. § 168B.01 et seq. 

Sec. 26-66. - Declaration of purpose and public nuisance. 
    The existence, accumulation, and storage of abandoned, wrecked, junked, partially dismantled, or inoperative vehicles constitute a hazard to the health, safety and welfare of the people of the city in that such vehicles can invite vandalism, create traffic hazards, harbor noxious diseases, furnish shelter and breeding places for vermin, constitute an attractive nuisance and present physical dangers to the safety and well-being of children and others. The accumulation and outside storage of such vehicles create an unsightly condition and constitute a blight on the landscape and a detriment to the environment and tend to reduce the value of private property. Therefore, the accumulation and storage of such vehicles on public or private property is hereby declared to constitute a public nuisance which may be abated as provided in this division or as provided under any other ordinance of the city or by the laws of the state. It is the intention of this division to prevent, reduce or eliminate the abandonment and improper storage of vehicles as defined in this division. 
(Ord. No. 204, § 1, 1-23-96) 
Sec. 26-67. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Abandoned vehicle means a vehicle: 
(1)  Not properly or currently licensed; 
(2)  Which is in an inoperable condition, including vehicles with pioneer, classic car, collector or street rod license plates; 
(3)  Lacking vital component parts including vehicles with pioneer, classic car, collector or street rod license plates; 
(4)  Which has remained on public property for a period of more than 48 hours; 
(5)  Which has remained on private property for a period of more than 48 hours without the consent of the person in control of such property; 
(6)  To which the last registered owner of record has relinquished dominion of waived all rights to possession; or 
(7)  Voluntarily surrendered by the owner and accepted by the city. 
    City means the City of Watertown. 
    Inoperative vehicle means any vehicle which cannot be driven or propelled under its own power in its existing condition or which cannot be driven or propelled under its own power in a safe manner because of its wrecked, junked or partially dismantled condition. 
    Person means any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
    Private property means any real property within the city which is privately owned and which is not public property as defined in this section. 
    Public property means any street, alley, parking lot, right-of-way, or other public property or facility. 
    Sheriff's department means the Carver County Sheriff's Department. 
    Vehicle means any machine as defined under M.S.A. §§ 168.11 or 169.01, including automobiles, trucks, trailers, motorcycles, tractors, snowmobiles, all terrain vehicles and other self-propelled machinery. 
    Vital component parts means those parts of a motor vehicle that are essential to the mechanical functioning of the vehicle, including, but not limited to, the motor, drive train and wheels. 
(Ord. No. 204, § 2, 1-23-96) 
Sec. 26-68. - Exceptions. 
    A vehicle shall not be considered an abandoned vehicle as defined in this division if the vehicle is kept: 
(1)  Completely enclosed within a building; 
(2)  On the premises of a vehicle repair business which is maintained and licensed in accordance with state law and conforms with this Code. The vehicle must be actively in the process of repair and must be maintained in an area screened from public view by an opaque fence at least six feet high; or 
(3)  In an appropriate storage place or depository maintained or authorized by the city. 
(Ord. No. 204, § 3, 1-23-96) 
Sec. 26-69. - Parking and storage prohibited. 
    No person shall park, store, leave, or permit the parking, storing or leaving of an abandoned vehicle, whether attended or not, upon any property, public or private, within the city for a period of more than 48 hours. 
(Ord. No. 204, § 4, 1-23-96) 
Sec. 26-70. - Prohibition on city streets. 
    It is unlawful for any person to abandon a vehicle in the right-of-way of highways, roads and streets within the city. No person shall park or leave any vehicle in a wrecked, junked, partially dismantled or inoperative condition in a right-of-way of any street, provided that a reasonable time, not to exceed 24 hours from the time of disability, is permitted for the removal or servicing of a disabled vehicle in an emergency caused by an accident or sudden breakdown of the vehicle. However, this shall not prohibit the city or sheriff's department from immediately removing a vehicle which is blocking, hindering or otherwise endangering traffic. 
(Ord. No. 204, § 5, 1-23-96) 
Sec. 26-71. - Failure to remove abandoned or inoperative vehicle. 
    Any person who abandons a motor vehicle on any public or private property without the consent of the person in control of such property, or any person who fails, neglects or refuses to remove the abandoned, wrecked, junked, partially dismantled or inoperative vehicle or to house such vehicle and abate such nuisance in accordance with the provisions of this division shall be guilty of a violation. 
(Ord. No. 204, § 6, 1-23-96) 
Sec. 26-72. - Removal and impoundment. 
    If the registered owner of any vehicle which is in violation of this division, or if the owner or person in lawful possession or control of the property upon which such vehicle is located, shall fail, neglect or refuse to remove or house such vehicle in accordance with this division, the city or the sheriff's department may remove, take into custody, and impound such vehicle and dispose of such vehicle in accordance with the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 204, § 7, 1-23-96) 
Sec. 26-73. - Entry upon private property for removal or abatement. 
    Any person, at the direction of an authorized representative of the city or the sheriff's department, is hereby expressly authorized to enter upon private property for the purpose of enforcing this division. 
(Ord. No. 204, § 8, 1-23-96) 
Sec. 26-74. - Immediate sale. 
    When an abandoned motor vehicle is more than seven model years of age, is lacking vital component parts, and does not display a license plate currently valid in this state or any other state or foreign country, it shall immediately be eligible for sale at public auction pursuant to section 26-77, and shall not be subject to the notification, reclamation, or title provisions of sections 26-75 and 26-76. 
(Ord. No. 204, § 9, 1-23-96) 
Sec. 26-75. - Notice. 
(a)  When an abandoned motor vehicle does not fall within the provisions of section 26-74, the city or sheriff's department shall give notice of the taking within ten days. The notice shall (1) set forth the date and place of the taking, the year, make, model and serial number of the abandoned motor vehicle if such information can be reasonably obtained and the place where the vehicle is being held, (2) inform the owner and any lienholders of their right to reclaim the vehicle under section 26-76, and (3) state that failure of the owner or lienholders to exercise their right to reclaim the vehicle and contents shall be deemed a waiver by them of all right, title, and interest in the vehicle and contents and a consent to the sale of the vehicle and contents at a public auction pursuant to section 26-77. 
(b)  The notice shall be sent by mail to the registered owner, if any, of the abandoned motor vehicle and to all readily identifiable lienholders of record. If it is impossible to determine with reasonable certainty the identity and address of the registered owner and all lienholders, the notice shall be published once in a newspaper of general circulation in the area where the motor vehicle was abandoned. Published notices may be grouped together for convenience and economy. 
(Ord. No. 204, § 10, 1-23-96) 
Sec. 26-76. - Right to reclaim. 
(a)  The owner or any lienholder of an abandoned motor vehicle entitled to notice shall have a right to reclaim such vehicle from the city or sheriff's department upon payment of all tickets, towing, preservation, storage, and administration charges resulting from taking the vehicle into custody within 15 days after the date of the notice required by section 26-75. 
(b)  Nothing in this division shall be construed to impair any lien of a garagekeeper under the laws of the state, or the right of a lienholder to foreclose. For the purposes of this section, "garagekeeper" is an operator of a parking place or establishment, an operator of a motor vehicle storage facility, or an operator of an establishment for the servicing, repair, or maintenance of motor vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 204, § 11, 1-23-96) 
Sec. 26-77. - Public sale. 
(a)  An abandoned vehicle and its contents taken into custody and not reclaimed under section 26-76 shall be sold to the highest bidder at public auction or sale ten days following published notice thereof in the legal newspaper of the city. The purchaser shall be given a receipt in a form prescribed by the registrar of motor vehicles, which shall be sufficient title to dispose of the vehicle. The receipt shall also entitle the purchaser to register the vehicle and receive a certificate of title, free and clear of all liens and claims of ownership. Before such a vehicle is issued a new certificate of title, it must receive a motor vehicle safety check. 
(b)  From the proceeds of the sale of an abandoned vehicle, the city shall reimburse itself for all costs and expenses incurred in the removal and disposal of the vehicle including towing, preservation, storage, notices, publication, administration costs and legal fees. Any proceeds remaining from a sale shall be held for the owner of a vehicle or entitled lienholder for a period of 90 days, and if not claimed shall thereafter be deposited in the city treasury. 
(c)  The city shall have the right under this division to bid on any abandoned or inoperative vehicle and its contents sold at public auction or, in the event that no bids are received, to claim title to any such vehicle and contents. 
(Ord. No. 204, § 12, 1-23-96) 
Sec. 26-78. - Assessments. 
    Any costs or expenses incurred in the removal and disposal of an abandoned vehicle pursuant to this division and not fully recovered or paid may be assessed against the real property of the property owner on which the violation occurred. Such assessment shall be made according to law and filed with the county auditor for collection with the following year's real estate taxes. 
(Ord. No. 204, § 13, 1-23-96) 
Sec. 26-79. - Violation. 
    Any person violating any provision of this division shall be punished as prescribed in section 1-13 of this Code. Each day that the violation exists shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 204, § 14, 1-23-96) 
Secs. 26-80-26-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - WEEDS AND OTHER HARMFUL VEGETATION[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Public nuisances affecting health, § 26-29. 

Sec. 26-101. - Cutting and removal of grass, weeds and other poisonous, noxious or harmful vegetation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner, lessee or occupant, or any agent, servant, representative or employee of any such owner, lessee or occupant, having control of any occupied or unoccupied lot or land or any part thereof in the city to permit or maintain on any such lot or land, or on or along the sidewalk, street or alley adjacent to such lot or land between the property line and the curb or for 15 feet outside the property line if there is no curb, or up to the middle of an unimproved alley or street, any growth of weeds, grass or brush to a greater height than eight inches on the average, or any accumulation of dead weeds, grass or brush. It shall also be unlawful for any such person to cause, permit or maintain poison ivy, ragweed, noxious or other poisonous plants, or plants detrimental to health, to grow or exist on any such lot or land in the city. 
(Ord. No. 151, § 1, 7-2-85) 
Sec. 26-102. - Duty of owner, lessee or occupant. 
    It shall be the duty of any owner, lessee or occupant of any lot or land in the city to remove or cause to be removed all such weeds, grass, brush or other poisonous, noxious or harmful vegetation as often as may be necessary to comply with the provisions of section 26-101; provided that, except for poisonous, noxious or harmful vegetation, if the cutting of weeds, grass or other vegetation has been and will be undertaken for agriculturally related purposes, the cutting of such vegetation may be done at least once every 35 days between May 1 and October 1 and shall be deemed to be in compliance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 151, § 2, 7-2-85) 
Sec. 26-103. - Removal by city; collection of costs. 
    If the provisions of sections 26-101 and 26-102 are not complied with, the zoning administrator shall serve written notice upon the owner, lessee or occupant or any person having the care or control of any such lot or land to comply with the provisions of this article. If the person upon whom the notice is served fails, neglects or refuses to cut and remove or to cause to be cut and removed such weeds, grass, brush or other poisonous, noxious or harmful vegetation within seven days after receipt of such notice, or if no person can be found in the city who either is or claims to be the owner of such lot or land, or who either represents or claims to represent such owner, the clerk-treasurer shall cause such weeds, grass, brush and other poisonous, noxious or harmful vegetation on such lot or land to be cut and removed and the cost of inspection and such cutting and removal, plus other additional costs in connection therewith, shall be certified by the clerk-treasurer to the county auditor and shall thereupon become and be a lien upon the property on which such weeds, grass, brush and other poisonous, noxious or harmful vegetation were located and shall be added to and become and form part of the taxes next to be assessed and levied upon such lot or land and shall bear interest at the same rate as taxes and shall be collected and enforced by the same officer and in the same manner as taxes. 
(Ord. No. 151, § 3, 7-2-85) 
Sec. 26-104. - Violation of article; penalty. 
    Any person who shall neglect to cut and remove weeds, grass, brush or other poisonous, noxious, or harmful vegetation as directed in this article, or who shall fail, neglect or refuse to comply with the provisions of any notice provided in this article, or who shall violate any of the provisions of this article, or who shall resist or obstruct the clerk-treasurer or the city's employees in the cutting and removal of weeds, grass, brush and other poisonous, noxious or harmful vegetation, shall, upon conviction thereof, be deemed guilty of a violation and shall be punished as prescribed in section 1-13. 
(Ord. No. 151, § 4, 7-2-85) 
Secs. 26-105-26-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - TREES AND SHRUBS 

Sec. 26-121. - Intent. 
    The intent of this article is to regulate the planting, maintenance, and removal of trees and shrubs in the city by implementing the following: 
(1)  Establishing a shade tree board which is the agency responsible for prescribing regulations relating to the planting, maintenance, and removal of trees and shrubs in public places; 
(2)  Providing for the issuance of permits for the planting, maintenance, and removal of trees and shrubs in public places; and 
(3)  Providing for the pruning and removal of trees on public property which endanger public safety. 
(Ord. No. 200, § 1, 9-29-94) 
Sec. 26-122. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein: 
    City shall mean the City of Watertown, County of Carver, State of Minnesota. 
    City forester shall mean the city planner, or other qualified designated official of the city. The city forester will be assigned to carry out the enforcement of this article. 
    Forestry department shall mean the department of planning and zoning. 
    Large trees shall mean those attaining a height of 45 feet or more. 
    Medium trees shall mean those attaining a height of 30 feet to 45 feet. 
    Park shall include all city parks having individual names. 
    Person shall mean any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, or organization of any kind. 
    Principal thoroughfare shall mean any street upon which trucks are not permitted. 
    Property line shall mean the outer edge of a street or highway right-of-way. This area includes the area between the curb and the platted lot line. 
    Property owner shall mean the person owning such property as shown by the County Auditor's Plat of Carver County, State of Minnesota. 
    Public place shall include all other grounds owned by the city. 
    Public trees shall include all shade and ornamental trees now or hereafter growing on any street or any public areas where otherwise indicated. 
    Small trees shall mean those attaining a height of 20 to 30 feet. 
    Street or highway shall mean the entire width of every public way or right-of-way when any part thereof is open to the use of the public, as a matter of right, for purposes of vehicular and pedestrian traffic. 
    Treelawn shall mean that part of a street or highway, not covered by a sidewalk or other paving, lying between the property line right-of-way, and that portion of the street or highway usually used for vehicular traffic. 
(Ord. No. 200, § 3, 9-29-94) 
Sec. 26-123. - Tree board. 
(a)  Creation and establishment. There is hereby created and established a city tree board, which shall consist of the parks and recreation commission. 
(b)  Duties and responsibilities. The duties of the city tree board shall be as follows: 
(1)  To study the problems and determine the needs of the city, in connection with its tree planting program; 
(2)  To recommend to the city council the type and kind of trees to be planted upon such municipal streets or in parks as is designated; 
(3)  To assist the city council and the citizens of the city in the dissemination of news and information regarding the selection, planting, preservation and maintenance of trees, whether the same is on private or public property, and to make such recommendations from time to time to the city council as to desirable legislation concerning the tree program and activities for the municipality. 
(4)  To provide regular and special meetings at which the subject of trees insofar as it relates to the municipality may be discussed by the members of the city tree board, officers and personnel of the municipality and its several divisions, and all others interested in the city tree program. 
(c)  Operation. The board shall operate within the rules set forth by the resolution establishing the parks and recreation commission. 
(Ord. No. 200, §§ 4-6, 9-29-94) 
Sec. 26-124. - City forester. 
(a)  Appointment. The city forester shall be appointed by the city council. 
(b)  Authority. The authority of the city forester shall be in accordance with the city forester job description. 
(Ord. No. 200, §§ 7, 8, 9-29-94) 
Sec. 26-125. - Permits required. 
(a)  Planting maintenance or removal. No person shall plant, spray, fertilize, preserve, prune, remove, cut above ground, or otherwise disturb any tree on any street or municipal-owned property without first obtaining a permit from the city forester or otherwise specified municipal authority. 
(b)  Planting. 
(1)  Application data. The application required herein shall state the number of trees to be set out; the location, grade, species, variety of each tree; the method of planting; and such other information as the city forester shall find reasonably necessary to determine whether a permit should be issued. 
(2)  Improper planting. Whenever any tree shall be planted or set out in conflict with the provisions of this section, it shall be lawful for the city forester to remove or cause removal of the same, and the exact cost thereof shall be assessed to the owner as provided by law in the case of assessments. 
(c)  Maintenance; application data. The application required herein shall state the number and kinds of trees to be sprayed, fertilized, pruned, protected, or otherwise preserved; the kind of treatment to be administered; the composition of the material to be applied; and other information as the city forester shall find necessary to determine whether a permit should be issued. 
(d)  Removal, replanting and replacement. No person or property owner shall remove a tree from the treelawn for the purpose of construction, or for any other reason without first filing an application and obtaining a permit from the city forester, and without replacing the removed tree or trees. The person or property owner shall bear the cost of removal and replacement of all trees removed from private property and 50 percent of the removal cost of all boulevard trees. 
(Ord. No. 200, § 9, 9-29-94) 
Sec. 26-126. - Public tree care. 
(a)  The city shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain, remove, or perform any other arborcultural practices as decided necessary within the lines of all streets, alleys, avenues, lanes, squares, and public grounds, as may be necessary to insure public safety or to preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds. No other planting may be done without consent of the city forester. 
(b)  The city tree board may remove or cause or order to be removed, any tree or part thereof which is in an unsafe condition or which by reason of its nature is injurious to sewers, electric power lines, gas lines, water lines, or other public improvements, or affected with any injurious fungus, insect or other pest. The tree board shall notify affected property owners of removal or trimming to be done and give the property owner the option to complete the work by contract with a city-approved tree contractor. Under certain conditions (i.e., emergency situations), the city may complete the work without prior notification to the property owner. 
(c)  Every tree overhanging any street or right-of-way within the city shall be pruned so that the branches shall not obstruct the light from any street lamp or obstruct the view of any street intersection and so that there shall be a clear space of eight feet above the surface of the street or sidewalk. Dead, diseased or dangerous trees, broken or decayed limbs which constitute a menace to the safety of the public shall be removed. The city shall have the right to prune any tree or shrub on private property when it interferes with the proper spread of light along the street from a street light or interferes with visibility of any traffic control device or sign. 
(d)  The minimum clearance of any overhanging portion of 12 feet over all streets except truck thoroughfares which shall have a clearance of 16 feet. 
(Ord. No. 200, § 10, 9-29-94) 
Sec. 26-127. - Abuse or mutilation of public trees. 
(a)  Unless specifically authorized by the city forester, no person shall intentionally damage, cut, carve, transplant, or remove any tree; attach any rope, wire, nails, advertising posters, or other contrivance to any tree, allow an gaseous liquid, or solid substance which is harmful to such trees to come in contact with them; or set fire or permit any fire to burn when such fire or the heat thereof will injure any portion of any tree. 
(b)  It shall be an unlawful practice for any person, firm, or city department to top any street tree, park tree, or other tree on public property without authorization from the city forester. 
(c)  Topping can be defined as severe cutting back of a branch to a stub. 
(Ord. No. 200, § 11, 9-29-94) 
Sec. 26-128. - Protection of trees. 
    A tree preservation plan is to be submitted by all developers and/or builders in accordance with Ordinance No. 183, regulating subdivisions in the city. 
(Ord. No. 200, § 12, 9-29-94) 
Sec. 26-129. - Violation and penalty. 
    Any person violating any provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 200, § 13, 9-29-94) 
Secs. 26-130-26-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - RECREATIONAL FIRES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 236, § 1, adopted Oct. 8, 2002, set out provisions pertaining to recreational fires intended for use as § 26-130. To reserve room for expansion of the Code, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been redesignated as § 26-151. 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 27. 

Sec. 26-151. - Recreational fires permitted. 
    Recreational fires within the City of Watertown shall be permitted only under the following conditions: 
(1)  Recreational fires shall not be conducted within 25 feet of any building, structure or combustible material. Conditions which could cause a fire to spread within 25 feet of a building or structure shall be eliminated prior to ignition. 
(2)  Recreational fires shall be conducted within a fire pit or surrounded completely by noncombustible and non-smoke or odor producing material such as rock, cement, brick, tile, or metal. 
(3)  Recreational fires shall be conducted using only wood or charcoal. No rubbish, yard waste, or construction debris shall be burned. 
(4)  Recreational fires shall not exceed three feet in diameter or three feet in height. 
(5)  Recreational fires shall not last longer than 12 consecutive hours. 
(6)  Fire extinguishing equipment such as a fire extinguisher, garden hose connected to a water supply, shovel, or water buckets shall be readily available for use at a recreational fire. 
(7)  Recreational fires shall be constantly attended by a person knowledgeable in the use of fire extinguishing equipment. An attendant shall supervise a recreational fire until the fire has been extinguished. 
(8)  Any officer of the Watertown Fire Department, Minnesota Department of Natural Resources, or Carver County Deputy Sheriff is authorized to require that recreational fires be immediately discontinued if such fires are determined to constitute a hazardous situation or the requirements of this section are not followed. 
(9)  Recreational fires are not permitted when the Minnesota Department of Natural Resources or fire chief has declared a burning ban or air quality alert. 
(Ord. No. 236, § 1, 10-8-02) 
Secs. 26-152-26-175. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - NOISE 

Sec. 26-176. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City means the City of Watertown or any representative of the department of building, planning, and public works or any other representative of the city as designated by the city administrator or city council. 
    Dynamic braking device means any device, primarily used on trucks, for the conversion of the engine from an internal combustion engine to an air compressor for the purpose of braking without the use of wheel brakes. Also commonly referred to as Jacobs brakes, Jake brakes, engine brakes, or compression brakes. 
    L10 level means the noise level, expressed in decibels (dBA), which is exceeded ten percent of the time within a one hour period, as measured by test procedures approved by the city using a sound level meter having characteristics as specified in the latest standards, S1.4, of the American National Standards Institute (ANSI). 
    L50 level means the noise level, expressed in decibels (dBA), which is exceeded 50 percent of the time within a one hour period, as measured by test procedures approved by the city using a sound level meter having characteristics as specified in the latest standards, S1.4, of the American National Standards Institute (ANSI). 
    NAC means noise area classification, based upon the land use activity at the location of the receiver and determines the noise standards that are applicable to the particular land use activity. 
    Noise means any sound not occurring in the natural environment, which shall include, but is not limited to, sounds produced by persons, aircraft, highways, motor vehicles, and/or emanating from residential, commercial, and industrial sources. 
    Noise pollution means the existence or combination of noises in such a quantity and/or at such levels, or of such nature or duration, that under these conditions could be potentially injurious or hazardous to human health, safety, welfare, or property, and which interferes with the enjoyment of life or property. 
    Obscene noise means any noise that in the opinion of the city is excessively and exceptionally injurious and detrimental to the public due to language used, manner of communication or the time of day. 
    Person means an individual, firm, partnership, corporation, trustee, association, the state and its agencies and subdivisions, or any body of persons whether incorporated or not and, with respect to acts prohibited or required herein, "person" shall include employees and licensees. 
    Receiving land use districts means the property, which contains the person, building, business, or activity being affected by the noise or noise pollution. 
    Sound level (noise level) means a weighted sound pressure level, expressed in decibels (dBA), obtained through the use of a sound level meter having characteristics as specified in the American National Standards Institute (ANSI) Specifications for Sound Level Meters. 
(Ord. No. 270, § 1, 6-28-05) 
Sec. 26-177. - Noises prohibited. 
(1)  General prohibition. No person shall make or cause to be made a distinctly and loudly audible noise that unreasonably annoys, disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace, safety or welfare of any person or precludes their enjoyment of property or affects their property's value. This general prohibition is not limited by the specific restriction of the following subsections of this section. 
(2)  Motor vehicles. No person shall operate a motor vehicle within the city limits in violation of the motor vehicle noise limits established by the Minnesota Pollution Control Agency, pursuant to M.S.A. § 169.693. 
(3)  Horns, audible signaling devices, etc. No person shall sound any audible signaling device on any vehicle except as a warning of danger, pursuant to M.S.A. § 169.68. 
(4)  Exhaust. No person shall discharge the exhaust, or permit the discharge of exhaust from any steam engine, stationary internal combustion engine, motor boat, motor vehicle, or snowmobile except through a muffler or other device that effectively prevents loud or explosive noises and complies with all applicable state regulations and laws. 
(5)  Defective vehicles or loads. No person shall operate any vehicle out of repair or loaded to such an extent that the vehicle creates loud or unnecessary grating, grinding, rattling, or any other noise. 
(6)  Radios, phonographs, paging systems, etc. No person shall use, operate, or permit the use of any radio receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph, paging system, machine or other device for the production or reproduction of sound in a distinct and loudly audible manner as to disturb the peace, quiet, and comfort of any person nearby. Operation of any such set, instrument, phonograph, machine or other device between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. in such a manner as to be plainly audible at the property line of the structure or building in which it is located, in the hallway or apartment adjacent, or at a distance of 50 feet if the source is located outside a structure or building shall be evidence of violation of this section. 
(7)  Participation in noisy parties or gatherings. No person shall participate in any party or other gathering of people giving rise to noise, disturbing the peace, quiet, or repose of another person. If a police officer determines that such a gathering is creating a noise disturbance, the police officer may order all persons present, other than the owner or tenant of the premises where the disturbance is occurring, to leave immediately. No person shall refuse to leave after being ordered by the police officer to do so. Every owner or tenant of such premises who has knowledge of the disturbance shall make a reasonable effort to see that the disturbance is stopped. 
(8)  Loudspeakers, amplifiers for advertising, etc. No person shall operate or permit the use or operation of any loudspeaker, sound amplifier or other device for the production or reproduction of sound on a street or other public place for the purpose of commercial advertising or attracting the attention of the public to any commercial establishment or vehicle. 
(9)  Animals. No person owning, operating, having charge of, or occupying any building or premises shall keep or allow to be kept any animal which shall, by any noise, unreasonably disturb the peace and quiet of any person in the vicinity. The phrase "unreasonably disturb the peace and quiet" shall include, but is not limited to, the creation of any noise by any animal which can be heard by any person, including a law enforcement officer or animal control officer, from a location outside of the building or premises where the animal is being kept and which animal noise occurs repeatedly over at least a five-minute period of time with one minute or less lapse of time between animal noise during the five minute period. 
(10)  Schools, churches, hospitals, etc. No person shall create any excessive noise on any street, alley, or public place adjacent to any school, institution, church, or hospital if the noises unreasonably interfere with the working of the institution and disturbs or unduly annoys its occupants or residents or when posted signs indicate the presence of such institutions. 
(11)  Dynamic braking devices. No person shall use motor vehicle brakes that are in any way operated or activated by the compression of the engine in any motor vehicle upon any public ways located within the city limits of Watertown, including, but not limited to, highways, streets, alleys, easements, or right-of-ways. An affirmative defense to prosecution under this subdivision shall demonstrate that the compression brakes were applied in an emergency situation or were considered necessary to prevent immediate or unanticipated danger to life or property. 
(Ord. No. 270, § 2, 6-28-05) 
Sec. 26-178. - Hourly restriction on certain operations. 
(1)  Domestic power equipment. No person shall operate a power lawn mower, power hedge, clipper, chainsaw, mulcher, garden tiller, edger, drill or other similar domestic power maintenance equipment except between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. on any weekday or between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. on any weekend or holiday. Snow removal and street sweeping equipment is exempt from this subsection. 
(2)  Refuse hauling. No person shall collect or remove garbage or refuse in any residential district except between the hours of 6:30 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. on any weekday or between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. on any weekend or holiday. 
(3)  Construction activities. No person shall engage in or permit construction activities involving the use of any kind of electric, diesel or gas powered machine or other power equipment, manual tools, movement of equipment, and other activities except between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. on any weekday or between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. on any weekend or holiday. 
(Ord. No. 270, § 3, 6-28-05) 
Sec. 26-179. - Receiving land use standards. 
(1)  Maximum noise levels by receiving land use districts. No person shall operate, cause, or permit to be operated any source of noise in such a manner as to create a noise level, which exceeds those limits set in Table 1 for the receiving land use category specified when measured at a point of normal human activity for the receiving land use district. The sound level within any particular zoning district shall be the responsibility of the person who owns, operates, or contributes to the sound level, regardless of the zoning district in question. 
Table 1: Sound Levels by Receiving Land Use Districts 
Day 
(7:00 a.m.-10:00 p.m.) Night 
(10:00 p.m.-7:00 a.m.) Land Use 
Districts L10 L50 L10 L50 Residential 65 60 55 50 Commercial 70 65 70 65 Industrial 80 75 80 75  
(2)  Exemptions. The levels prescribed in subsection (1), Table 1 of this section, do not apply to noise which is generated by railroads or motor vehicles traveling on state or county highways, but such noise shall be subject to other applicable sections of this article. 
(3)  Measurement of noise level. Sound level requirements shall apply at the area of human activity or at the property or zoning lines of the receiving land use district. Measurements shall also be taken at any location within the receiving land use district for the purpose of evaluation and to enforce other sections of this article. 
(Ord. No. 270, § 4, 6-28-05) 
Sec. 26-180. - Exception for emergency work. 
    Noise created exclusively for the performance of emergency work to preserve the public health, safety, or welfare, or in the performance of emergency work necessary to restore a public service or eliminate a public hazard shall be exempt from the provisions of this article. Persons responsible for performing such emergency work shall inform the city of the need to initiate the work or if the work is commenced during non-business hours of the city, then at the beginning of business hours for the city on the next business day. Any person responsible for such emergency work shall take all reasonable actions to minimize the amount of noise or noise pollution. 
(Ord. No. 270, § 5, 6-28-05) 
Sec. 26-181. - Power and duties of the city. 
(1)  Administering officer. The city and its related departments shall administer the noise control program established by this article. 
(2)  Testing procedures. The city shall adopt guidelines establishing the testing procedures and the specific instrumentation to be used to enforce the provisions established within this article. A copy of these guidelines shall be kept on file at city hall and shall be made available for review by the public during office hours. 
(a)  Measurement methodology. The city shall enforce the rules and procedures established by the Minnesota Pollution Control Agency, pursuant to Minnesota Rules chapter 7030.0060, as a guide for the enforcement of the noise provisions as established within this article. 
1.  Measurement location. The measurement of sound shall be made at or within the applicable noise area classification (NAC) at the point of human activity that is nearest to the noise source. All measurements must be made outdoors. 
2.  Equipment specifications. All sound level measuring devices shall meet Type O, I, II, or S specifications as established by the American National Standards Institute S1.4-1983. 
3.  Calibration. All sound level measuring devices shall, at a minimum, be externally field calibrated both before and after monitoring using a calibration device of known frequency and sound pressure level. 
4.  Measurement procedures. The following procedures shall be used to obtain representative sound level measurements: 
a.  Measurements shall be made at least three feet off the ground or surface and away from natural of artificial structures that would result in an inaccurate measurement. 
b.  Measurements shall be made using the A-weighting and fast response characteristics of the sound measuring device as specified by the American National Standards Institute S1.4-1983. 
c.  Measurements shall not be made in sustained winds or in precipitation that results in a difference of less than ten decibels between the background noise level and the noise source being measured. 
d.  Measurements shall be made using a microphone that is protected from ambient conditions that would prevent an accurate measurement. 
5.  Data documentation. A summary sheet for all sound level measurements shall be completed and signed by the person making the measurements. At a minimum, the summary sheet shall include: 
a.  Date; 
b.  Time; 
c.  Location; 
d.  Noise source; 
e.  Wind speed and direction; 
f.  Temperature; 
g.  Humidity; 
h.  Make, model, and serial number of measuring equipment; 
i.  Field calibration results; 
j.  Monitored levels; and 
k.  Site sketch indicating noise source, measurement location, directions, distances, and obstructions. 
(3)  Studies and inspections. The city shall conduct research, monitoring, and other studies related to sound as are necessary to enforce the provisions of this article. A city official shall inspect existing or potential noise or noise pollution as frequently as deemed necessary to ensure compliance with this article. Upon request of the city, the person responsible for any noise or noise pollution shall permit access to the area at any reasonable time for the purpose of inspection and monitoring of the site. The city shall be allowed access to all records and documents relating to the noise or noise pollution as necessary to determine compliance with this article. 
(4)  Noise impact statements. The city may require noise impact statements in association with, but not limited to, a change in zoning classification; or for a permit or license for any structure, operation, process, installation, alteration, or project that may be considered a potential noise source to submit a noise impact statement. The city shall evaluate each statement and make recommendations to the city council either in favor or against the license or permit for which the applicant is requesting. 
(5)  Other powers and duties. The city shall exercise the right to perform other such duties that are considered reasonable and necessary in order to enforce this article. If the established testing procedures and the specific instrumentation to be used to enforce the provisions established within this article are not readily available upon the receiving of a complaint, the sheriff's department or its members shall use their discretion when enforcing the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 270, § 6, 6-28-05) 
Sec. 26-182. - Variances. 
(1)  Authority. The city shall have the power and authority to grant variances from the requirements as established within this article. 
(2)  Application. 
(a)  Required. A variance is required in order to create temporary noise conditions, which may exceed the requirements established within section 26-181 of this article. A person seeking a variance shall submit an application to the city. The application shall state the dates during which the variance is proposed, the location of the noise source, the reasons why the variance is sought, the steps that will be taken to minimize the noise level to adjacent areas, and any other information requested by the city that is considered pertinent to the granting of such variance. If the application for the variance is for more than one day, additional information may be required. Once a complete application has been filed, the city shall notify all residences within 500 feet of the subject area. The notification shall indicate a date, time, and place for a public hearing in which the request will be heard. 
(b)  Exception. City street and utility maintenance and construction do not require a variance. City council approved functions, including, but not limited to festivals, concerts and sporting events do not require a variance 
(3)  Action on application. A public hearing will be held on the requested variance. At such time, all persons affected shall be given the opportunity to be heard. The city shall either approve or deny the application within 30 days of receipt. In determining whether to approve or deny the application, the city shall find that full compliance with the requirements as stated within the ordinance would constitute an unreasonable hardship for the applicant or the surrounding community. The hardship of the applicant shall be balanced against the potential adverse impact on the health, safety, and welfare of the persons affected, the surrounding properties, and all other possible adverse effects of granting the variance. A variance may be granted subject to specific conditions, which may include, but are not limited to, time limits. 
(4)  Grounds for denial. A variance request may be denied if a history of complaints has been filed for excessive noise in violation of this article or if conditions to minimize the adverse effects upon the community or surrounding neighborhood have not been met as established under any previous variance request. 
(5)  Duration. A variance application shall not exceed six events and may be renewed upon request by the original applicant for a period not to exceed three additional events. Renewal shall be subsequent to review and approval by the city. 
(6)  Violation. If the holder of a variance should violate the terms and/or conditions of the granted variance, the variance shall be revoked without any prior written notice. 
(Ord. No. 270, § 7, 6-28-05) 
Sec. 26-183. - Enforcement. 
(1)  Notice of violations. If the city should determine that a noise exceeds the maximum sound level permitted within this article, written notice of the violation shall be sent to the owner or occupant of the premises where the noise or noise pollution originates. Such person shall be given a reasonable amount of time in which to correct or remove the violation. Failure to correct or remove the violation within the specified time period constitutes a violation of this article. 
a.  Notwithstanding the above, the city, upon determination of an obscene noise violation, may choose to issue a citation without a prior written warning. 
(2)  Enforcement duties. The Carver County Sheriff, by contract with the city, shall enforce this article. 
(3)  General penalty. Every person who violates any provision of this article is guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction, be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-13 of this Code, plus the costs of prosecution. Each act of violation and each day a violation occurs or continues constitutes a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 270, § 8, 6-28-05) 
ARTICLE VIII. - PREDATORY OFFENDER RESIDENCY RESTRICTION 

Sec. 26-184. - Findings and intent. 
(a)  Repeat predatory offenders present a threat to the public safety of the community as a whole, especially children. Predatory offenders assigned a risk level III under the risk assessment scale established by the Minnesota Commissioner of Corrections are more likely than other classifications of offenders to use physical violence, to repeat their offenses, to have committed multiple offenses, to have more victims than are ever reported, and, as a result, to be prosecuted for only a fraction of their crimes. The cost of predatory offender victimization to society at large, while not precisely calculable, is steep. 
(b)  As expressed in M.S.A. § 412.221, Subd. 32, the city has power to provide for the prevention of crime, the benefit of residence, and the promotion of health, safety, order, convenience, and the general welfare, as it deems necessary and expedient. 
(c)  The city has a compelling interest in promoting, protecting, and improving the health, safety, and general welfare of its citizens, and specifically has a compelling interest to protect against the serious threat to children posed by predatory offenders, including the risk of recidivism and harm that released sex offenders, assessed at a risk level III due to their high risk of re-offense, will pose to this community. 
(d)  By this section, the city prohibits certain predatory offenders of risk level III from establishing temporary or permanent residence in certain locations where children are known to regularly congregate in concentrated numbers. 
(Ord. No. 397, § 1, 6-28-16) 
Sec. 26-185. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
(1)  Child: Any person under the age of 18. 
(2)  Child care facility: A facility licensed by the Minnesota Department of Human Services, or Carver County to provide child care, including facilities having programs for children known as nursery schools, day nurseries, child care centers, day care centers, cooperative day care centers, and Head Start programs. 
(3)  Designated offender: Any person who has been categorized as a level III predatory offender under M.S.A. § 244.052, a successor statute, or a similar statute from another state in which that person's risk assessment indicates a high risk of re-offense. 
(4)  Permanent residence: A place where a person abides, lodges, or resides for 14 or more consecutive days. 
(5)  Public park: A public recreation center or area, created, established, designated, maintained, provided, or set aside by the city, county, or state, for the purposes of public rest, recreation, and enjoyment, and all buildings, facilities, and structures located thereon. 
(6)  Public playground: A city, county, or state-owned public improved outdoor area designed, equipped, and set aside for children's play, including a school building playground, a child care building playground, a play area of a public park, or an area that contains permanent play equipment open to the public. 
(7)  Temporary residence: A place where a person abides, lodges, or resides for a period of 14 or more days in the aggregate during any calendar year and which is not the person's permanent residence, or a place where the person routinely abides, lodges, or resides for a period of four or more consecutive or non-consecutive days in any month and which is not the person's permanent residence. 
(8)  School: Any public or nonpublic elementary or secondary school. 
(Ord. No. 397, § 1, 6-28-16) 
Sec. 26-186. - Residence prohibition. 
(a)  Prohibited location of residence: It is unlawful for any designated offender to establish a permanent or temporary residence within 1,000 feet of any school, public park, or public playground, or 500 feet of any child care facility. 
(b)  Measurement of distance: For purposes of determining the minimum distance separation required by subsection (a), the requirement shall be measured by following a straight line from the outer property line of the permanent or temporary residence of the designated offender to the nearest outer property line of the school, child care facility, public park, or public playground. 
(c)  Official map: The city clerk shall maintain an official map showing prohibited locations as defined by this section. The clerk shall update the map annually to reflect any changes in the location of prohibited zones. The map shall not be deemed conclusive or all encompassing, or relieve any person subject to this ordinance from their duty to comply with the prohibitions herein, since prohibited zones change from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 397, § 1, 6-28-16) 
Sec. 26-187. - Penalty. 
    Any person convicted of violating any provision of this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-13 of this Code. Each day that a designated offender maintains a permanent or temporary residence in violation of this Code shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 397, § 1, 6-28-16) 
Sec. 26-188. - Exemptions. 
    A designated offender residing within the prohibited area as described in section 26-186 does not commit a violation of that section if any of the following apply: 
(1)  The designated offender established the permanent or temporary residence and reported and registered the residence pursuant to M.S.A. §§ 243.166 and 243.167 or a successor statute, prior to July 15, 2016. 
(2)  The designated offender was a minor when he or she committed the offense and he or she was not convicted as an adult. 
(3)  The designated offender is a minor. 
(4)  The school, public park, or public playground within 1,000 feet of the designated offender's permanent residence or temporary residence or the child care facility within 500 feet of the designated offender's permanent residence or temporary residence was opened after the designated offender established the permanent residence or temporary residence and reported and registered the residence pursuant to M.S.A. §§ 243.166 and 243.167 or a successor statute. 
(5)  The designated offender's permanent or temporary residence is also the primary residence of the designated offender's parent(s), grandparent(s), sibling(s), spouse, or child(ren). 
(6)  The designated offender's permanent or temporary residence is property purchased, leased, or contracted with and licensed by the Minnesota Department of Corrections prior to July 15, 2016. 
(Ord. No. 397, § 1, 6-28-16)
