If the city council determines that a site plan contains minor additions to an existing development, the site plan is not subject to the requirements of this article. 
    Where development is proposed for property not contiguous to land already served by public facilities, such services shall be extended or provided to the property at total cost to the developer or property owner, including all costs necessary for oversizing, land acquisition, engineering, etc. 
(Ord. No. 243, § 05, 2-11-03) 
Sec. 46.5-6. - Denial. 
    New development not meeting the requirements for adequate public facilities contained within this article shall not be recommended for approval by the planning commission except pursuant to sections 46.5-8 or 46.5-23. 
(Ord. No. 243, § 06, 2-11-03) 
Sec. 46.5-7. - Minor subdivisions exempt. 
    Subdivisions which can be approved by the minor subdivision procedure described in the City of Watertown Subdivision Ordinance are not subject to the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 243, § 07, 2-11-03) 
Cross reference- Minor subdivision approval, § 52-46. 
Sec. 46.5-8. - Variance. 
    The planning commission may recommend and the city council may grant a variance from the requirements of this article only if the variance meets the following requirements: 
(1)  Granting the variance would observe the spirit of this article and secure public safety and welfare; and 
(2)  The physical features and characteristics of the proposed plat or site plan are such that a waiver would not impair the intent and purpose of the requirement; and 
(3)  The variance will not endanger or present a threat to the public health, safety, or welfare; and 
(4)  The requirements imposed by this article would result in extraordinary hardship. 
(Ord. No. 243, § 08, 2-11-03) 
Secs. 46.5-9-46.5-30. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ROADS/TRAILS 

Sec. 46.5-31. - Generally. 
    All new development shall be served by an adequate network of existing and proposed new roads and trails. 
(Ord. No. 243, 2-11-03) 
Sec. 46.5-32. - Exemptions. 
(a)  The city council may exempt from the terms of this article the subdivision of land used solely for agricultural purposes, provided: 
(1)  No more than four lots shall be created; and 
(2)  There exists in the original tract of land ten acres per each lot subdivided; and 
(3)  The road in front of each lot to be subdivided has been constructed to or will be constructed to city design standards. 
(b)  The city council may exempt from the terms of this article the subdivision of land used for agricultural purposes solely for transfer to a member of the immediate family of the owner(s) of the original tract of land. Any such subdivision shall provide a declaration, signed by the owner, that: 
(1)  Certifies the intent of the owner to transfer the land only to a member of the immediate family; and 
(2)  Expressly warrants that no conveyance of the lot will be made to anyone not a member of the immediate family for a period of ten years, except as may be required to satisfy a mortgage in case of loan foreclosure. 
(3)  Where the planning commission finds that extraordinary hardship will result from strict compliance with this article because of alteration to existing historic structures, including bridges, as determined by the National Register of Historic Places, the planning commission may recommend and the city council may approve a subdivision so that substantial justice may be done and the public interest secured. 
(Ord. No. 243, § 09, 2-11-03) 
Sec. 46.5-33. - New public roads. 
(a)  New public roads required to be built as part of the new development shall be constructed to the standards adopted by the city, at the expense of the owner or developer. 
(b)  The city engineer may require a traffic impact study for proposed development to be provided by the developer in order to determine existing road capacities and construction standards applicable to the new development. 
(c)  The type and location of roads to be built or improved shall be based on the projected volume of traffic that will be generated by the new development in accordance with the adopted standards by the city, or as determined by the county engineer and/or the MNDOT depending on the jurisdiction of the roadway in question. 
(Ord. No. 243, § 10, 2-11-03) 
Sec. 46.5-34. - Existing public roads. 
(a)  Existing public roads proposed to serve the new development shall meet the standards adopted by the city. Where an existing road is a county or state highway, such roads are to meet all applicable standards as established by appropriate jurisdiction. 
(b)  Adequate roads shall provide safe and efficient access to, from, and within a new development. Such access shall include access to adjacent commercial, industrial, and recreational properties. Adequate roads shall be extended to property lines, as required by the city. Where a property is adjacent to or has frontage on an unimproved road, such road shall be improved to applicable design standards. The portion of the existing roads required to be adequate for the proposed new development shall be those that meet the intent of this section and provide access to and from the development to the nearest designated intersection with a road to be adequate to support the projected traffic volume generated by the development, as recommended by the city engineer. 
(c)  In evaluating the adequacy of the existing roads or the improvements necessary to make the existing roads adequate, the following shall be considered, but not be limited to by the planning commission and city council: 
(1)  Existing traffic. 
(2)  Traffic projected to be generated by the development. 
(3)  Traffic projected to be generated by other approved but not constructed development, including potential development outlined by the comprehensive plan or applicable area plans. 
(4)  Improvements scheduled or approved by the City of Watertown, Carver County, and MNDOT to take place within two years from the anticipated date of final plat approval. 
(5)  Traffic studies that may be required by the city engineer and county engineer and/or the MNDOT. 
(6)  Any other information that may reasonably be required by the city engineer, county engineer, MNDOT, planning commission, or city council to effectively evaluate the road network or information supplied by the developer. 
(Ord. No. 243, § 11, 2-11-03) 
Sec. 46.5-35. - Inadequacy determined. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article, if an existing road is determined by the planning commission and city council to be inadequate to accommodate the traffic flow projected to be generated from the new development when combined with existing traffic flow, the new development shall not be approved. 
(Ord. No. 243, § 12, 2-11-03) 
Sec. 46.5-36. - Trails. 
    Trails shall be provided in accordance with the comprehensive trail plan transportation plan and as directed by the planning commission and city council. 
(Ord. No. 243, § 13, 2-11-03) 
Cross reference- Trails, §§ 52-134, 52-135. 
Secs. 46.5-37-46.5-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SCHOOLS 

Sec. 46.5-61. - Generally. 
    New residential developments will be approved by the city council only when it can be reasonably expected that adequate public school facilities will be available to accommodate such developments. 
(Ord. No. 243, 2-11-03) 
Sec. 46.5-62. - Adequacy determined. 
    The Watertown-Mayer School Board may review all subdivision plans as required by this article, and forward a recommendation within 30 days to the planning commission based on the adequacy of the current or proposed facilities. 
(Ord. No. 243, § 14, 2-11-03) 
Secs. 46.5-63-46.5-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEMS 

Sec. 46.5-86. - Generally. 
    All new development shall be served by adequate sewage disposal systems. 
(Ord. No. 243, § 01, 2-11-03) 
Sec. 46.5-87. - Adequacy determined. 
(a)  In evaluating the adequacy of any sewage disposal system (other than a private, individual, on-site system), all parts of the system affected by the projected flow generated from the new development shall be considered including, but not limited to, laterals, interceptors, pumping stations, force mains, points of discharge, flow meters and rights-of-way. 
(b)  In evaluating the adequacy of sewage disposal systems, the following may be considered, but shall not be limited to: 
(1)  Design capacity. 
(2)  Available capacity. 
(3)  The city's adopted standards, guidelines, policies, and procedures. 
(4)  The projected flow to be generated by the new development. 
(5)  Other proposed or expected connections to the system reasonably probable of fruition. 
(6)  Other variables found to have an effect on the systems ability to accept the projected flow. 
(Ord. No. 243, § 15, 2-11-03) 
Cross reference- Sanitary sewer, § 52-137. 
Sec. 46.5-88. - Determination of expected flow. 
    The projected flow for the proposed development shall be evaluated by a Minnesota Registered Professional Engineer and a complete report submitted to the city for review. Adequacy of the system shall then be determined by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 243, § 16, 2-11-03) 
Sec. 46.5-89. - Inadequacy determined. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article, if the city council, upon recommendation of the city engineer, determines that the sewage disposal system is inadequate to accommodate the sewage disposal needs of the new development when considered together with existing development and development which is reasonably probable of fruition, the new development shall not be approved. 
(Ord. No. 243, § 17, 2-11-03) 
Secs. 46.5-90-46.5-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - WATER SUPPLY AND DISTRIBUTION SYSTEMS 

Sec. 46.5-111. - Generally. 
    All new development shall be served by an adequate water supply and distribution system which provides sufficient water and service pressure for domestic consumption and fire protection. 
(Ord. No. 243, § 17, 2-11-03) 
Sec. 46.5-112. - Adequacy determined. 
(a)  The adequacy of the water supply distribution system shall be evaluated by a Minnesota Registered Professional Engineer and a complete report submitted to the city for review. Adequacy of the system shall then be determined by the city council. 
(b)  When evaluating the adequacy of any water supply and distribution system for domestic consumption and fire protection other than a private, individual on site water supply (well), all parts of the system affected by the projected water needs of the new development shall be considered, including, but not limited to the following: 
(1)  The system's design capacity. 
(2)  The system's water supply source. 
(3)  The system's available capacity. 
(4)  The adopted guidelines, standards, procedures and policies regarding water service. 
(5)  The projected water needs of the proposed development including domestic consumption and fire protection. 
(6)  Other proposed or expected connections to the system reasonably probable of fruition. 
(7)  The evaluations and recommendations of the fire department. 
(8)  Other variables found to have an effect on the ability of the water system to deliver the projected water needs of the development. 
(9)  Existing storage, treatment, and pumping facilities affected by the proposed development. 
(Ord. No. 243, § 18, 2-11-03) 
Cross reference- Water supply, § 52-136. 
Sec. 46.5-113. - Inadequacy determined. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article, if the city, upon recommendation from the city engineer, determines that the community or multi-use water supply and distribution system is inadequate to accommodate the projected needs of the new development, or will result in an unreasonable drop of water pressure, the development shall not be approved. 
(Ord. No. 243, § 19, 2-11-03) 
Secs. 46.5-114-46.5-135. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - PARKS 

Sec. 46.5-136. - Generally. 
    All new development shall be served by an adequate system of active and passive parks which provide sufficient opportunity for recreation activities. 
(Ord. No. 243, 2-11-03) 
Sec. 46.5-137. - New parkland. 
    New parkland and park improvements shall be provided in accordance with the Watertown Subdivision Code, the Watertown Park Improvement 2002 study, which is a proportional improvement of the park system based on the proposed or potential increase of new residents and park users, and other studies the city council may deem necessary from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 243, § 20, 2-11-03) 
Cross reference- Parks, § 52-166. 
Sec. 46.5-138. - Adequacy determined. 
    New residential developments will be approved by the city council only when it can be shown that adequate parkland is available to accommodate the new development. The city may require a study to ascertain the location and type of parkland required based on the size and type of the proposed development. 
(Ord. No. 243, § 21, 2-11-03) 
Secs. 46.5-139-46.5-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - WARNING SYSTEMS 

Sec. 46.5-161. - Generally. 
    All new development shall be served with adequate civil and weather warning systems. 
(Ord. No. 243, 2-11-03) 
Sec. 46.5-162. - Adequacy determined. 
    The adequacy of the existing and proposed warning system shall be determined by the city upon recommendations made by the city engineer, fire chief, and Carver County Emergency Management. 
(Ord. No. 243, § 22, 2-11-03) 
Sec. 46.5-163. - Exceptions. 
    Nothing under the terms of this article shall prohibit or prevent the city from reaching an agreement with a property owner or developer concerning the construction of the necessary improvements for the purpose of ensuring that public facilities are adequate as required by this article. 
(Ord. No. 243, § 23, 2-11-03) 
Chapter 47 - SEXUALLY ORIENTED BUSINESSES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 326, § 1, adopted September 10, 2008, repealed the former Ch. 47, §§ 47-1-47-5, 47-21-47-29 and 47-51-47-55, and Ord. No. 327, adopted September 10, 2008, enacted a new Ch. 47 as set out herein. The former Ch. 47 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 207, adopted April 22, 1997. 

ARTICLE I. - GENERAL 

Sec. 47-1. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this provision of the Watertown City Code is to prescribe requirements for adult use establishments in order to protect and promote the health, safety, morals, decency and general welfare of residents in the city. 
(Ord. No. 327, § 1, 9-10-08) 
Sec. 47-2. - Findings of the city council. 
    The city council of Watertown makes the following findings regarding the effects that adult use establishments have on the character of the City of Watertown's neighborhoods. In making these findings, the city council accepts the recommendations and conclusions of the "Report of the Attorney General's Working Group on Regulation of Sexually Oriented Businesses," (Humphrey III, June 6, 1989), "Adult Entertainment Report," (Olmstead County Planning Department, March 2, 1988), "A 40-Acre Study," (St. Paul Division of Planning, 1967), hereafter collectively referred to as "reports," which are on file at city hall. 
(1)  Sexually oriented business can contribute to an increase in criminal activity in the area in which such businesses are located, increasing the demands on city crime-prevention programs and law enforcement services. 
(2)  Sexually oriented businesses can be used as fronts for prostitution and other criminal activity. The experience of other cities indicates that proper management and operation of such businesses can minimize this risk. 
(3)  Sexually oriented businesses can increase the risk of exposure to communicable diseases, including, but not limited to, acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS), for which there is currently no cure. Experiences of other cities indicate that such businesses can facilitate the spread of communicable diseases by virtue of the design and use of the premises, endangering not only the patrons of such establishments but also the general public. 
(4)  Sexually oriented businesses can cause or contribute to public health problems by the presence of live adult entertainment in conjunction with food and/or drink on the same premises. 
(5)  The risk of criminal activity and/or public health problems can be minimized though a licensing and regulatory scheme as prescribed in this chapter herein. 
(Ord. No. 327, § 1, 9-10-08) 
Sec. 47-3. - Conclusions. 
    In direct furtherance of the substantial goals of public health, safety and welfare, the city council adopts the following licensing regulations, recognizing that it has great interest in the promotion of health and the prevention of criminal activity. It is not the intent of this chapter to impose limitations or restrictions on the content of any communicative materials, including sexually oriented materials. Similarly, it is not the intent of this chapter to restrict or deny adults, as defined by this section, access to communicative materials including adult-content materials that do not meet the legal definition of obscenity according to M.S.A. § 617.241 and as protected by the First Amendment, or to deny adults as defined by this section access by the distributors and exhibitors of adult entertainment to their intended markets. Instead, this section represents a balancing of competing interest: reduced criminal activity through the regulation of adult use establishments or businesses and their patrons. Thus, this chapter is designed to alleviate undesirable social problems that accompany adult-use establishments and businesses without curtailing constitutionally protected expression. 
(Ord. No. 327, § 1, 9-10-08) 
Sec. 47-4. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Adult in this section pertains to any reference, exhibition or conduct of which are sexual, obscene or prurient in nature or depict sexual, obscene and/or prurient themes and/or exude or intend to exude sexual characteristics with an emphasis on specified anatomical areas or specified sexual activities as defined in this chapter. 
    Adult(s) in this section refers to an individual person or persons of whom is considered a legal adult by law or legally emancipated and not a minor. 
    Adult use establishment(s ) means and includes any business, establishment, place or venue or other premises or enterprise open to some or all members of the public but which excludes minors by reason of age and which devotes a substantial or significant portion of its inventory, stock in trade or floor area (exclusive of storerooms, stock areas, or any other storage area not open to the public, but inclusive of an Adult Content Warehouse as defined in this chapter) to material or content that is sexual in nature and/or publicly displays adult merchandise, or generates or substantiates its revenues from the sale of items, merchandise, materials or other matter including the dissemination of information that emphasize, depict, simulate, describe and/or expose Specified Sexual Activities or Specified Anatomical Areas as defined in this chapter and/or sexual content or themes. Activities classified as obscene as defined by M.S.A. § 617.241, as may be amended, are not included. Such adult establishments or businesses described herein include but are not limited to: 
(1)  Adult content bookstores. Any business, establishment, place or venue that excludes minors by reason of age, and that provides, disseminates, offers, or that derives significant revenue from the sale, barter or rental of materials, items, merchandise or matter including but not limited to printed and electronic information, pictures, slides, records, audio tapes, videotapes, movies, video discs, motion pictures, films, or any delivered medium that is adult or sexual in nature, or that depict, expose, simulate, describe or suggest specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas as defined in this chapter. 
(2)  Adult motion picture theaters. Any business, establishment, place or venue that excludes minors by reason of age and that presents or provides to the public sexually-oriented or adult content or themes for observation through motion picture medium, regardless of frequency or volume of clientele. 
(3)  Adult motion picture sales/rentals. Any business, establishment, place or venue that excludes minors by reason of age, and to which the adult public is invited and/or permitted to rent, buy, trade or barter electronic or mechanic formats of motion pictures, including but not limited to electronically-, electrically-, or mechanically-controlled or operated still or motion picture machines, projectors, movies, electronic discs, or other image-written or image-producing item that is used to convey images that emphasize, distinguish, characterize, depict or describe specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas as defined in this chapter. 
(4)  Adult massage parlors. Any business, establishment, place or venue that excludes minors by reason of age, and that offers, provides and/or derives a substantial or significant portion of its revenue from the service of massage or health maintenance distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas as defined in this chapter. 
(5)  Adult steam room/bath house/sauna facilities. Any business, establishment, place or venue that excludes minors by reason of age, and that offers, provides and/or derives a substantial or significant portion of its revenue from health or sports club service(s), steam bath, sauna, heat bathing or relaxation service that is distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas as defined in this chapter. 
(6)  Adult companionship establishments/escort agency. Any business, establishment, place or venue that excludes minors by reason of age, and that provides the service of engaging a person or persons in the discussion, conversation, listening, communication or companionship with another person or persons, characterized by an emphasis on adult themes, sexually-oriented activities or content, specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, as defined in this chapter, occurring or to occur on the premises or elsewhere, including electronic formats. 
(7)  Adult rap/conversation parlors. Any business, establishment, place or venue that excludes minors by reason of age, and that provides the service of engaging in the listening, discussion, conversation, talk, or communication thereof characterized by an emphasis on adult themes, content, information, specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, as defined in this chapter, occurring or to occur on the premises or elsewhere, including electronic formats. 
(8)  Adult health/sport clubs. Any business, establishment, place or venue that provides the service of health maintenance, or a sport or athletic club that excludes minors by reason of age, and that is distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, as defined in this chapter, occurring or to occur on the premises or elsewhere. 
(9)  Adult cabarets. Any business, establishment, place or venue that excludes minors by reason of age, and that provides some or all members of the adult public with live entertainment or dancing that presents nudity and/or depicts specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, or that presents, displays, depicts or provides matter that is meant to evoke sexual feelings, behavior, or to arouse or excite patrons in a sexually-oriented way and with sexually-oriented themes or content. 
(10)  Adult novelty businesses. Any business, establishment, place or venue that excludes minors by reason of age, and that provides, disseminates, offers, or that derives significant revenue from the sale, barter or rental of materials, items, objects, merchandise or matter characterized by an emphasis of depicting, describing or conveying sexually-oriented themes or content characterized by specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, as defined in this chapter. 
(11)  Adult motion picture arcades. Any business, establishment, place or venue to which adult members of the public are invited or permitted, which excludes minors by reason of age, to use or operate electronic, electrical, or mechanical equipment, machines, projectors, or other image-producing devices to display or show still or motion pictures, images or displays that are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on depicting, describing or conveying sexually-oriented content, adult themes, specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
(12)  Adult modeling studios. Any business, establishment, place or venue that excludes minors by reason of age, and that provides live models who, with the intent of providing sexual stimulation or sexual gratification, engage in specified sexual activities or display specified anatomical areas while being observed, painted, painted upon, sketched, drawn, sculptured, photographed, or otherwise reproduced or depicted by image. 
(13)  Adult hotels/motels. Any business, establishment, place or venue that excludes minors by reason of age and that provides hotel or motel services and offers or presents adult or sexually-oriented themes or content or material with an emphasis on specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. 
(14)  Adult body painting studios. Any business, establishment, place or venue that excludes minors by reason of age and that provides the service of applying paint, ink, or other substance(s), whether transparent or non-transparent, to the body of a patron when the person is nude or clad in a manner that exposes any portion of specified anatomical areas as defined in this chapter. 
(15)  Adult content warehouse. Any business, establishment, place, venue or premises that houses, provides the services of storage space, stockroom(s), or warehousing, including that of a distribution center, for merchandise or material containing or depicting adult content or themes, from which premises such adult merchandise or material are intended for dissemination and delivery to either the adult public, a wholesaler, or to a third-party vendor or dealer, whether via electronically, through the Internet, telephone, fax, or via catalog, magazine or by post. 
    Adult use establishment(s), accessory: 
(1)  Means adult use establishment as defined in this chapter; and 
(2)  Comprise ten percent or less of the floor area of the establishment of which is open to the adult public, exclusive of storerooms and/or stockrooms; or 
(3)  Derive 20 percent or less of the gross receipts of the entire business operation; or 
(4)  Not involve or include any activity other than the sale, barter or rental of adult merchandise or items. 
    Adult use establishment(s), principal: 
(1)  Means adult use establishment as defined in this chapter; and 
(2)  Comprise more than ten percent of the floor area of the establishment of which is open to the adult public, exclusive of storerooms and/or stockrooms; or 
(3)  Derive more than 20 percent of the gross receipts of the entire business operation. 
    City administrator means the city administrator of the City of Watertown and/or his/her designee(s) acting on behalf of the city administrator. 
    Licensee means a person in whose name a license to operate a sexually oriented use business has been issued, as well as the individual listed as an applicant on the application for a license. 
    Person means an individual, proprietorship, partnership, corporation, association, or other legal entity. 
    Premises means the real property and all building and structures located on the real property. 
    Retail-oriented adult use establishment(s) means the offering of goods and/or services of which are characterized by an emphasis on adult content or themes and used as a primary or sole activity of a business or establishment, including but not limited to the following classification of uses as defined in this chapter: 
(1)  Adult bookstore; 
(2)  Adult novelty business; 
(3)  Adult motion picture sales/rentals. 
    Service-oriented adult use establishment(s) means the offering of goods and/or services of which are characterized by an emphasis on adult content or themes and used as a primary or sole activity of a business or establishment, including but not limited to the following classification of uses as defined in this chapter: 
(1)  Adult motion picture theater/arcade; 
(2)  Adult steam room/bath house/sauna facility; 
(3)  Adult companionship establishment; 
(4)  Adult rap/conversation parlor; 
(5)  Adult health/sport club; 
(6)  Adult cabaret; 
(7)  Adult body painting studio; 
(8)  Adult hotel or motel; 
(9)  Adult massage parlor; 
(10)  Adult modeling studio. 
    Specified anatomical areas: 
(1)  Less than completely and opaquely covered human genitals, pubic region, buttock, anus, or female breast(s) below a point immediately above the top of the areola; and 
(2)  Human male genitals, even if completely and opaquely covered. 
    Specified sexual activities: 
(1)  Actual or simulated sexual intercourse, normal or perverted, including oral copulation, anal intercourse, oral-anal copulation, genital-genital, anal-genital, or oral-genital intercourse, bestiality in regards to any type of sexual intercourse between a human being and an animal, direct physical stimulation of unclothed genitals, flagellation or torture in the context of a sexual relationship, or the use of excretory functions in the context of a sexual relationship, and any of the following sexually-oriented acts or conduct: analingus, buggery, coprophagy, coprophilia, cunnilingus, fellatio, necrophilia, pederasty, pedophilia, piquerism, sapphism, zooerasty; 
(2)  Exhibitions of depicted human genitals in the state of sexual stimulation, arousal or tumescence, including any explicit, close-up representation of a human genital organ whether clothed, unclothed or opaquely sheathed; 
(3)  Use of human or animal ejaculation, sodomy, oral copulation, coitus, or masturbation; 
(4)  Fondling or touching of nude human genitals, pubic region, buttocks, or female breast; 
(5)  Sadomasochistic situations involving a person or persons, any of whom are nude, clad in undergarments or in sexually revealing costumes, and who are engaged in activities involving the flagellation, torture, abuse, fettering, binding or other physical restraint of any such persons; 
(6)  Erotic or lewd touching, fondling or other sexually-oriented contact with an animal by a human being; or 
(7)  Human excretion, urination, menstruation, vaginal or anal irrigation. 
    Substantial enlargement of an adult use establishment means the increase in floor area occupied by the business by more than 20 percent, as the floor area existed on the effective date of this chapter. 
    Substantial or significant portion means an amount which is more than exactly 20 percent, or where otherwise defined in this chapter. 
    Transfer of ownership or control of an adult use establishment means and includes any of the following: 
(1)  The sale, lease, or sub-lease of the business; 
(2)  The transfer of securities which constitute a controlling interest in the business, whether by sale, exchange, or similar means; or 
(3)  The establishment of a trust, gift, or other similar legal device which transfers the ownership or control of the business, except for transfer by bequest or other operation of law upon the death of the person possessing the ownership or control. 
(Ord. No. 327, § 1, 9-10-08) 
Sec. 47-5. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be punished as prescribed in section 1-13 of Watertown Municipal Code. 
(b)  A person who operates or causes to be operated an adult use establishment without a valid license or in violation of this chapter is subject to a suit for injunction as well as prosecution for criminal violations. 
(Ord. No. 327, § 1, 9-10-08) 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSE 

Sec. 47-6. - Generally. 
(a)  Required. 
(1)  No person, firm, or corporation shall operate an adult use establishment, without formal review of the application by city council in the form of a public hearing. 
(2)  No person, firm, or corporation shall operate an adult use establishment without having first secured a license as herein provided. 
(b)  Exceptions. The following shall not require a license or review by the city council under this chapter: 
(1)  Material with significant literary content or social commentary; 
(2)  A business where sexually oriented materials are sold, bartered, distributed, leased, furnished, or otherwise provided for off-site use or entertainment, if the sexually oriented material on each item is sufficiently and completely blocked from view as required by M.S.A. § 617.293, as it may be amended from time to time, and each item is in an area accessible only to an employee or the business; 
(3)  A person or organization exempted under M.S.A. § 617.295; 
(4)  Activity regulated under M.S.A. § 617.251; 
(5)  Displaying works of art showing specified anatomical areas, so long as sexually oriented materials are for not sale, and the business does not have a liquor license; 
(6)  Movies rated G, PG, PG-13, NC-17 or R; 
(7)  A person appearing in a state of nudity for the purpose of a modeling class operated: 
a.  By a proprietary school licensed by the state; a college, junior college, or university supported entirely or partly by taxation; 
b.  By a private college or university which maintains and operates educational programs in which credits are transferable to a college, junior college, or university supported entirely or partly by taxation; 
c.  In a structure: 
1.  Which has no sign visible from the exterior of the structure and no other advertising that indicates a nude person is available for viewing; and 
2.  Where in order to participate in a class, a student must enroll at least three days in advance of the class; and 
3.  Where no more than one nude model is on the premises at any one time. 
(c)  An application for a license must be made on a form provided by the city. The application must be accompanied by a drawing, sketch or diagram showing the configuration of the premises, including a statement of total floor space occupied by the business. The drawing, sketch or diagram need not be professionally prepared but must be drawn to a designated scale or drawn with market dimensions of the interior of the premises to an accuracy of plus or minus one inch. 
(d)  In order for a license to issue, the applicant must comply with Watertown Municipal Code and state law, including, but not limited to, the applicant being qualified according to the provisions of Watertown Municipal Code and the premises must be inspected and found to be in compliance with the law by the fire department and building official. 
(e)  If a person who wishes to operate an adult use establishment is an individual party, the individual must sign the application for a license as applicant. If the applicant party consists of more than one individual, then each individual who has an interest in the business must sign the application for a license as applicant. Each applicant must be qualified under section 47-7 and each applicant shall be considered a licensee if a license is granted. 
(Ord. No. 327, § 2, 9-10-08) 
Sec. 47-7. - Issuance. 
(a)  All adult use establishment applicants shall adhere to M.S.A. § 617.242, Subd. 2. 
(b)  An applicant wishing to operate an adult use establishment at a location where this type of establishment was not previously located must notify the city at least 60 days before submitting a permit application for the adult use establishment. This notice shall be sent by certified mail to the city administrator. Upon signed receipt of the applicant's notice by certified mail, the city shall be allowed a 60-day review period of the application prior to presenting the application to the city council for review and public hearing. 
(c)  The city council shall approve the issuance of a license for an adult use establishment applicant within 60 days after the date of the required public hearing unless the city council reasonably deems it necessary to hold subsequent hearings on the matter, or if the city council finds one or more of the following to be true: 
(1)  The applicant is a minor at the time the application is submitted. 
(2)  The applicant failed to supply all of the information requested on the license application. 
(3)  The applicant failed to supply all information and materials deemed necessary by the city administrator. 
(4)  The applicant is delinquent in his or her payment to the city or another city within the State of Minnesota involving taxes, fees, fines, or penalties assessed against him or her or imposed upon him or her in relation to an adult use establishment or another business or establishment for which more than any portion of the gross receipts of the business operation are derived from the sale, rental, barter, or services characterized by an emphasis on adult content or themes. 
(5)  The applicant gave false, fraudulent, or untruthful information on the license application and/or with the materials submitted with the application. 
(6)  The applicant has been convicted of a violation of a provision of this chapter within five years immediately preceding the application. The fact that a conviction is being appealed shall have no effect. 
(7)  The applicant is residing with a person who has been denied a license by the city to operate an adult use establishment or business within the preceding 12 months, or residing with a person whose license to operate an adult use establishment or business has been revoked within the preceding 12 months. 
(8)  The premises to be used for the adult use establishment or business have not been approved by the fire department and the building official as being in compliance with applicable laws and ordinances. 
(9)  The license application fee and investigation fee required by this chapter have not been paid. 
(10)  The applicant has been employed in an adult use establishment or business in a managerial capacity within the preceding 24 months and has demonstrated that he or she is unable to operate or manage the adult use establishment or business premises in a peaceful and law abiding manner, thus necessitating action by law enforcement officers. 
(11)  The applicant or the proposed establishment is in violation of or is not in compliance with this Code. 
(12)  Fewer than five complete years from the date of discharge have passed since an applicant or his or her spouse, companion, partner or roommate, with whom he or she resides, or a business partner, agent or employee has been convicted of a felony or a gross misdemeanor or misdemeanor relating to sex offenses, obscenity offenses. Such offenses include but are not limited to: 
a.  Prostitution under M.S.A. §§ 609.321; 609.324; or 609.3242. 
b.  Criminal sexual conduct under M.S.A. §§ 609.342 to 609.3451. 
c.  Solicitation of children under M.S.A. § 609.352. 
d.  Indecent exposure under M.S.A. § 617.23. 
e.  Distribution or exhibition of obscene materials and performances under M.S.A. § 617.241. 
f.  Use of a minor in a sexual performance under M.S.A. § 617.246. 
g.  Possession of pornographic work involving minors under M.S.A. § 617.247. 
(13)  The fact that a conviction is being appealed shall have no effect on the disqualification of the applicant or his or her spouse, companion, partner or room mate, with whom he or she resides, or a business partner, agent or employee. 
(14)  The premises to be licensed as an adult use establishment is currently licensed by the city as a tanning facility, tattoo establishment, pawn shop, therapeutic massage enterprise, or an establishment licensed to sell alcoholic beverages. 
(15)  The license, if granted, shall state the name of the person or persons to whom it is granted, the expiration date, and the address of the adult use establishment or business. 
(Ord. No. 327, § 2, 9-10-08) 
Sec. 47-8. - License fees; investigation fees. 
    All applications shall be accompanied by a license fee, investigation fee and an annual license renewal fee. The initial license fee for an adult use establishment license shall be set by the city council. The investigation fee for the purpose of issuing a license shall be set by the city council. The annual license renewal fee shall be set by the city council. In the event that the license is denied upon application and review by city council, the license fee shall be refunded; however, no part of the license investigation fee shall be returned to the applicant. No part of the annual license fee shall be refunded if the license is suspended or revoked. 
(Ord. No. 327, § 2, 9-10-08) 
Sec. 47-9. - Inspection. 
(a)  An applicant or licensee shall permit representatives of the Carver County sheriff's department, fire department, and building inspection division to inspect the premises of an adult use establishment for the purpose of ensuring compliance with the law, at any time it is occupied or open for business. 
(b)  A person who operates an adult use establishment or his or her business partner, agent or employee commits an offense if he or she refuses to permit a lawful inspection of the premises by a representative of the Carver County sheriff's department at any time it is occupied or open for business. 
(c)  The provisions of this section do not apply to areas of an adult hotel or motel which are currently being rented by a customer or customers for use as permanent or temporary habitation. 
(Ord. No. 327, § 2, 9-10-08) 
Sec. 47-10. - Expiration. 
(a)  Each renewal license shall be issued for a maximum period of one year. All licenses shall expire on December 31 of each year. Each license may be renewed only by making an application as provided in section 47-8 of this chapter. Application for renewal shall be made at least 90 days before the expiration date. If the city council determines good and sufficient cause is shown by the applicant for failure to file a timely renewal application, the city council and/or city administrator may, if other provisions of the section are complied with, grant the application. 
(b)  When the city council denies renewal of a license, the applicant shall not be issued a license for one year from the date of denial. If, subsequent to denial, the city council finds that the basis for denial of the renewal license has been corrected or abated, the applicant may be granted a license if at least 90 days have elapsed since the date that the application was denied. 
(Ord. No. 327, § 2, 9-10-08) 
Sec. 47-11. - Suspension. 
    The city administrator may suspend a license for a period not to exceed 60 days following written notice and an opportunity to be heard if the city administrator determines that a licensee or an employee of an adult use establishment has: 
(1)  Violated or is not in compliance with this Code or state law; 
(2)  Engaged in excessive use of alcoholic beverages while on the adult use establishment or business premises; 
(3)  Refused to allow inspection of the adult use establishment premises as authorized by this chapter; 
(4)  Knowingly permitted unlawful gambling by any person on the adult use establishment or business premises. 
(5)  Demonstrated inability to operate or manage an adult use establishment or business in a peaceful and law-abiding manner, thus necessitating action by law enforcement officers. 
(6)  Fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement contained in a license application or a renewal application. 
(7)  Fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement made in the course of carrying on the licensed occupation or business. 
(8)  A licensee's criminal conviction that is directly related to the occupation or business licensed as defined by M.S.A. § 364.03, Subd. 2, provided that the licensee cannot show competent evidence of sufficient rehabilitation and present fitness to perform the duties of the licensed occupation or business as defined by M.S.A. § 364.03, Subd. 3. 
(9)  Conducting the licensed business or occupation in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety, or general welfare of the community. 
(Ord. No. 327, § 2, 9-10-08) 
Sec. 47-12. - Revocation. 
(a)  The city administrator may revoke a license preceded by written notice and an opportunity to be heard if a cause of suspension of section 47-11 occurs and the license has been suspended within the preceding 12 months. 
(b)  The city administrator may revoke a license if the city administrator determines that: 
(1)  A licensee gave false or misleading information to the city on the application or during the application process; 
(2)  A licensee or an employee has knowingly allowed possession, use, sale, or barter of a controlled substance(s) on the premises; 
(3)  A licensee or an employee has knowingly allowed prostitution to occur on the premises; 
(4)  A licensee or an employee knowingly operated the adult use establishment or business during a period of time when the licensee's license was suspended. 
(5)  A licensee violated any of the provisions of M.S.A. §§ 617.241-617.299 relating to the illegal distribution, possession, or sale of obscene materials. 
(6)  A licensee, or his or her spouse, companion, partner or roommate, with whom he or she resides, or a business partner, agent or employee who has been convicted of a felony or a gross misdemeanor or misdemeanor relating to sex offenses, obscenity offenses, or adult uses in the past five years. 
(7)  On two or more occasions within a 12-month period, a person or persons committed an offense occurring in or on the licensed premises that are a felony or a gross misdemeanor or misdemeanor relating to sex offenses, obscenity offenses, or adult uses, for which a conviction has been obtained, and the person or persons were employees of the adult use establishment or business at the time the offenses were committed; 
(8)  A licensee or an employee has knowingly allowed any act of sexual intercourse, sodomy, oral copulation, masturbation, or sexual contact to occur in or on the licensed premises. The term "sexual contact" shall have the meaning as it is defined in M.S.A. § 609.341, Subd. 11(b); or 
(9)  A licensee is delinquent in payment to the city for ad valorem taxes, local lodging tax, or other taxes or fees related to the adult use establishment. 
(c)  The fact that a conviction is being appealed shall have no effect on the revocation of the license. 
(d)  When the city administrator revokes a license, the revocation shall continue for two years and the licensee shall not be issued an adult use establishment license for two years from the date that the revocation became effective. If, subsequent to revocation, the city administrator finds that the basis for the revocation has been corrected or abated, the applicant may be granted a license if at least 90 days have elapsed since the date the revocation was corrected or abated. 
(Ord. No. 327, § 2, 9-10-08) 
Sec. 47-13. - Appeal. 
(a)  Generally. If the city administrator denies the issuance of a license, or suspends, or revokes a license, the administrator shall sent to the applicant, or licensee, by certified mail, return receipt requested, written notice of the action, and the right to an appeal. The aggrieved party may appeal in writing the decision of the city administrator within ten days of receiving notice of the city's action. The filing of an appeal stays the action of the city administrator in suspending or revoking a license until the city council makes a final decision. 
(b)  Procedure. The city council may appoint a committee of the council or an independent hearing officer to hear the matter, report findings of fact, and provide a recommendation for disposition to the council. Hearings on the appeal shall be open to the public and the licensee or applicant shall have the right to appear and be represented by legal counsel and to offer evidence in its behalf. The city council shall make a final decision within 60 days of the conclusion of the hearing. 
(c)  Additional requirements. The city council may condition denial, suspension, revocation, or non-renewal of a license upon appropriate terms and conditions. 
(Ord. No. 327, § 2, 9-10-08) 
Sec. 47-14. - Transfer. 
    A licensee shall not transfer his or her license to another, nor shall a licensee operate an adult use establishment or business under the authority of a license at any place other than the address and premise(s) designated in the adult use establishment application and permit. 
(Ord. No. 327, § 2, 9-10-08) 
ARTICLE III. - ADDITIONAL REGULATIONS 

Sec. 47-15. - Existing adult use establishments. 
(a)  License administration for existing adult use establishments. Within ten days exclusive of Saturday and Sunday, of the published date of this chapter, any existing adult use establishments or businesses shall apply for a license from the city. Failure to apply for a license is a violation of this chapter. 
(b)  An existing adult use establishment may continue to operate pending review of the license application by the city, after which license review, the city administrator may either grant or deny a license based on review of the license application provisions provided by this chapter. 
(c)  Existing adult use establishments or businesses which are legally classified as non-conforming uses and are granted a license may continue in accordance with the provision of this chapter. 
(d)  An owner or operator whose adult use establishment or business shall have the right to request an extension provided that owner or operator demonstrates or proves a burden exclusive of pecuniary hardship with the effective termination date of the non-conforming adult use establishment. 
(1)  Such hardships and burdens that may be considered by city council include but are not limited to: 
a.  The degree or magnitude of threat to the public health, safety, and general welfare posed by the secondary impacts of the operation. 
b.  The length of time that the adult use establishment has been operating. 
c.  The ease by which the property could be converted to a conforming adult use. 
d.  The nature and character of the surrounding neighborhood. 
e.  The value and condition of the improvements on the property. 
(e)  An application for an adult use establishment license or a reapplication must be made on a respective form provided by the city. 
(Ord. No. 327, § 3, 9-10-08) 
Sec. 47-16. - Adult companionship establishment/escort agencies. 
    An adult companionship establishment or escort agency shall not employ or offer or provide services to any person under the age of 18 years. 
(Ord. No. 327, § 3, 9-10-08) 
Sec. 47-17. - Adult model studios. 
    An adult model studio shall not employ any person under the age of 18 years or offer or provide services to any person under the age of 18 years. 
(Ord. No. 327, § 3, 9-10-08) 
Sec. 47-18. - Adult motion theaters and adult motion picture theaters. 
    A person commits an offense if he or she allows a person under the age of 18 years to appear in a state of nudity or on the premises of an adult theater or adult motion picture theater. 
(Ord. No. 327, § 3, 9-10-08) 
Sec. 47-19. - Adult hotels and motels. 
(a)  Evidence that a sleeping room in a hotel, motel, or similar commercial establishment has been rented and vacated two or more times in a period of time that is less than ten hours creates a rebuttable presumption that the establishment is an adult hotel or motel as defined in this chapter. 
(b)  A person commits an offense if, as the person in control of a sleeping room in a hotel, motel, or similar commercial establishment that does not have an adult use establishment license, he or she rents or sub-rents a sleeping room to a person and, within ten hours from the time the room is rented, he or she rents or sub-rents the same sleeping room again. 
(c)  For purposes of subsection 47-19(b), the terms "rent" or "sub-rent" mean the act of permitting a room to be occupied for any form of consideration or remuneration. 
(Ord. No. 327, § 3, 9-10-08) 
Sec. 47-20. - Exhibition of sexually explicit films or videos. 
(a)  A person who operates or causes to be operated an adult use establishment or business, other than an adult motel or hotel, which exhibits on the premises in a viewing room of less than 150 square feet of floor space, any video reproduction which depicts specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, shall comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  Upon application for an adult use establishment license, the application shall be accompanied by a drawing, sketch or diagram of the premises showing a plan thereof specifying the location of one or more manager's stations and the location of all overhead lighting fixtures and designating any portion of the premises in which patrons will not be permitted. A manager's station shall not exceed 32 square feet of floor area. The diagram shall also designate the place at which the permit will be conspicuously posted, if granted. A professionally prepared diagram in the nature of an engineer's or architect's blueprint shall not be required; however, each diagram should be oriented to the north or to some designated street or object and should be drawn to a designated scale or with marked dimensions sufficient to show the various internal dimensions of all areas of the interior of the premises to an accuracy of plus or minus six inches. The city administrator may waive the foregoing diagram for license renewal applications if the applicant adopts a diagram that was previously submitted and approved, and certifies that the configuration of the premises has not been altered since it was prepared. 
(2)  The application shall be sworn to be true and correct by the applicant. 
(3)  No alteration in the configuration or location of a manager's station may be made without the prior approval of the city administrator. 
(4)  It is the duty of the owners and operator of the premises to ensure that at least one employee is on duty and situated in a manager's station at all times that any patron is present inside the premises. 
(5)  The interior of the premises shall be configured in such a manner that there is an unobstructed view from any manager station(s) of every area of the premises to which any patron is permitted access for any purpose excluding rest rooms. Rest rooms may not contain video reproduction equipment. The view required in this subsection must be by direct line of sight from each manager station(s). 
(6)  It shall be the duty of the owners and operator, and it shall also be the duty of any agents and employees present in the premises to ensure that the view area specified in subsection (a)(5) remains unobstructed by any doors, walls, merchandise, display racks or other materials at all times that any patron is present in the premises and to ensure that no patron is permitted access to any area of the premises which has been designated as an area in which patrons will not be permitted in the application filed pursuant to subsection (a)(1). 
(7)  The premises shall be equipped with overhead lighting fixtures of sufficient intensity to sufficiently illuminate every place to which patrons are permitted access. 
(8)  It shall be the duty of the owners and operators and it shall also be the duty of any agents and employees present in the premises to ensure that the illumination described above is maintained at all times that any patron is present in the premises. 
(b)  A person having a duty under subsections (a)(1) through (a)(8) of section 47-20 commits an offense if the person fails to fulfill that duty. 
(Ord. No. 327, § 3, 9-10-08) 
Sec. 47-21. - General license restrictions. 
(a)  Posting of license. The license shall be posted in a conspicuous place at or near the entrance to the adult use establishment or business so that it may be easily viewed at any time. 
(b)  Effect of license. A license issued under this chapter is only effective for the compact and contiguous space expressly specified in the approved license application. 
(c)  Maintenance of order. A licensee under this chapter shall be responsible for the conduct of the business being operated and shall not allow any illegal activity to take place on or near the licensed premises, including, but not limited to, prostitution, public indecency, indecent exposure, disorderly conduct, or the sale or use of illegal drugs. Every act or omission by an employee or independent contractor of the licensee constituting a violation of the chapter shall be deemed the act or omission of the licensee if such act or omission occurs either with the authorization, knowledge, or approval of the license, or as a result of the licensee's negligent failure to supervise the employees or independent contractor. 
(Ord. No. 327, § 3, 9-10-08) 
Sec. 47-22. - Terms of operation. 
(a)  Applicable laws. Operators of adult use establishments shall comply with the provisions of this Code and with the laws of the State of Minnesota and the United States of America. No provision(s) of this Code shall be construed as authorizing or permitting conduct that is prohibited or regulated by other statutes or ordinances, including but not limited to statutes or ordinances prohibiting the exhibition, sale or distribution of obscene material as defined by the State of Minnesota, inordinately prurient in content or nature, or the exhibition, sale or distribution of specified materials to minors. 
(b)  Existing adult use establishments. Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, existing adult use establishments must comply with all requirements of this chapter immediately upon its effective date. 
(c)  Regulation of hours of operation. Adult use establishments shall be permitted to operate between the hours of 11:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m., Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday and Saturday of each month. Adult use establishments shall not be permitted to operate during the hours of 9:01 p.m. and 10:59 a.m., Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday and Saturday of each month. Adult use establishments shall not be permitted to operate anytime Sunday or national holiday. 
(d)  Offsite viewing. Any adult use establishment shall prevent the viewing of its merchandise or any materials depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas by any visual or auditory media, including the display, decoration, sign, show window, sound transmission, or other means, from the public right-of-way or from any place not on the premises of the adult use establishment where the public may be able to view, listen to or experience the matter, including off-site viewing. 
(e)  Prohibition on liquor: 
(1)  Adult use establishments shall be prohibited from selling, dispensing or providing intoxicating beverages or food for consumption, or any intoxicating edible matter that is capable of being imbibed and may temporarily impair judgment thereafter. Such matter includes but is not limited to alcohol, liquor, 3.2 percent and higher malt liquor, alcohol that is mixed with other liquids or food forms including but not limited to gelatin and ice. 
(2)  The sale and/or consumption of any intoxicating edible matter is strictly prohibited on the real property premises of any adult use establishment or business, including any parking areas that are owned or leased by the adult use establishment or its owner(s) or employees, or any parking areas that are being used by patrons of the adult use establishment while those patrons are engaging in the business or service(s) provided by the adult use establishment. 
(f)  Entrance and exit points. 
(1)  All entrance and exit points to and from the adult use establishment, with the exception of emergency fire exits and those entrance and exit points that are not useable by patrons, shall be visible from the public right-of-way and illuminated, beginning at sunset, during the hours in which the adult use establishment is being operated or open to the public. 
(2)  It shall be the duty of the owners and operators and it shall also be the duty of any agents and employees present in the premises to ensure that the illumination described above is maintained at all times that any patron is present in the premises. 
(3)  A person commits an offense if he or she knowingly allows a patron(s) of the adult use establishment to pass through an entrance or exit point not designated for public use as described above in section 47-22(f)(2), except when required and permitted due to emergency situations or situations that warrant immediate egression of the premises. 
(g)  Signs. 
(1)  Exterior signs for adult use establishments or businesses shall not contain representational depiction of any specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas as defined in this chapter. 
(2)  Adult use establishments shall not graphically describe or present descriptions of adult themes or content on any exterior portion of the premises, or on any interior portion of the premises that is visible from outside the adult use establishment building or premises. 
(3)  Adult use establishments shall prominently display within two feet of the entrance point of business a permanent sign of professional quality that states, "This business sells or displays matter containing adult themes. Persons under 18 years of age are prohibited." The size of the letters on the sign shall be between three-eighths of an inch and two inches in height. This sign does not contribute to the maximum allowable signage for any one building or property. 
(h)  Access by minors. 
(1)  Minors shall not be permitted on the property or premises of an adult use establishment or business, except: 
a.  A retail-oriented adult use establishment, accessory, may allow minors on the premises provided that: 
1.  The area or portion of floor space which is allocated for the sale or rental of adult content is sufficiently and completely screened and not accessible, whether physically, visually or audibly to minors; 
2.  The area or portion of floor space which is allocated for the sale or rental of adult content shall prominently display, within two feet of the entrance point of the screened area, a sign of professional quality that states, "This screened area sells or displays matter containing adult themes. Persons under 18 years of age are prohibited." The size of the letters on the sign shall be between three-eighths of an inch and two square inches in height. In the case of a retail-oriented adult use establishment, accessory, additional exterior signage as prescribed in section 47-22(g)(3) is not required; or 
3.  Adult items or merchandise are kept in a storage facility, stock or store room not open to the public. 
b.  No adult item, merchandise, matter or material may be offered, sold, bartered, transferred, or otherwise conveyed to a minor. 
c.  No adult item, merchandise, matter, material, representation or depiction of an adult theme or adult content shall be displayed, communicated or presented whether physically, visually, audibly or otherwise, in a fashion that allows such content to be visible to a minor, whether or not the minor is on the adult use establishment premises. 
(i)  Adult use establishment entertainment. 
(1)  A live performer, entertainer, dancer or employee, whether or not under contract, shall not be under 18 years of age. 
(2)  All adult performances such as dancing and entertaining shall occur on a platform intended for the purpose of performance and shall not be fewer than two feet from the level of the floor. 
(3)  No performers, entertainers, dancers or employees, whether or not under contract, shall fondle, caress or touch any patron, and no patron shall fondle, caress, or touch any performer, entertainer, dancer or employee. 
(4)  No person may be nude on the premises of any adult use establishment. 
(Ord. No. 327, § 3, 9-10-08) 
Sec. 47-23. - Location requirements. 
(a)  Adult use establishment, principal. 
(1)  Service-oriented adult use establishments, principal, as prescribed in section 47-4 are permitted uses in industrial districts subject to the following requirements: 
a.  An adult use establishment shall not be located within 1,000 feet of any residential planned unit development (PUD) district, residential district or residential property, whether existing or use-guided by the most recently adopted comprehensive plan. 
b.  An adult use establishment shall not be located within 2,800 feet of an existing school, place of worship, elder or child care facility, religious, educational or medical institution, including institutionally-owned property. 
c.  An adult use establishment shall not be located within 1,500 feet of another adult use establishment. 
d.  An adult use establishment shall not be located within 2,800 feet of any parkland property or public recreational facility. 
(2)  Retail-oriented adult use establishments, principal, as prescribed in section 47-4 are permitted uses in industrial districts subject to the following requirements: 
a.  An adult use establishment shall not be located within 1,000 feet of any residential planned unit development (PUD) district, residential district or residential property, whether existing or use guided by the most recent comprehensive plan. 
b.  An adult use establishment shall not be located within 2,800 feet of an existing school, place of worship, elder or child care facility, religious, educational or medical institution, including institutionally-owned property. 
c.  An adult use establishment shall not be located within 1,500 feet of another adult use establishment. 
d.  An adult use establishment shall not be located within 2,800 feet of any parkland property or public recreational facility. 
(b)  Adult use establishment, accessory. 
(1)  Service-oriented adult use establishments, accessory, as prescribed in section 47-4 are permitted uses in industrial districts subject to the following requirements: 
a.  An adult use establishment shall not be located within 1,000 feet of any residential planned unit development (PUD) district, residential district or residential property, whether existing or use-guided by the most recently adopted comprehensive plan. 
b.  An adult use establishment shall not be located within 2,800 feet of an existing school, place of worship, elder or child care facility, religious, educational or medical institution, including institutionally-owned property. 
c.  An adult use establishment shall not be located within 1,500 feet of another adult use establishment. 
d.  An adult use establishment shall not be located within 2,800 feet of any parkland property or public recreational facility. 
    Retail-oriented adult use establishments, accessory, as prescribed in section 47-4 are permitted uses in commercial districts and industrial districts and are subject to the provisions of this Code. 
(c)  For purposes of this chapter, distances shall be the shortest measurement from the property line of any residential district, residential property, educational institution, place of worship, elder or child care facility, public park land, public recreational facility, or an adult use establishment to the property line where the proposed adult use establishment is to be located. 
(Ord. No. 327, § 3, 9-10-08) 
Chapter 48 - SIGNS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 349, adopted June 8, 2010, amended Ch. 48 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 48, §§ 48-1-48-27, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 255 adopted June 29, 2004 and Ord. No. 279, adopted February 28, 2006. 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; planning, ch. 46.5; zoning, ch. 62. 

Sec. 48-1. - Purpose. 
    These regulations set forth by the City of Watertown combine the need to protect the public safety and welfare, the need to encourage pedestrian movement, the need for a well-maintained and attractive community, and the need to adequately convey ideas, provide communication and identify features within the community. The provisions do not ensure or provide for every property or business owner's desired level of visibility for signs. The sign standards are intended to allow signs to have adequate visibility from streets and rights-of-way that abut a site, but not for visibility from streets and rights-of-way farther away. The regulations for signs and awnings have the following specific objectives: 
(1)  To ensure that signs and awnings are designed, constructed, installed and maintained according to standards to safeguard life, health, property and public welfare and to eliminate excessive and/or confusing sign displays that create potential hazards to motorists, pedestrians and to property. 
(2)  To allow and promote positive conditions for sign communication while at the same time restrict signs which create continuous visual clutter and hazards at public right-of-way intersections; 
(3)  To reflect and support the desired character and development patterns of the various zoning districts in order to plan and promote an attractive environment; 
(4)  To allow for adequate and effective signs in commercial and industrial zones while preventing signs from dominating the appearance of the area, thereby encouraging a positive business atmosphere; 
(5)  To establish a sign application and sign permit review process that effectively regulates issues pertaining to the location, placement and physical characteristics of signs in an effort to ensure compatibility with adjoining land uses, architecture and landscape. 
(6)  To provide for consistent and fair application and enforcement of regulations pertaining to signs and to ensure that the constitutionally guaranteed right of free speech is protected. 
(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10) 
Sec. 48-2. - Findings. 
    The city finds: 
(1)  Exterior signs serve as an adequate medium through which expression may be conveyed. 
(2)  Mismanaged and/or accumulation and proliferation of signage has the potential to impede visibility and flow for the passage of vehicular traffic and pedestrian movement, thereby creating a hazard for the health, safety and welfare of the public. 
(3)  Consistent regulation of the physical characteristics and placement of exterior signs can produce a more desirable effect on the character, quality and economic vitality of the community. 
(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10) 
Sec. 48-3. - Scope. 
    The requirements of this chapter apply to all signs, sign structures, awnings, banners and strobe lights located within the City of Watertown. A lessee or owner shall not permit a sign to be placed, erected or maintained on property under their control that does not conform to the requirements of this chapter and all other applicable regulations. 
(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10) 
Sec. 48-4. - Clarification for rights-of-way. 
    Signs established by city, county or state agencies are permitted in rights-of-way. Non-governmental/jurisdictional signs located in the rights-of-way are prohibited except in the following situations where any of the following apply: 
(1)  Building signs, sign structures, banners and awnings that are located in the Central Business District which extend from private property over public sidewalks provided such signs, sign structures, banners and awnings adhere to the requirements of this chapter; or 
(2)  Portable or temporary signs located in the central business district not exceeding six square feet of surface area, and which are no taller than three feet from the ground. 
(3)  Public art. 
(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10) 
Sec. 48-5. - Authority. 
    This chapter shall be administered and enforced by the zoning administrator. 
(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10) 
Sec. 48-6. - Administration. 
    The zoning administrator shall have authority to implement procedures, forms, and written policies for administering the provisions of this chapter. The zoning administrator shall examine all applications for permits for the erection of signs, issuance of permits and denials, authorize the continued use of signs that conform with the requirements of this chapter, record and file all applications for permits with any accompanying plans and documents, make inspections of signs in the City of Watertown, unless required by the building inspector, and make such reports as the city may require. 
(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10) 
Sec. 48-7. - Hierarchy of regulations. 
(a)  Conflicts within chapter 62, zoning. In general, an area with base zoning, PUD (planned unit development), overlay zoning, or another planned district is subject to all of the sign regulations of this chapter. When the regulations conflict, unless specifically indicated otherwise, the regulations for a planned district supersede regulations for an overlay zone and the regulations for an overlay zone shall supersede regulations for base zones. The regulations for planned districts and overlay zones shall supersede conflicting regulations for a specific use or development unless specifically stated otherwise. 
(b)  Other conflicts. In the event that no sign regulations exist in a planned district, this chapter shall govern. Where there is a conflict between a land use regulation and a structural regulation, or other conflicts not otherwise addressed by this chapter, the most restrictive shall apply. 
(c)  Objective land use standards and definitions that apply to signs and awnings. Signs, sign structures, awnings and banners being constructed as part of a larger development project shall be subject to additional standards when applicable. Where a land use review is required, the review procedures and criteria contained in this chapter shall apply except as follows: 
(1)  Sign adjustments or modifications. Approval criteria for sign adjustments shall be made by the zoning administrator. 
(2)  Nonconforming signs. Approval criteria for the determination of nonconforming sign status shall be made by the zoning administrator. 
(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10) 
Sec. 48-8. - Relationship to other city, regional, state and federal regulations. 
(a)  Compliance required. In addition to the requirements of the zoning chapter, signs shall comply with all other applicable city, regional, state and federal regulations. Where the provisions of this chapter conflict with those set forth in other regulations under the Municipal Code of Watertown, the more restrictive shall control. 
(b)  References to other regulations. References in this chapter to other city, regional, state or federal regulations do not constitute a complete list of such regulations. These references do not imply any responsibility by the city for enforcement of regional, state, or federal regulations. 
(c)  Current versions and citations. All references to other city, regional, state, or federal regulations in this chapter refer to the most current version and citation for those regulations, unless specifically indicated otherwise. Where the referenced regulations have been repealed, sign code requirements for compliance are no longer in effect. 
(d)  Sign-, sign structure- and awning-, and banner-related provisions. Any approved land use review that applies to a specific site shall supersede the standards of this chapter. Examples of land use reviews include master plans, impact mitigation plans, conditional or interim uses, adjustments, design standards and historic design standards. In the event that a land use review does not include provisions for signs, sign structures and/or awnings, the provisions of this chapter shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10) 
Sec. 48-9. - Applying the code. 
    Literal readings of the code language shall be used. Regulations are no more or less strict than as stated. Words used in this chapter shall have their normal dictionary meaning unless otherwise stated with specific meaning or reference, or unless the context clearly indicates another meaning. 
(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10) 
Sec. 48-10. - Situations where the code is silent. 
    Proposals for signs where the code is silent, or where the rules of this chapter do not provide a basis for concluding that the sign is allowed, are prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10) 
Sec. 48-11. - Severability. 
    In the event any word or sentence in this chapter, or provision or portion of this chapter, or rules adopted by this chapter is invalidated by any court of competent jurisdiction, the remaining words and/or sentences, provisions, or portions thereof shall not be affected and shall continue in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10) 
Sec. 48-12. - Definitions. 
    The following words and terms, wherever they occur in this chapter, shall be interpreted as herein defined: 
    Abandoned sign means any sign, awning or banner and/or its supporting sign structure which for 180 or more consecutive days has no longer been maintained by the entity which established the sign, or which for a period of 180 or more consecutive days no longer serves the purpose originally intended by the sign, or which has become irrelevant, or which has not been maintained in a manner sufficient to uphold the aesthetic value or physical characteristics of the sign. Signs applicable to a business temporarily suspended because of a change in ownership or management of such business shall not be deemed abandoned unless the property remains vacant for a period of one year or more. Any sign remaining after demolition of a principal structure shall be deemed to be abandoned. Non-conforming signs shall be regulated according to section 48-32. 
    Area of sign means the area of the largest single face of the sign within a perimeter which forms the outside shape, but excluding the necessary supports or uprights on which the sign may be placed. If the sign consists of more than one section or module, all areas will be totaled. Any irregular shaped sign area shall be computed by using the actual sign face surface. In the case of wall signs, the area of the copy will be used. 
    Awning means a roof-like cover, often of fabric, plastic, metal or glass designed and intended for protections from the weather or as a decorative embellishment, and which projects from a wall or roof of a structure primarily over a window, walk, or the like. Any part of an awning which also projects over a door shall be counted as an awning. 
    Awning sign means a sign printed on, or in some fashion attached directly to the surface of an awning. 
    Back lit (sign illumination) means a direct source of light which illuminates a sign by shining through a translucent surface of a sign, including plastic signs, lit from an internal light source.
