    Backed sign means a sign with copy on two faces that are back-to-back, V-shaped, A-shaped, stacked, side-by-side, parallel, or within ten degrees of parallel of each other. 
    Balloon sign means a sign consisting of a bag made of lightweight material supported by helium, hot, or pressurized air which is greater than 24 inches in diameter. 
    Banner means a temporary sign typically made of cloth, plastic, or vinyl materials. 
    Beacon/search beacon means any light with one or more beams directed into the atmosphere or directed at one or more points not on the same lot as the light source; also, any light with one or more beams that rotate or move. 
    Bench sign means a sign which is affixed to a bench not to include memorial dedications in park or recreational areas. 
    Billboard means a sign structure with a surface area over 100 square feet per surface that identifies or communicates a commercial or noncommercial message. 
    Building length means the longest straight line parallel to adjacent public right-of-way from end wall to end wall of a building. 
Figure 1: Building Length 

    Building "shy zone" means the area on the sidewalk within two feet of the building face. 
    Building sign means any sign attached to or supported by any building. 
    Canopy means a roof-like cover, often of fabric, plastic, metal or glass, on a support, which provides overhead shelter or shade over a doorway. An awning or a marquee is not a canopy. 
    Canopy sign means any sign that is part of or attached to a canopy, made of fabric, plastic, or structured protective over a door or entrance. 
    Changeable copy sign means a sign or portion thereof with characters, letters, or illustrations that can be changed or rearranged through manual, mechanical, or electrical means without altering the face or the surface of the sign. A sign on which the only copy that changes is an electronic or mechanical indication of time and temperature shall be considered a "time and temperature" portion of a sign and not a commercial message or a changeable copy sign for purposes of this chapter. 
    Commercial speech means any sign which advertises or identifies a product, business, service, event, or any other matter of commercial nature. 
    Copy and graphic means the graphical content of a sign surface in either permanent or removable components, pictograph, symbolic or alphabetic form. 
    Day(s) means calendar days, unless specifically stated as working days. 
    Direct illumination (sign illumination) means a sign whose light source is either located in the interior of the sign so that the rays go through the face of the sign, or which is attached to the face of the sign and is perceived as a design element of the sign. 
    Dynamic sign means any sign with characteristics that appear to have movement or that appear to change, caused by any method other than physically removing and replacing the sign or its components, whether the apparent movement or change is in the display, the sign structure, or any other component of the sign. This includes displays that incorporate technology or methods allowing the sign face to change the image without having to physically or mechanically replace the sign face or its components, as well as any rotating, revolving, moving, flashing, blinking or animated display and any display that incorporates movement such as rotating panels, LED lights manipulated through digital input, digital ink or any other method or technology that allows the sign face to present a series of images or displays, regardless of the frequency at which the change occurs. 
    External illumination means illumination of a sign that is affected by an artificial source of light not contained with the sign itself. 
    Fascia sign means a single-faced sign attached flush to a building or other structure. Fascia signs do not include sign structures that are attached to signs defined as sign structures by this section. 
    Facade means the front of a building; part of a building facing a street. 
    Flag means any fabric or similar lightweight material attached at one end of the material, usually to a staff or pole, so as to allow movement of the material by atmospheric changes and which contains distinctive colors, patterns, symbols, emblems, insignia, or other symbolic devices. 
    Freestanding sign means a sign and its applicable structure supported upon the ground that is not attached to any building. 
    Grade means the elevation or level of the ground, street or public right-of-way closest to the sign, awning or banner to which reference is made. 
    Hazardous sign means a sign constituting a hazard to public safety because it no longer meets the lateral and/or vertical loads as specified in the building code, or because it no longer meets the wiring and installation standards of the electrical code, or because it is located or situated in such a way that it poses a threat to public safety by obstructing traffic or pedestrian movement or lines-of-sight. 
    Height of sign means the vertical distance measured from the average grade at the base of the sign to the top of the highest attached component of the sign. 
    Illuminated facade highlights means lighted areas that highlight a building's architectural or structural features and that do not convey a message or image. Illuminated facade highlights can be created either by light projected onto a feature or highlighting a feature with a light fixture. Neon tubing highlights, electronic highlights, or other highlights with color features along a wall or facade's structural features is prohibited. 
    Incidental sign means a small sign, emblem, or decal no larger than one square foot. 
    Lawn sign means a freestanding sign made of lightweight materials such as cardboard or vinyl that is supported by a frame, pole, or other support structure placed directly in the ground without foundation or other anchor. 
    Monument sign means a low profile freestanding sign, with its base resting on the ground and incorporating the design and building materials complementary to the architectural theme of the buildings on the same property. 
    Non-commercial speech means dissemination of messages not classified as commercial speech which include, but are not limited to, messages concerning political, religious, social, ideological, public service and informational topics. 
    Nonconforming sign means a sign that was created in conformance with Watertown Municipal Code, but which subsequently, due to a change in the zoning, land use regulations, or Municipal Code regulations, is no longer in conformance with the current applicable Municipal Code regulations. 
    Off-premises sign means any sign or banner located on any real property for which the owner, maintainer, or entity causing the sign or banner to exist is different from the owner, maintainer, or entity occupying the property on which the sign or banner is located. 
    On-premises sign means a sign identifying or advertise an establishment, person, activity, goods, products or services located on the site where the sign is installed. 
    Owner means, for purposes of this chapter, any person, people, party(ies) recorded on official land records. 
    Permanent sign means any sign not classified as a temporary sign, and which is placed on a structure or affixed to or placed on the ground for a period for more than 14 consecutive days. 
    Pole sign. See Pylon sign . 
    Portable sign means any sign or banner not permanently attached to the ground or a building and designed to be moved easily. Portable signs include, but are not limited to, A-boards, portable reader-boards, and similar signs. For purposes of this chapter, portable signs shall be considered temporary signs. 
    Projecting sign means any sign attached to and projecting out from a building face or wall, generally at right angles, to the building. Projecting signs include signs that extend partially or fully into the right-of-way or partially or fully on private property. 
    Pylon sign means any freestanding sign which as its supportive structure(s) anchored in the ground and which has a sign face elevated above ground level by pole(s) or beam(s) and with the area below the sign face open. 
    Right-of-way means, for purposes of this chapter, a right-of-way shall be defined as any public or private area that allows for the passage of people or goods. Right-of-way includes passageways such as freeways, streets, bike paths, alleys, and walkways. A public right-of-way is a right-of-way that is dedicated or deeded to the public for public use and under the control of a public agency. 
    Roof sign means any sign erected, constructed or placed upon or over a roof, or placed so as to extend over or above the roofline, which is wholly or partly supported by such buildings. Roof signs shall not include signs located on a mansard roof if the sign is mounted vertically and architecturally integrated with the roof. For the purposes of this chapter architecturally integrated mansard signs and other architecturally integrated signs located below the principal roof line shall be classified as wall signs. 
    Scrolling text means a type of movement in which the letters or symbols move vertically or horizontally across the sign in a continuous scroll, permitting a viewer to observe the message over time. Scrolling shall not include flashing or other types of video movement. 
    Sign means materials placed or constructed, or light projected, that (1) conveys a message or image, and (2) is used to inform or attract the attention of the public. Some examples of signs are materials or lights meeting the definition of the preceding sentence and which are commonly referred to as signs, placards, A-boards, posters, billboards, murals, diagrams, banners, flags, or projected slides, images or holograms. The scope of the term 'sign' does not depend on the content of the message or image conveyed. 
    Sign contractor means any person, partnership or corporation engaged in whole or in part of the erection or maintenance of signs. 
    Sign face means the surface of the sign upon, against, or through which the message of the sign is exhibited. 
    Sign maintenance means normal care needed to keep a sign functional including fixing or replacement of broken or worn parts. Replacement includes comparable materials only. Repairs may be made with the sign in position or with the sign removed. 
    Sign structure means any device or material which supports, or has supported, or is capable of supporting, a sign in a stationary position, including decorative components. 
    Structural alteration means modification of a sign, sign structure or awning that affects the sign or awning size, shape, height, or location; changes in structural materials; or replacement of electrical components with other than comparable materials. The replacement of wood parts with metal parts, the replacement of incandescent bulbs with light emitting diodes (LED), or the addition of electronic elements to a non-electrified sign constitute structural alterations. Structural alteration does not include ordinary sign maintenance or repair, repainting an existing sign surface, including changes of message or image, exchanging painted and pasted or glued materials on painted wall signs, or exchanging display panels of a sign through release and closing of clips or other brackets. 
    Swinging sign means any sign installed on an arm, mast or spar, which is not permanently fastened to an adjacent wall or upright pole. 
    Temporary business sign means a temporary sign which is used by a business to display commercial messages pertaining to on site services and goods or any non-commercial message. 
    Temporary sign means any sign placed on a structure or affixed to or placed on the ground for limited period of time not exceeding 14 consecutive days. This includes items such as banners, portable signs, sandwich or curb signs. 
    Through pedestrian zone means the portion of a sidewalk or walkway that is intended for pedestrian travel and is entirely free of permanent and temporary objects. 
    Wall sign means any sign attached to a wall or building with the sign's face in a parallel plane to the plane of the building. This includes signs painted directly on a wall. 
    Window sign means any sign installed on a window for purposes of viewing from outside the premises. For purposes of this chapter, a window sign which is located inside a building but which is visible from a public right-of-way or adjacent public or private property shall be considered a window sign. 
(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10; Ord. No. 362, § 1, 10-25-11; Ord. No. 382, § 1, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 48-13. - Permits required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, company or other entity to erect, alter or relocate within the city any sign without first obtaining a permit and paying the fee required herein unless provided elsewhere. The zoning administrator may require persons failing to hold such permit to pay double the permit fee. No person shall erect, construct, or maintain any sign upon any property or building without the consent of the owner or person entitled to possession of the property or building. Awnings require building permits and shall be reviewed by the zoning administrator and the building inspector. Certain installations are exempt from permit requirements. Exemption from permit or registration does not by default grant authorization for any sign, sign structure or awning to be erected or structurally altered in violation of the provisions of this chapter. 
(1)  Sign permits. No permanent sign shall be erected, altered, reconstructed, maintained or moved in the city without first securing a permit from the city. The content of the message or speech displayed on the sign shall not be reviewed or considered in determining whether to approve or deny a sign permit. A sign permit must be obtained for all permanent signs other than signs on awnings provided that the installation or application of the sign onto the awning occurs with the construction of the awning. Awnings that have been issued building permits do not need a separate awning sign permit, but the awning sign must be reviewed and approved by the zoning administrator prior to issuing the building permit. Indirect lighting for a sign requires a separate electrical permit. A sign permit is required in the situations listed below: 
a.  To establish a permanent sign; 
b.  To establish a temporary sign for more than 14 days for a time period deemed appropriate by the zoning administrator and not to exceed 30 days; or 
c.  To structurally alter a sign as defined as 'structural alteration' in section 48-12. 
(2)  Permit application. Application for a permit shall be in writing addressed to the zoning administrator and shall contain the following information: 
a.  Names and addresses of the applicant, owner of the sign and the owner of the property on which the sign is to be located. 
b.  The address at which the sign is to be erected. 
c.  The lot, block and addition on which the sign is to be erected and the street on which it is to front. 
d.  A complete set of plans showing the necessary elevations, setbacks, size and details to fully and clearly represent the construction and place of the sign. Plans shall depict the site triangle and unobstructed sight lines for vehicles. 
1.  Building signs. 
i.  A drawing of the proposed sign showing dimensions and describing materials, lettering, colors, illumination, and support systems. 
ii.  Photographs of the building face and the building faces of any adjacent buildings. 
iii.  A drawing of the building face and site plan showing the location of the proposed sign. 
iv.  A cross section of the building face showing how the sign will be attached and how far it will extend from the building. 
v.  Any pictorial proof or other information that the sign is of historical significance or is a reproduction of an historic sign. 
vi.  A building sign plan for a building with more than one use or business, showing all signs. The building sign plan shall be approved by the zoning administrator. 
2.  Monument signs. 
i.  A drawing of the proposed sign showing dimensions and describing materials, lettering, colors, illumination, and support systems. 
ii.  A cross section of the sign structure showing how the sign will be installed, including footings, etc. 
iii.  A site plan drawn on a certified survey showing the proposed sign setbacks. 
iv.  A freestanding sign plan for a building with more than one use or business, showing all signs on a given property. 
e.  Type of sign (i.e. wall sign, monument, etc.). 
f.  Certification by applicant indicating the application complies with all requirements of the sign ordinance. 
g.  If more than one use or business on the property, a sign plan shall be submitted showing all signs on a given property. 
h.  Sign permits become null and void if the sign is not installed 180 days after the issuance of a permit. 
(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10; Ord. No. 382, § 1, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 48-14. - Exempt signs. 
    The following signs are exempt from requiring a permit: 
(1)  Signs that are in existence and are being re-erected following sign repair and sign maintenance. 
(2)  Signs indicating building addresses, per requirements of state fire code. 
(3)  Notwithstanding any other provisions of this sign ordinance, signs consistent with table 1 containing non-commercial speech may be posted in accordance with M.S.A. § 211B.045 as may be amended. 
(4)  Signs located within the confines of a building, and which are not visible from the public right-of-way. 
(5)  Traffic or other municipal signs, civic or service organizations, legal notices, railroad crossing signs, danger, emergency signs, those signs concerned with safety and general welfare of the public, and other signs as may be approved by the zoning administrator. 
(6)  No sign permit is required for window signage that does not cover more than one-third of the total area of the window in which the sign is displayed. Signs covering more than one-third of a window shall be considered wall signs. 
(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10; Ord. No. 382, § 1, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 48-15. - Signs exemption table. 
    The following table 1 shall determine signage types, quantities, maximum sign face areas, setbacks and maximum aggregate signage that are exempt from requiring a permit according to the zoning district. A second sign may be allowed as long as the total sign face area does not exceed the maximum allowable sign face area for each type of sign and maximum aggregate signage for each lot.

(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10) 
Sec. 48-16. - Signs on public property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to paint, print, or in any way affix any picture, sign, signboard or poster on any post, utility pole, fire escape, hydrant, curb, sidewalk, tree, lamp post or other structure of any kind on, or as to overhang or protrude over any property owned by the City of Watertown or any easement or public right-of-way of the city. The city may at any time and without notice impound signs which have been installed on public property or within public right-of-way or easement. The city may not be held liable for any damage to impounded signs. 
(b)  The zoning administrator may approve temporary signs on public or institutional property for special events. The first approval for a site may allow only one use of the sign for a specified duration, not to exceed 30 days. Subsequent approvals for the same type of sign may allow recurring use of the sign for limited durations over a period of up to one year. 
(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10) 
Sec. 48-17. - Computations for sign area and face. 
(a)  Sign area formula. The area of a sign shall be determined by the zoning administrator using actual dimensions where practical, or approximate dimensions when irregularity of a sign shape warrants. The sign area shall be the sum of the area of not more than two contiguous rectangles or squares that enclose the extreme points or edges of all copy, and/or graphical components of said sign. Unless otherwise indicated, poles, bases, and other supports shall not be included in the sign area calculation. The area of a square or rectangular shaped sign is determined by multiplying the length (L) by the width (W). 
Figure 2: Sign Area Measurement 

(1)  Sign cabinets. The area of sign faces enclosed in frames or cabinets is determined based on the outer dimensions of the frame or cabinet surrounding the sign face. 
(2)  Backed signs. Only one side of a backed sign is counted in determining the area of sign faces. Where the two sides are not of equal size, the larger of the two sides is used for the determination of sign area. 
(3)  Multiple cabinets. For freestanding and projecting signs that contain multiple cabinets on one structure and oriented in the same direction, the modules together are counted as one sign face. 
(4)  Signs on a base material. When a sign is on a base material and attached without a frame, such as a wood board or Plexiglas panel, the dimensions of the base material are to be used. 
(5)  Painted wall signs. Painted wall signs are measured by drawing an imaginary rectangle around the edge of each of the sign elements. Sign elements will be measured as one unit when the distance between the elements is less than two times the length of each element. Visible wall area includes windows and doors, but not openings such as loading entrances. 
(6)  Awnings and marquees. When signs are incorporated into awnings, the sign area is determined by computing the area of an imaginary rectangle drawn around the sign face. 
(b)  Sign height measurement. The height of the sign shall be computed as the vertical distance measured from the average grade at the base of the sign to the top of the highest attached component of the sign. When a sign is located adjacent to a public road, and the height of the adjacent road is greater than the height of the proposed sign location, the height of the sign shall be measured from the average grade of the road adjacent to the sign. 
Figure 3: Sign Height Measurement 

(c)  Total sign area calculation. The total square footage of all sign surfaces shall be computed by adding together the sign areas of all signs on a property. 
Figure 4: Total Sign Area Measurement Example 

(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10; Ord. No. 382, § 1, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 48-18. - Prohibited signs. 
    The following are prohibited in all zoning districts. 
(1)  Signs obstructing vision. Any sign which obstructs the vision of drivers or pedestrians or detracts from the visibility of official traffic-control device. This includes indoor signs that are visible from public streets. 
(2)  Permanent balloon signs. 
(3)  Portable signs, except temporary signs as defined in section 48-12. 
(4)  Unofficial traffic signs or signals. Signs that imitate or resemble official traffic lights, signs or signals or signs that interfere with the effectiveness of any official traffic light, sign or signal. 
(5)  Signs with moving parts, moving lighting or animation. No sign shall display any moving parts, be illuminated with any flashing or intermittent lights, use changing light intensity, utilize spotlights giving off an intermittent or rotating beam existing as a collection or concentration of rays of light (including but not limited to revolving beacons, beamed lights, or similar devices), or be animated. The only exceptions to this provision include allowable changeable copy signs; barbershop poles; static time, temperature, and price information changing when necessary. 
(6)  Signs erected, constructed or structurally altered without a permit. 
(7)  Roof signs. 
(8)  Hazardous signs, any sign or sign structure which is structurally unsafe, is not kept in good repair, or is capable of causing electrical shock to persons likely to come in contact. 
(9)  Billboards. 
(10)  Signs with obscene, indecent, or immoral matter that is prurient in content or nature or exhibition, shall be prohibited on signs. 
(11)  Painted wall signs including signs painted on the face of a structure. Works of art which are not commercial messages are exempt. 
(12)  Signs that make noise. 
(13)  Signs mounted or painted on vehicles when the vehicle is parked or stored on property or adjacent rights-of-way in such a manner as to identify a business or advertise a product. 
(14)  Off-premises signs. 
(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10; Ord. No. 382, § 1, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 48-19. - Regulations specific to a given zoning district. 
    The standards for exempt signs are stated in section 48-15, table 1 of this chapter. Standards for signs not listed as an exempt sign per section 48-15, table 1 shall be as follows: 
(1)  Residential zoning district. 
a.  In general. Any sign(s) in residential zoning districts which do not meet the standards for exempt signs in table 1 are not permitted unless in conformance with the subsections below. The zoning administrator may refer the request for a sign permit to the planning commission and city council as provided for in section 48-32. 
b.  Residential monument signs. 
1.  In addition to the total allowable sign area for individual residences within a residential zoning district, one monument sign for a unified residential area with six or more units shall be allowed. 
i.  Thirty-two square foot maximum copy and graphic area per entrance; 
ii.  Seventy-five square foot maximum total monument area per entrance; 
iii.  Eight-foot maximum height; 
iv.  Located at primary entrances to subdivision; 
v.  A second sign may be permitted if there is more than one entrance from a public street into the unified residential area, for a maximum of two residential monument signs per unified residential area. 
vi.  Single or double faced. If double faced, the sign faces shall be parallel; 
vii.  External illumination; 
viii.  Located with a dedicated permanent sign easement and not within public right-of-way; and 
ix.  If the sign is to be located in a development which includes individual ownership parcels, the sign shall be located on a parcel held in common ownership and shall be perpetually maintained by a homeowner's association or responsible property owners. 
x.  Changeable copy signs are not permitted for, or as a part of, a residential monument sign. 
c.  Conditionally permitted uses in residential districts: For the following conditionally permitted uses within a residential district, permanent signs which comply with the following standards are permitted. If the use is not specifically listed below, the sign shall be regulated by this chapter. 
1.  Public and semipublic educational, religious and institution facilities: For each educational, religious, public or private institution, and nursing home property, signs are permitted which comply with the following standards: 
i.  Monument signs: 
A.  One sign not to exceed 32 square feet maximum copy and graphic area; 
B.  Seventy-five square feet maximum monument area; 
C.  Eight-foot maximum height; 
D.  Single or doubled faced; and 
E.  Internal or external illumination and the light source shall not be exposed. 
ii.  Building signs: 
A.  Individually mounted letters not to exceed 24 inches in height; 
B.  One sign, area not to exceed 50 square feet or ten percent of the area of the building on which the sign is located, whichever is less; and 
C.  Illumination shall be external. 
(2)  Central business district. The city council has determined that a successful commercial district benefits all residents and visitors in Watertown through the competitive offering of various goods and services in a pleasing environment. The city council has determined that several factors influence the perception and successfulness of an area, including, but not limited to, lighting, signage, landscaping and pedestrian amenities. 
a.  The city shall encourage the use of pedestrian-scale projecting signage as a means of promoting an inviting and walkable area. 
b.  The area of projecting, canopy signs, marquees, and awnings shall not be used in calculating the maximum square feet for a given building within the central business district. 
c.  Signs shall meet all applicable requirements of this chapter and the requirements of the Watertown Downtown Design Standards. 
d.  Signage may be permitted on the rear side of buildings at a rate not to exceed one square foot per two linear feet of building frontage at the rear of the building to a maximum of 25 square feet. "Rear of the building" is defined in this case as the side most opposite to Lewis Avenue. 
e.  All businesses within a multi-tenant building must be represented on the sign(s). 
f.  Nonconforming signs or sign structures shall not be considered. 
g.  Signs shall not be permitted to be internally lit, unless new businesses are established within an existing building and are trying to conform to, be consistent with, or match existing signage of the principal tenant. The zoning administrator shall determine if proposed signage is consistent.

(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10; Ord. No. 382, § 1, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 48-20. - Building signs. 
(a)  Building sign area allowed. One square foot of aggregate sign area may be erected for every lineal foot of building frontage to a maximum of 100 square feet. This total shall not include exempt signs and standards outlined in table 1. In the case of a building on a corner lot, aggregate building signage may be increased one square foot per two lineal feet of secondary street frontage, to a maximum of 100 square feet. No more than 100 square feet may be permitted on one side, 200 square feet total. 
(b)  Multi-tenant building. Where a building, group of attached buildings on the same block, or center contains more than one tenant, the allowable sign area for any single business may be its portion of the gross square footage of the building or center applied as a percentage to the allowable sign area of the entire building or center, subject to size limitations for specific signs. No more than one building sign per each tenant shall be permitted. This provision shall not include projecting signage allowed in the C-3 zoning district. All signage within multi-tenant buildings shall be consistent in design and construction. 
(c)  Letters, symbols, and logos. Under no circumstances shall a letter, symbol, or logo dimension greater than six square feet be allowed in any zoning district. 
(d)  Convenience stores. Only one sign on a canopy in a convenience store or gasoline pump use may be permitted. Such sign shall be one square foot per linear foot of frontage of the canopy to a maximum sign area of 50 square feet. Such sign shall be confined to the actual dimensions of the canopy. 
(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10; Ord. No. 382, § 1, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 48-21. - Monument signs. 
(a)  Number of signs. One sign shall be permitted on each lot of record, provided however, if the frontage of such lot measured in a straight line along such street exceeds 500 feet, then two such signs shall be permitted. In the case of a corner lot, one additional sign may be permitted. A minimum distance of 250 feet shall separate the two permitted monument signs on a single lot of record. 
(b)  Setbacks. The minimum front yard setback required for monument signs is ten feet. All signs shall have a side setback not less than the height of the sign. 
(c)  Maximum sign area. The total area of a monument sign shall be the actual square footage of one sign face. Double faced signs may be permitted with the maximum square footage permitted on each side. The maximum sign area of a monument sign shall not exceed 25 square feet; provided, however, the maximum sign area may be increased one square foot for each additional two feet of setback over the minimum required setback to a maximum sign area of 60 square feet and not to exceed a height of 12 feet. 
(d)  Maximum height of sign. The maximum height of a monument sign shall be five feet; provided, however, signage height may be increased one foot for each additional two feet of setback over the minimum required setback to a maximum sign height of 12 feet. The vertical distance between the sign face and the base shall not be greater than 12 inches. 
(e)  Width. The width of the top of the sign structure shall be no more than 120 percent of the width of the base. Monument signs shall have a monolithic or columnar line that maintains essentially the same profile from grade to top. 
(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10) 
Sec. 48-22. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 382, § 1, adopted Dec. 9, 2014, deleted § 48-22, which pertained to pylon signs and derived from Ord. No. 349, § 1, adopted June 8, 2010. 
Sec. 48-23. - Projecting signs. 
    Projecting signs shall be permitted in commercial districts, and shall be encouraged particularly in the central business district, provided that all supports for signs and lighting is architecturally compatible with the principal structure and surrounding area, as well as compatible with the most recently adopted version of the Watertown Downtown Design Standards. 
(1)  Only one projecting sign is allowed per tenant in a multi-tenant building. 
(2)  Signs shall not project over vehicle parking, or public or private streets. 
(3)  All signs shall maintain a minimum of eight feet of clearance over pedestrian ways. 
(4)  The projecting sign shall be hung at a right angle from the building face. 
(5)  Projecting signs may extend a maximum of four feet from the building wall and must be setback a minimum of two feet from the face of curb or street surface. 
(6)  The use of guy wires, chains, straps or steel rods as a support is strictly prohibited. In the event that the weight of a projecting sign requires the use of a guy wire, chain, strap or steel rod for support, the sign shall not be permitted. 
(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10) 
Sec. 48-24. - Changeable copy signs. 
    Changeable copy signs are permitted in all zoning districts, if approved by the city council following a public hearing held by the planning commission. The city council may allow a changeable copy sign located on public property in the central business district without a public hearing. Changeable copy signs must be integrated into an allowable monument sign as regulated by this chapter and subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  Maximum of 25 square feet or 50 percent of the maximum sign area, whichever is less, shall be dedicated to the changeable copy face. 
(2)  Changeable copy signs must be separated from other changeable copy signs by at least 50 feet. Standard setback regulations for monument and pylon signs shall apply. 
(3)  Standard regulations for monument signs shall apply including setbacks and height of the sign as regulated by this chapter. 
(4)  All portions of the message shall have minimum display duration of four seconds and shall be a static display. In all districts, no portion of the message may flash, blink, twirl, change color or in any manner imitate movement as to be deemed a distraction to passing motorists. The exception to this regulation is the transitions between each display panel by fading or dissolving in or out and the allowance of messages that appear to scroll vertically or horizontally across the sign, but are otherwise in compliance with the requirements of this ordinance, including the definition of "scrolling text." Reasonable speed of the scrolling text shall be determined by the city. 
(5)  All electronic changeable copy signs shall be equipped with an automatic dimming device that controls the sign's brightness to meet the following standards: 
i.  The electronic changeable copy sign shall not exceed 500 lumens per square meter measured one foot from the sign face for the time period between one-half hour before sunset and one-half hour after sunrise. 
ii.  The electronic changeable copy sign shall not cast glare that exceeds 0.4 of a foot candle above ambient light measured at the property line of an adjoining residential property or one foot candle measured at the curb line of a public right-of-way. 
(6)  During the review and approval process, or at any time following the approval of the sign, the city may impose limits to the hours and times that a changeable copy sign may be permitted to be operated. 
(7)  The copy of the sign must be limited to ten words to allow passing motorists to read the entire copy with minimal distraction. 
(8)  Audio, speakers and any form of pyrotechnics is prohibited in association with an electronic changeable copy sign. 
(9)  When located within 150 feet of a residentially-used lot in a residential zone, all parts of the electronic changeable copy sign must be oriented so that no portion of the sign face is visible from an existing or permitted principal structure on that lot or the changeable copy sign shall be dimmed to a light level, as determined by the city, which does not increase the existing light levels on the affected residential property. 
(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10; Ord. No. 362, § 2, 10-25-11; Ord. No. 382, § 1, 12-9-14) 
Sec. 48-25. - Design standards. 
(a)  General. All signs, excluding temporary signs, shall be designed and constructed of materials that are similar to those used on the principal building. In the case of projecting signs located in the central business district, all signs, excluding temporary signs, shall be designed and constructed of materials and colors that are approved in the Watertown Downtown Design Standards Manual. Such signage shall be dominated with materials of permanency and strength and shall be compatible with other structures and signs in the development. A sign shall not obscure architectural features of a building. 
(b)  Sign face. No building sign face shall extend horizontally beyond the supporting structure a distance greater than six inches. These standards do not apply to projecting signs, which are generally at right angles to buildings. 
(c)  Allowable sign area. Unless otherwise indicated in this chapter, ground, monument, and pylon signs, where permitted, shall be limited to one per property for total allowable sign area. 
(d)  Signs needing electricity. Signs needing electricity shall be subject to all applicable electrical codes as may be amended. Overhead wiring for such signs is prohibited. 
(e)  Wind pressure and dead load requirements. All signs and sign structures shall be designed and constructed to withstand a wind pressure as regulated by the State building code and/or other ordinances of the City of Watertown. Temporary signs shall be excluded from dead load provisions as required above. 
(f)  Clearance from electric lines. Clearance from electric lines shall be in conformance with the National Electric Code (NEC). 
(g)  Number of faces. No sign shall have more than two faces. Sign faces shall be parallel unless otherwise permitted. 
(h)  Illumination. 
(1)  Illumination of signs shall comply with chapter 62 code requirements governing lighting and glare control. 
(2)  Lighted signs shall not be permitted in any residential zoning district except in the case of institutional P-2 districts. 
(3)  Indirect illumination for signs shall be so constructed and maintained so that the source of light (i.e. the bulb; not the fixture) is not visible from the public right-of-way or residential property. 
(4)  A constant level of light shall be maintained, provided that this shall not be construed to prohibit use of an automatic dimmer to reduce garish effects at night. Lighting shall not flash or move unless approved by the city council. Neon tubing and highlights with color features along a wall or facade's structural features is prohibited. Colored lighting schemes shall be prohibited in all zoning districts unless otherwise permitted by city council. 
(i)  Landscaping. Sign owners shall be required to maintain the appearance of the ground around all signs detached from buildings and to landscape where possible. 
(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10) 
Sec. 48-26. - Construction, maintenance and repairs. 
(a)  All signs and structures shall be properly maintained and shall be constructed of sufficiently permanent materials so that they shall not succumb to deterioration from weathering. 
(b)  Any existing sign or sign structure which is rotted, unsafe, deteriorated, defaced, or otherwise altered, shall be repainted, repaired, replaced, or removed if repair is not feasible. Sign maintenance shall be the responsibility of the underlying fee owner. 
(c)  If the zoning administrator finds that any sign has been erected without the necessary approvals or any sign is being maintained in violation of this chapter or any zoning provision, the zoning administrator may give written notice of such violation to the installer of said sign, the permit holder, and/or the owner, lessee or manager of the property on which the sign is located as best as can be determined by the zoning administrator. If, after receiving said notice, such person fails to remove or alter said sign so as to comply with the provisions of this chapter or zoning provisions, the sign shall be deemed to be a nuisance and may be abated by the city under M.S.A. ch. 429, or such other procedure as determined appropriate. The cost of such abatement, including administrative expenses and reasonable attorneys' fees, may be levied as a special assessment against the property upon which the sign is located. 
(d)  Inspections. The zoning administrator may cause to be inspected from time to time any sign regulated by this chapter for the purpose of ascertaining whether the sign is secure, and whether it is in need of removal or repair to be in compliance with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10) 
Sec. 48-27. - Abandoned signs. 
    Signs or supporting structures not used for 180 consecutive days must be removed. Any abandoned sign now or hereafter existing shall be taken down and removed by the owner, agent, or person having beneficial use of the building or land upon which sign may be found within 30 days after written notification from the zoning administrator and, upon failure to comply with such notice within the time specified in such order, the zoning administrator is hereby authorized to cause removal of such sign, and any expense thereto shall be paid by the owner of the building or structure to which the sign is attached. 
(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10) 
Sec. 48-28. - Emissions prohibited. 
    No sign shall emit audible sound, noticeable odor, or smoke or other visible matter. 
(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10) 
Sec. 48-29. - Obstruction of fire exits, light or ventilation. 
    No sign shall be permitted to obstruct or interfere in any way with the free use of any door, window, fire escape, nor to obstruct or impair operation of any opening required for light or ventilation. 
(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10) 
Sec. 48-30. - Traffic hazard. 
    It shall be illegal for any sign to interfere with, obstruct the view of, or be of such design which may be confused with any authorized traffic sign, signal, or device; nor shall any sign imitate an official traffic sign or include the words "Stop," "Look," "Caution," or any other word, phrase, symbol, or character in such a manner as to interfere with, mislead, or confuse those in transit. 
(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10) 
Sec. 48-31. - Time periods. 
    Temporary banners, signs and portable signs shall be permitted without a sign permit in all districts for a maximum time period of 14 days. The zoning administrator may grant special permission to allow temporary banners, signs, and portable signs for a greater time period, not to exceed 30 days. Such signs are subject to the quantity, size, quality and sign setback provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10) 
Sec. 48-32. - Appeal. 
    If the zoning administrator determines that a proposed sign does not meet the provisions or requirements of this chapter, the zoning administrator shall give notice of that determination and the reasons therefore to the applicant within 15 days of having received a completed application. If the applicant disagrees with the decision of the zoning administrator, the applicant may, within 15 days of the mailing of the zoning administrator's determination, appeal the decision to the planning commission by notifying the zoning administrator in writing of such appeal. 
    Upon receipt of such appeal, the zoning administrator shall schedule a public hearing with the planning commission. Written notice of the public hearing shall be mailed at least ten days before the date of the hearing to the applicant and property owners within 350 feet of the outer boundaries of the property in question. The failure to give mailed notice to individual property owners or defects in the notice shall not invalidate the proceedings, provided a bone fide attempt to comply with this decision has been made. 
    At the hearing the planning commission shall review the application and exhibits and hear the testimony of the applicant, the zoning administrator and all others wanting to be heard on the matter. Upon completion of the hearing the planning commission may uphold the decision of the zoning administrator or allow an appeal upon consideration of the following factors. The content of the sign shall not be considered. 
(1)  The location, size and design of the proposed sign(s); 
(2)  The character of the surrounding area; 
(3)  The proposed character of the surrounding area according to the Comprehensive Plan; 
(4)  The consistency of the proposed sign(s) in comparison to existing signs located in the surrounding area; 
(5)  The appropriateness of the proposed sign(s) in light of the anticipated use of the property; and 
(6)  The granting of a waiver which will not be detrimental to the public welfare nor create an adverse effect upon the surrounding property. 
    The planning commission shall recommend its decision to the city council for final determination. 
(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10) 
Sec. 48-33. - Fees. 
    Fees for sign permits shall be set by the city council in an amount determined by resolution of the city council from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10) 
Sec. 48-34. - Nonconforming signs. 
    It is recognized that signs exist within the zoning districts which were lawful before this sign ordinance was enacted, but will be prohibited under the terms of this chapter. It is the intent of this sign ordinance that nonconforming signs shall not be enlarged upon or expanded, nor be used as grounds for adding other signs or uses prohibited elsewhere in the same district. It is further the intent of this sign ordinance to permit legal nonconforming signs existing on the effective date of this sign ordinance to continue as legal nonconforming signs provided such signs are safe, are maintained so as not to be unsightly, and have not been abandoned or removed subject to the following provisions: 
(1)  No sign shall be enlarged or altered in a way which increases its nonconformity. 
(2)  If the use of the nonconforming sign or sign structure is discontinued for a period of one year the sign or sign structure shall not be reconstructed or used except in conformity with the provisions of this chapter. 
(3)  Should such nonconforming sign or sign structure be damaged or structure be destroyed by any means to an extent greater than 50 percent of its market value and all required permits for its reconstruction have not been applied for within 180 days of when the sign or sign structure was damaged, it shall not be reconstructed or used except in conformity with the provisions of this chapter. 
(4)  Should such sign or sign structure be moved for any reason for any distance whatsoever, it shall thereafter conform to the regulations for the zoning district in which it is located after it is moved. 
(5)  No existing sign devoted to a use not permitted by the zoning code in the zoning district in which it is located shall be enlarged, expanded or moved except in changing the sign to a sign permitted in the zoning district in which it is located. 
(6)  When a building loses its nonconforming status all signs devoted to the structure shall be removed and all signs painted directly on the structure shall be repainted in a neutral color or a color which complements the structure. 
(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10) 
Sec. 48-35. - Substitution clause. 
    The owner of any sign which is otherwise allowed by this chapter may substitute non-commercial speech in lieu of any other commercial speech or non-commercial speech. This substitution of copy may be made without any additional approval or permitting. The purpose of this provision is to prevent any inadvertent favoring of commercial speech over non-commercial speech, or favoring of any particular non-commercial speech over any other non-commercial speech. This provision prevails over any more specific provision to the contrary. 
(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10) 
Sec. 48-36. - Violations. 
    Violation of this chapter is a misdemeanor. Each day that the violation continues is a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 349, § 1, 6-8-10)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 50-1-50-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 50-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Commercial establishment means any premises where a commercial or industrial enterprise of any kind is carried on, and shall include restaurants, clubs, churches and schools. 
    Garbage means all putrescible wastes, including animal offal and carcasses of dead animals, but excluding human excreta, sewage and water-carried wastes. 
    Multiple residential dwelling means any building used for residential purposes consisting of more than four dwelling units with individual kitchen facilities for each. 
    Other refuse means ashes, nonrecyclable glass, crockery, cans, paper, boxes, rags and similar non-putrescible wastes, including sand, earth, brick, stone and concrete except when on-site construction is occurring, and trees, tree branches and wood except when stored as firewood. 
    Recyclable means materials which may be recycled or reused through recycling processes. 
    Residential dwelling means any single building containing one through four residential dwelling units with individual kitchen facilities for each. "Residential dwelling" includes townhouses. 
    Special pickup means any collection of materials other than garbage, other refuse, recyclables and yard waste, including white goods, household hazardous waste, furniture, oversized materials and construction debris. 
    Yard waste means leaves, grass clippings or other plant materials as may be defined by city council resolution. 
(Ord. No. 275, 11-22-05) 
Sec. 50-27. - Garbage collection. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner of an occupied residential dwelling, multiple residential dwelling or commercial establishment not to have periodic collection or disposal of garbage or other refuse as required in this article. It shall be unlawful to dump or bury garbage and other refuse in the city. 
(Ord. No. 275, 11-22-05) 
Sec. 50-28. - General operating and equipment standards. 
(a)  All solid waste which is hauled must be secured in covered, leak-proof vehicles or containers such that loads will not blow free or discharge liquids from the hauling vehicle. Where spillage does occur, the material must be picked up immediately by the hauler or solid waste transporter. Spillage that cannot be immediately and completely cleaned up must be reported to the city. 
(b)  All vehicles or containers which are used to haul solid waste on a regular basis must be kept clean and free of residues of the waste material so as to minimize problems associated with odors, animals, and insects. 
(c)  No one shall collect or transport solid waste that is smoking, smoldering, or burning, except in a container designed and approved by the fire marshall and the city for that purpose. 
(d)  Not including non-putrescible source-separated recyclable materials, solid waste may not be stored in any type of collection or transportation vehicle for a period of more than 48 hours. This period may be extended up to 72 hours if the waste cannot be disposed of or processed due to a legal holiday being celebrated on a Friday or Monday. Non-putrescible source-separated recyclable materials may be stored in collection and/or transportation vehicles for no longer than seven calendar days. 
(e)  No solid waste collection or transportation vehicle which is not thoroughly cleaned and free of waste residues may be parked outdoors within 500 feet of a commercial or residential structure not owned by the owner or the operator of the vehicle for more than two hours unless the city has been notified and has approved a longer duration. 
(f)  All relevant Minnesota Department of Transportation (MnDOT) and Minnesota Department of Health (MDH) requirements regarding equipment, operations, and inspections and all applicable local, state and federal regulations must be met. 
(g)  Insurance. The hauler shall obtain and submit certificates of insurance issued by insurers duly licensed by the State of Minnesota providing the following coverage, or a self-insurance plan certified by the Minnesota Commissioner of Commerce for providing equivalent coverage. 
(1)  General liability coverage in the amount of $500,000.00 for bodily injury per occurrence, $250,000.00 for property damage per occurrence, or $500,000.00 combined single limit; and 
(2)  Automobile liability coverage in the amounts of $500,000.00 for property damage, $250,000.00 for bodily injury per person and $500,000.00 for bodily injury per accident, or $500,000.00 combined single limit. 
(3)  Workers compensation insurance in accordance with M.S.A. ch. 176. 
    Nothing in this provision shall prohibit a hauler from providing insurance with limits higher than the limits provided herein. All such required policies shall name the City of Watertown as additional insureds. All policies and certificates shall be endorsed to require that the insurer provide at least a 60-day written notice to the city prior to the effective date of policy cancellation, non-renewal, or material adverse change in coverage terms. The hauler shall maintain insurance in compliance with this paragraph throughout the term of the license. 
(Ord. No. 275, 11-22-05) 
Secs. 50-29-50-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 50-41. - Required. 
(a)  Operating license. Any hauler which collects or transports mixed municipal solid waste in the City of Watertown must obtain and maintain an operating license from the city. 
(b)  Vehicles licensed/vehicle decals. All vehicles used by the hauler for the collection or transportation of mixed municipal solid waste within the city shall be included in the hauler's license application. The hauler shall affix a decal as required by the city in a conspicuous place on the left side of the cab of the vehicle for which it was issued. The hauler must maintain the license decal so that it is readily visible and legible at all times. Any vehicle not bearing the required decal shall be considered unlicensed. 
(c)  Identification. The business name and telephone number of the hauler shall be printed or painted in legible characters on both sides of all vehicles or containers used by the hauler to store, collect, or transport mixed municipal solid waste in the city. Such characters shall be at least four inches in height for all vehicles and at least two inches in height for all containers. 
(d)  It is unlawful for any person to haul garbage, other refuse or recyclables for hire without a license from the city, or to haul garbage, other refuse or recyclables from his own residence or business property other than as excepted in this article. 
(e)  It is unlawful for any person to scavenge or otherwise collect garbage, other refuse, recyclables or yard waste at the curb or from containers designated for recyclable materials without a license from the city and an account relationship with the owner or tenant of the premises. 
(f)  Nothing in this section shall prevent persons from hauling garbage, other refuse or recyclables from their own residences or business properties subject to the following conditions and requirements: 
(1)  All garbage must be transported in containers that are watertight on all sides and the bottom, with tightfitting covers on top; 
(2)  All other refuse and recyclables must be transported in vehicles with leakproof bodies and completely covered or enclosed so as to completely eliminate the possibility of loss of cargo; 
(3)  All garbage and other refuse must be dumped or unloaded only at the designated sanitary landfill or county designated facility; 
(4)  Recyclables must be disposed of at a recycling facility, organized recycling drive or through a licensed recyclable hauler; and 
(5)  Yard waste must be composted privately or be disposed of at a composting facility or through a licensed refuse hauler. 
(Ord. No. 275, 11-22-05) 
Sec. 50-42. - Hauler license requirements. 
(a)  A hauler license shall be granted only upon the condition that the licensee have watertight packer-type vehicles or, in the case of collection of recyclables, appropriate container vehicles to prevent loss in transit of liquid or solid cargo; that the vehicle be kept clean and as free from offensive odors as possible, and that the vehicle shall not be allowed to stand in any street longer than reasonably necessary to collect garbage, other refuse, yard waste or recyclables. Licenses shall be issued by the city council for a one-year period. License fees shall be set by city council resolution. 
(b)  The hauler shall designate and file at city hall collection dates in the city for residential collection. Collection on dates other than those filed is unlawful except to collect a missed pickup, special pickup as approved by the city, or when an observed holiday halls within that week. The hauler shall give at least 60 days' notice to the city and its customers of any change in collection dates. 
(c)  The city council, in the interest of maintaining healthful and sanitary conditions in the city, hereby reserves the right to limit the number of licenses to be issued pursuant to this article. 
(d)  An applicant for a hauler license shall file with the clerk-treasurer a schedule of proposed rates to be charged for the licensed period. A licensee shall give the city and its customers at least 60 days' notice for any proposed rate change. Any rate increase proposal will require approval by the city council. Haulers may charge on the basis of volume. 
(Ord. No. 275, 11-22-05) 
Sec. 50-43. - Licensee responsibilities. 
    Licensee's responsibilities shall include, but shall not be limited to those described in this section. 
    The licensee shall be responsible for compliance with all of the provisions of this chapter and all applicable state and federal statutes and rules promulgated there under. 
    The licensee shall allow the city, its employees and designees free access to the solid waste management activity, site, or facility; provided that the entrance and activity is undertaken after reasonable notice and during normal business hours, except as provided in M.S.A. § 115A.882 Records; inspection; for the purpose of making such inspections as may be necessary to determine compliance with the requirements of this chapter or any other applicable statute, ordinance, or regulation. 
    The licensee shall allow the city, its employees and designees access to records required under M.S.A. ch. 115A.882 Records; Inspection, MPCA Solid Waste Management Rules parts 7001.3500 Subp. 3. A. and 7035 concerning the operation of a solid waste management activity or facility. 
    No licensee shall operate any solid waste management activity or facility, or dispose of, or permit to be disposed, any solid wastes in a manner so as to degrade the soil, air, or waters of the city. Any licensee who causes any degradation of the soil, air, or waters of the city shall undertake whatever action is necessary to correct the degradation and restore the soil, air, or waters to its condition prior to its degradation. 
    The licensee shall be responsible for facilitating all environmental monitoring, including but not limited to water, soil, and landfill gases, which are required by this chapter or the license conditions for the applicable solid waste management activity or facility. 
    The licensee agrees to indemnify and save the city harmless from all injuries, losses, costs, and charges that may be incurred by the city due to the negligent or intentional acts the licensee, its officers, agents, or employees or the failure of the licensee to comply with the provisions of this chapter and which are not otherwise payable from the insurance and financial assurance required by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 275, 11-22-05) 
Sec. 50-44. - Reporting responsibilities. 
    If a commercial hauler terminates service to an account due to delinquent payment, the commercial hauler shall notify the city of this action within 15 days of the termination so that the Department may determine the potential for public health or pollution problems resulting from the lack of collection services at the property. 
(Ord. No. 275, 11-22-05) 
Secs. 50-45-50-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - RECYCLING 

Sec. 50-56. - Requirements. 
(a)  Recycling shall be provided by the hauler to the following: 
(1)  Curbside recycling to residential dwellings which have accounts with the hauler. 
(2)  Commercial and multiple residential dwellings. 
(b)  Recyclables collected by the hauler shall include tin cans, aluminum beverage cans, glass containers (all colors), plastics, newspapers, magazines, and cardboard. Other materials required to be recycled may be added by city council resolution. 
(Ord. No. 275, 11-22-05) 
Sec. 50-57. - Annual report. 
    All hauling licensees shall report to the city in written form by September 1 of each year the quantity of all recyclables and yard waste abated from the landfills for the previous 12-month period. Such quantities shall be reported by tonnage, with the exception that yard waste may be reported in estimates of cubic yardage abated. Failure to certify the volumes and submit the report may be cause for revocation of hauling license. 
(Ord. No. 275, 11-22-05) 
Sec. 50-58. - Hours of operation. 
(a)  Commercial licensed haulers must operate or haul only in commercial areas and between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. 
(b)  Residential licensed haulers must operate or haul only in residential areas and between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. 
(c)  No garbage or recycling hauling shall be allowed on Sundays. 
(Ord. No. 275, 11-22-05) 
Sec. 50-59. - Uniform applicability of county and state requirements. 
    The licensee shall comply with all applicable county ordinances and regulations and state laws and regulations not inconsistent with this chapter unless such laws supersede the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 275, 11-22-05) 
Chapter 51 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC PLACES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 51-1. - Right-of-way usage. 
(a)  The risk of damage including but not limited to landscaping, gardens, or plantings including nursery and inanimate materials, lawn irrigations systems, and pet containment systems that are installed or encroach on city owned right-of-way shall be assumed by the property owner. 
(b)  All disturbed areas shall be restored with sod or seed. 
(Ord. No. 340, § 1, 7-28-09) 
Secs. 51-2-51-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RIGHT-OF-WAY MANAGEMENT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 300, § 1, adopted June 26, 2007, repealed Ch. 51, Art. II, §§ 51-26-51-48, in its entirety. Subsequently, Ord. No. 301, § 1, adopted June 26, 2007 enacted a new Art. II, §§ 51-26-51-58 to read as herein set out. Prior to this amendment, Art. II, pertained to Right-of-Way Use Regulations and derived from Ord. No. 262, §§ 1.01-1.09, 1.11-1.23, adopted Dec. 14, 2004. 

Sec. 51-26. - Findings, purpose, and intent. 
(a)  To provide for the health, safety and welfare of its citizens, and to ensure the integrity of its streets and the appropriate use of the rights-of-way, the city strives to keep its rights-of-way in a state of good repair and free from unnecessary encumbrances. 
(b)  Accordingly, the city enacts this new article II of The Municipal Code of Watertown relating to right-of-way permits and administration. This article imposes reasonable regulation on the placement and maintenance of facilities and equipment currently within the city's rights-of-way or to be placed therein at some future time. It is intended to complement the regulatory roles of state and federal agencies. Under this article, persons excavating and obstructing the rights-of-way will bear financial responsibility for their work through the recovery of out-of-pocket and projected costs from persons using the public rights-of-way. 
(c)  This article shall be interpreted consistently with 1997 Session Laws, Chapter 123, substantially codified in M.S.A. §§ 237.16, 237.162, 237.163, 237.79, 237.81, and 238.086 (the "Act") and the other laws governing applicable rights of the city and users of the right-of-way. This Article shall also be interpreted consistent with Minnesota Rules 7819.0050 - 7819.9950 where possible. To the extent that any provision of this article cannot be interpreted consistently with the Minnesota Rules, the interpretation most consistent with the Act and other applicable statutory and case law is intended. 
(Ord. No. 301, § 1, 6-26-07) 
Sec. 51-27. - Election to manage the public rights-of-way. 
    Pursuant to the authority granted to the city under state and federal statutory, administrative and common law, the city elects pursuant to M.S.A. § 237.163 Subd. 2(b), to manage rights-of-way within its jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 301, § 1, 6-26-07) 
Sec. 51-28. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions apply to this article of this Code. References to "subdivisions" are unless otherwise specified references to subdivisions in this section. 
    Abandoned facility means a facility no longer in service or physically disconnected from a portion of the operating facility, or from any other facility, that is in use or still carries service. 
    Applicant means any person requesting permission to excavate, install utilities in or obstruct a right-of-way. 
    City means the city of Watertown, Minnesota. For purposes of sections 51-26 through 51-58, city means its elected officials, officers, employees and agents. 
    Commission means the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission. 
    Congested right-of-way means a crowded condition in the subsurface of the public right-of-way that occurs when the maximum lateral spacing between existing underground facilities does not allow for construction of new underground facilities without using hand digging to expose the existing lateral facilities in conformance with M.S.A. § 216D.04, Subd. 3, over a continuous length in excess of 500 feet. 
    Construction performance bond means any of the following forms of security provided at permittee's option: 
(1)  Cash deposit; 
(2)  Letter of credit, in a form acceptable to the city. 
    Degradation means a decrease in the useful life of the right-of-way caused by excavation in or disturbance of the right-of-way, resulting in the need to reconstruct such right-of-way earlier than would be required if the excavation or disturbance did not occur. 
    Degradation cost subject to Minnesota Rules 7819.1100 means the cost to achieve a level of restoration as determined by the city at the time the permit is issued, not to exceed the maximum restoration shown in plates 1 to 13, set forth in Minnesota Rules parts 7819.9900 to 7819.9950. 
    Degradation fee means the estimated fee established at the time of permitting by the city to recover costs associated with the decrease in the useful life of the right-of-way caused by the excavation, and which equals the degradation cost. 
    Delay penalty is the penalty imposed as a result of unreasonable delays in right-of-way excavation, obstruction, patching, or restoration as established by permit. 
    Department inspector means any person authorized by the city to carry out inspections related to the provisions of this section. 
    Director means the city administrator of the city, or her or his designee. 
    Emergency means a condition that: 
(1)  Poses a danger to life or health, or of a significant loss of property; or 
(2)  Requires immediate repair or replacement of facilities in order to restore service to a customer. 
    Equipment means any tangible asset used to install, repair, or maintain facilities in any right-of-way. 
    Excavate means to dig into or in any way remove or physically disturb or penetrate any part of a right-of-way. 
    Facility or facilities means tangible asset in the public right-of-way required to provide utility service. The term does not include facilities to the extent the location and relocation of such facilities are preempted by M.S.A. § 161.45, governing utility facility placement in state trunk highways. 
    High density corridor means a designated portion of the public right-of-way within which right-of-way users having multiple and competing facilities may be required to build and install facilities in a common conduit system or other common structure. 
    Hole means an excavation in the right-of-way, with the excavation having a length less than the width of the pavement or adjacent pavement. 
    Local representative means a local person or persons, or local designee of such person or persons, authorized by a registrant to accept service and to make decisions for that registrant regarding all matters within the scope of this article. The designee shall be identified by the registrant, person or persons in writing and maintained on file at city hall. Notice shall be deemed to be received by the registrant when provided to the local representative. 
    Management costs means the actual costs the city incurs in managing its rights-of-way, including such costs, if incurred, as those associated with registering applicants; issuing, processing, and verifying right-of-way permit applications; inspecting job sites and restoration projects; maintaining, supporting, protecting, or moving user facilities during right-of-way work; determining the adequacy of right-of-way restoration; restoring work inadequately performed, mapping of "as built" location of facilities located in the right-of-way; and revoking right-of-way permits and performing all other tasks required by this article, including other costs the city may incur in managing matters described in this article. Management costs do not include payment by a telecommunications right-of-way user for the use of the right-of-way, the fees and cost of litigation relating to the interpretation of Minnesota Session Laws 1997, chapter 123; M.S.A. §§ 237.162 or 237.163 or any ordinance enacted under those sections, or the city fees and costs related to appeals taken pursuant to section 802.61. 
    Obstruct means to place any tangible object in a right-of-way so as to hinder free and open passage over that or any part of the right-of-way for a period of eight hours or more without the issuance of a right-of-way permit. 
    Obstruction permit means the permit which, pursuant to this article, must be obtained before a person may obstruct a right-of-way, allowing the holder to hinder free and open passage over the specified portion of that right-of-way, for the duration specified therein, including a blanket permit for a period of time and for types of work specified by the director, if deemed appropriate in her or his discretion. 
    Obstruction permit fee means money paid to the city by a permittee to cover the costs as provided in section 51-37. 
    Patch or patching means a method of pavement replacement that is temporary in nature. A patch consists of (1) the compaction of the subbase and aggregate base; and (2) the replacement, in kind, of the existing pavement for a minimum of two feet beyond the edges of the excavation in all directions. 
    Pavement means any type of improved surface that is within the public right-of-way and that is paved or otherwise constructed with paver blocks, bituminous, concrete, aggregate, or gravel. 
    Permit has the meaning given "right-of-way permit" in M.S.A. § 237.162. 
    Permittee means any person to whom a permit to excavate or obstruct a right-of-way has been granted by the city under this Section. 
    Person means an individual or entity subject to the laws and rules of this state, however organized, whether public or private, whether domestic or foreign, whether for profit or nonprofit, and whether natural, corporate, or political. 
    Public right-of-way or right-of-way has the meaning given it in M.S.A. § 237.162, Subd. 3. 
    Registrant means any person who (1) has or seeks to have its equipment or facilities located in any right-of-way, or (2) in any way occupies or uses, or seeks to occupy or use, the right-of-way or place its facilities or equipment in the right-of-way. 
    Restore or restoration means the process by which an excavated right-of-way and surrounding area, including pavement and foundation, is returned to the same condition and life expectancy that existed before excavation. 
    Right-of-way permit means either the utility permit or the obstruction permit, or both, depending on the context, required by this article. 
    Right-of-way user means: 
(1)  A telecommunications right-of-way user as defined by M.S.A. § 237.162, Subd. 4; or 
(2)  A person owning or controlling a facility in the right-of-way that is used or intended to be used for providing utility service, and who has a right under law, franchise, or ordinance to use the public right-of-way. 
    Service or utility service means and includes: 
(1)  Services provided by a public utility as defined in M.S.A. § 216B.02, Subds. 4 and 6; 
(2)  Services of a telecommunications right-of-way user, including transporting of voice or data information; 
(3)  Services of a cable communications system as defined in M.S.A. ch. 238.02, Subd. 3; 
(4)  Natural gas or electric energy or telecommunications services provided by a local government unit; 
(5)  Services provided by a cooperative electric association organized under M.S.A. ch. 308A; and 
(6)  Water, sewer, steam, cooling or heating services. 
    Small wireless facility means a wireless facility that meets both of the following qualifications: 
(1)  Each antenna is located inside an enclosure of no more than six cubic feet in volume or could fit within such an enclosure; and 
(2)  All other wireless equipment associated with the small wireless facility provided such equipment is, in aggregate, no more than 28 cubic feet in volume, not including electric meters, concealment elements, telecommunications demarcation boxes, battery backup power systems, grounding equipment, power transfer switches, cutoff switches, cable, conduit, vertical cable runs for the connection of power and other services, and any equipment concealed from public view within or behind an existing structure or concealment. 
    Supplementary application means an application made to excavate or obstruct more of the right-of-way than allowed in, or to extend, a permit that had already been issued. 
    Temporary surface means the compaction of subbase and aggregate base and replacement, in kind, of the existing pavement only to the edges of the excavation. 
    Trench means an excavation in the right-of-way, with the excavation having a length equal to or greater than the width of the pavement or adjacent pavement. 
    Telecommunication right-of-way user means a person owning or controlling a facility in the right-of-way, or seeking to own or control a facility in the right-of-way, that is used or is intended to be used for transporting telecommunication or other voice or data information. For purposes of this section, a cable communication system defined and regulated under M.S.A. ch. 238, and telecommunication activities related to providing natural gas or electric energy services whether provided by a public utility as defined in M.S.A. § 216B.02, a municipality, a municipal gas or power agency organized under M.S.A. chs. 453 and 453A, or a cooperative electric association organized under M.S.A. ch. 308A, are not telecommunications right-of-way users. 
    Utility permit means the permit which, pursuant to this section, must be obtained before a person may excavate in a right-of-way. A utility permit allows the holder to excavate that part of the right-of-way described in such permit. 
    Utility permit fee means money paid to the city by an applicant to cover the costs as provided in section 51-37. 
    Utility pole means a pole that is used in whole or in part to facilitate telecommunications or electric service. 
    Wireless support structure means a new or existing structure in a right-of-way designed to support or capable of supporting small wireless facilities, as reasonably determined by the city. 
(Ord. No. 301, § 1, 6-26-07; Ord. No. 408, § 1, 5-8-18) 
Sec. 51-29. - Administration. 
    The director is the principal city official responsible for the administration of the rights-of-way, right-of-way permits, and the ordinances related thereto. The director may delegate any or all of the duties hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 301, § 1, 6-26-07) 
Sec. 51-30. - Utility coordination committee. 
    The city may create an advisory utility coordination committee. Participation on the committee is voluntary. It will be composed of any registrants that wish to assist the city in obtaining information and by making recommendations regarding use of the right-of-way, and to improve the process of performing construction work therein. The city may determine the size of such committee and shall appoint members from a list of registrants that have expressed a desire to assist the city. 
(Ord. No. 301, § 1, 6-26-07) 
Sec. 51-31. - Registration and right-of-way occupancy. 
(a)  Registration. Each person who occupies, uses, or seeks to occupy or use, the right-of-way or place any equipment or facilities in or on the right-of-way, including persons with installation and maintenance responsibilities by lease, sublease or assignment, must register with the city. Registration will consist of providing application information, designating the local representative and paying the registration fee. Registration shall be renewed by the first of each calendar year or prior to applying for the first permit of a calendar year.
