(b)  Minor subdivisions. Any subdivision of land creating not more than three lots in which the lots created conform with all of the following requirements may be considered a minor subdivision: 
(1)  The subdivision meets the zoning ordinance requirements for frontage on an existing road. 
(2)  The subdivision does not require the construction of any new public facilities or improvements, including buffers, but excluding parks or trails. 
(3)  The subdivision complies with the comprehensive plan, zoning ordinance, and official map. 
(4)  The subdivision does not appear to circumvent the requirements of this chapter. 
(5)  Any land subdivision that creates one new lot shall be platted and the final plat recorded with the county recorder. 
(c)  Minor subdivision procedure. The owner or developer shall file with the platting officer five copies of a plat or survey of the land to be subdivided by a licensed land surveyor if the land is to be described by metes and bounds or for the purpose of a minor boundary adjustment in accordance with this section, along with a completed application, the required fees, and an up-to-date abstract, registered property report, or such other evidence required by the city attorney and/or platting officer to show that the applicant has sufficient ownership or control of the land to make application. The application shall be considered officially filed when the platting officer has determined that the application is complete and other required documents are attached to the application. 
(d)  Procedure for approval/denial. Within a reasonable time after the platting officer has determined that the application is complete, the platting officer shall: 
(1)  Review the documents demonstrating ownership or control or refer the documents to the city attorney for review. 
(2)  Refer copies of the plat to the city engineer and other staff, boards, committees, or outside agencies, as appropriate, and to the affected municipal or private utility companies. 
(3)  Provided no objection is received, the platting officer may approve the minor subdivision. Following receipt of unfavorable review reports, the platting officer may refer the subdivision request to the planning commission and city council in such manner as prescribed for major subdivisions. 
(e)  Qualifications governing approval of minor subdivisions. Any subdivision plat approved pursuant to this section shall conform with the Carver County Manual of Standard Procedures: Subdivision Plats and Registered Land Surveys. 
(f)  Minor boundary adjustments. The relocation of the boundary lines between two existing abutting parcels shall be considered a minor subdivision provided such relocation shall not cause the creation of a new parcel or parcels and such parcels comply with the zoning ordinance. The platting officer may approve minor boundary adjustments. Surveys for both amended parcels shall be required. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02; Ord. No. 249, § 2, 8-26-03) 
Sec. 52-47. - Copies of recorded deeds (minor subdivisions). 
    Whenever deeds are recorded instead of a plat, the developer shall, immediately upon receipt of the recorded deeds from the county recorder or certificate of title from the registrar of titles, provide copies thereof to the platting officer for verification of the recording of the documents. No building permits shall be issued prior to the city receiving evidence of the recording of deeds. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02) 
Secs. 52-48-52-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SKETCH PLAN[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 249, § 3, adopted Aug. 26, 2003, amended div. 3 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former div. 3, §§ 52-61-52-80, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 230, adopted June 11, 2002. 

Sec. 52-61. - Sketch plan; generally. 
(a)  Developers shall prepare for review with the planning commission, city engineer, city planner and others a sketch plan depicting the proposed subdivision. The sketch plan and any accompanying information shall serve as a basis for discussion between the developer and the city and is intended to provide a developer with an advisory review. 
(b)  A land planner or landscape architect shall develop the sketch plan to maximize existing conditions (including but not limited to vegetation, topography, natural resources, etc.), minimize adverse impacts on adjacent properties, while enhancing pedestrian and vehicular access and creating a cohesive, aesthetically pleasing, inviting, and attractive environment. Upon approval of the sketch plan, a licensed engineer shall prepare the approved design for later stages. 
(c)  All applicable ordinances and regulations shall be addressed after the approval of a sketch plan, but prior to the acceptance of a preliminary plat. 
(d)  The sketch plan shall contain the following information: 
(1)  A site location map showing major streets, parks, community facilities and other significant developments. 
(2)  Tract boundaries. 
(3)  North point and scale. 
(4)  Topography and physical features, including lakes, ponds, wetlands and wooded areas. 
(5)  Proposed uses, including park and open space. 
(6)  Streets within and adjacent to the tract. 
(7)  Proposed general street design. 
(8)  Proposed lot size and orientation. 
(9)  Proposed zoning change, if any. 
(e)  Submission of such sketch plan shall not constitute formal filing of a preliminary plat. The planning commission will, on the basis of such sketch plan, unofficially advise the developer of the extent to which the proposed subdivision conforms to this chapter and will discuss possible modifications. The city council may also review the sketch plan. 
(f)  Following review of the sketch plan, the city council may cause the engineer to prepare a feasibility study for extension or improvement of public utilities, including water, sewer, storm, streets and trails. 
(Ord. No. 249, § 3, 8-26-03) 
Secs. 52-62-52-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PRELIMINARY PLAT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 249, §§ 4 and 6, adopted Aug. 26, 2003, amended div. 4 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former div. 4, §§ 52-81-52-100, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 230, adopted June 11, 2002. 

Sec. 52-81. - Preliminary plat; generally. 
    Property shall be platted to augment existing topography vegetation, etc. and shall be consistent with the prepared sketch plan, comprehensive plan, and prepared master plan. A preliminary plat shall be prepared and reviewed as follows: 
(1)  Application. The application for preliminary plat approval shall be on forms prescribed by the city and shall be accompanied by copies of the preliminary plat in such number as required by the city. The applicant shall pay the application fee and an escrow deposit established by city council resolution from time to time. The escrow deposit shall be used throughout the complete subdivision process to reimburse costs or expenses incurred by the city and can only be waived or decreased by the city council. All required data, documentation plans, copies and fees must be submitted before the application will be considered complete. Rejection of the plat by the city council, or abandonment or withdrawal of the proposed plat by the developer, shall not entitle the applicant to a return of all or any part of the application fee. 
(2)  Content. The application shall include, but is not limited to: 
a.  Evidence of ownership or interest in the property. 
b.  Application fee as determined from time to time by the city council. 
c.  Completed application forms. Developer shall provide all information as required on the development application. 
(3)  Public hearing. The planning commission shall hold a public hearing on the preliminary plat after notice of the date, time, place and purpose of the hearing has been published once in the official newspaper at least ten days prior to the hearing. Written notice shall also be mailed by the city to the applicant and all owners of record within 350 feet of the outer boundaries of the preliminary plat. Failure to give notice or defects in the notice shall not affect the validity of the proceedings. 
(4)  Planning commission review. The planning commission shall make a recommendation on the preliminary plat to the city council. The planning commission may recommend approval, approval subject to conditions or that the preliminary plat be denied. If denial is recommended, the reasons for that recommendation shall be stated in the record. The preliminary plat review by the planning commission and city council shall include review of the provisions of adequate public facilities, including school facilities, traffic impacts to the streets and trails, water, sewer systems. 
(5)  City council review. Following action by the planning commission, the city council shall consider the preliminary plat. The city council shall make its decision within 120 days following receipt by the city of the properly completed application, unless the developer consents in writing to a continuance. 
(6)  Findings of approval-Preliminary and final plat. The findings necessary for city council approval of the preliminary plat and the final plat shall be as follows: 
a.  The proposed subdivision is consistent with the zoning ordinance and all other applicable ordinances; 
b.  The proposed subdivision is consistent with all applicable city, county and regional plans including but not limited to the city's comprehensive plan and master plan for the area; 
c.  The physical characteristics of the site, including but not limited to topography, soils, vegetation, susceptibility to erosion and siltation, susceptibility to flooding, and stormwater drainage are suitable for the proposed development; 
d.  The proposed subdivision makes adequate provision for water supply, storm drainage, sewage disposal, streets, erosion control and all other improvements required by this chapter; 
e.  The proposed subdivision will not conflict with easements of record; 
f.  The proposed subdivision is not premature. A subdivision is premature if any of the following exists: 
1.  Lack of adequate stormwater drainage; 
2.  Lack of dedicated and improved public streets; 
3.  Lack of adequate sanitary sewer systems; 
4.  Lack of adequate off-site public improvements or support systems. 
(7)  Duration. Approval of a preliminary plat shall expire one year after the date of approval unless the developer has filed a completed application for approval of the final plat or has received an extension from the city council. An extension shall be granted only if good cause is shown by the applicant, and if there has been no change in any land use control or comprehensive plan affecting the use, development density, lot size, lot layout, dedication or platting requirements since the approval of the preliminary plat, and the city council determines that it is in the best interest of the city to grant an extension. The duration of an extension shall be determined by the city council and shall begin from the date of expiration of the preliminary plat. 
(Ord. No. 249, § 5, 8-26-03; Ord. No. 330, § 1, 11-10-08) 
Sec. 52-82. - Site plan (where required). 
    In areas where development proposals require site plan approval as prescribed in article VIII of the Watertown Zoning Code, such procedures shall be followed as prescribed. 
(Ord. No. 249, § 6, 8-26-03) 
Sec. 52-83. - Annexation. 
(a)  Joint resolution. If deemed appropriate the city council may accept a request for annexation using the following procedures: 
(1)  Township discussion. The property owner shall make an informal request to the township board regarding annexation of the land. Annexation should follow staging as identified in the Watertown Comprehensive Plan. 
(2)  Council discussion. Following informal review of the request by the township board and receipt of recommendation from the board, the city council may review the request. If the city council deems necessary, the council shall direct the city attorney to draft a joint resolution for annexation, to be adopted by both the city and the township. 
(b)  Other methods. The city may annex land pursuant to other provisions of M.S.A. ch. 414. 
(Ord. No. 249, § 6, 8-26-03) 
Sec. 52-84. - Rezoning. 
    Following annexation the city council may rezone property consistent with the comprehensive and master plans of the city following procedures outlined in section 62-165 of the zoning code. 
(Ord. No. 249, § 6, 8-26-03) 
Secs. 52-85-52-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - FINAL PLAT 

Sec. 52-101. - Generally. 
(a)  The final plat shall be prepared by a licensed land surveyor who is registered in this state and shall conform to the requirements of this chapter and state law. 
(b)  The final plat will have incorporated all modifications required by the city council and in all other aspects shall conform with the preliminary plat. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 52-102. - Procedures. 
(a)  Generally. 
(1)  Unless otherwise provided in the development contract for phased development, within one year after the date of the city council approval of the preliminary plat, the developer shall file an application for approval of the final plat. In addition to the application the developer shall submit: 
a.  Copies of the plat in such quantities as required by the city. 
b.  Two mylar copies of the plat. 
c.  One 200-scale copy of the plat. 
(2)  Termination. If the final plat application is not filed within this period, the preliminary plat will be considered void unless for good cause shown an extension is requested in writing by the developer and granted by the city council. 
(b)  Planning commission review. The planning commission shall make a recommendation on the preliminary plat to the city council. The planning commission may recommend approval, approval subject to conditions or that the preliminary plat be denied. If denial is recommended, the reasons for that recommendation shall be stated in the record. 
(c)  City council review. The city council shall review the final plat and shall approve or disapprove the plat following recommendation from the planning commission. 
(d)  Acceptable form. No final plat shall be approved by the city council until the plat is in a form acceptable for recording with the county, the proper filing fees have been paid to the city, a development agreement has been signed, appropriate security has been furnished, and no other payments to the city related to the development are outstanding. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 52-103. - Development agreement. 
    Before the city signs a final plat and before the developer constructs any improvements, the developer shall enter into a development agreement with the city. The agreement shall delineate the conditions under which approval is granted. The city council shall approve the development agreement by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 52-104. - Recording. 
    If the final plat is approved, the developer shall record the plat in the Office of the Carver County Recorder/Registrar of Titles within 45 days after the date of approval and furnish the city evidence of the recording; otherwise the approval of the subdivision shall be considered null and void. No building permits shall be issued until evidence of recording the plat is received. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 52-105. - Reproducible mylar print copy and blue line print to city. 
    The developer shall, immediately upon recording, furnish the city with a reproducible mylar copy and one blue line print of the final plat or survey. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 52-106. - Duration. 
    Approval of a final plat submitted under this division shall expire one year after the date of approval unless construction has commenced in accordance with the plan, or an extension is granted by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02) 
Secs. 52-107-52-125. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DESIGN STANDARDS 
DIVISION 1. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 52-126. - Generally. 
    All developments within the jurisdictional limits of the City of Watertown shall conform to the engineering and building standards as adopted by the city. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 52-127. - Streets. 
(a)  Dedication. Streets shall be dedicated on the plat to the public. The location and design of streets shall consider existing and planned streets, accommodate anticipated traffic circulation, topography conditions, runoff or stormwater, public convenience and safety and the proposed land uses of property to be served. 
(b)  Right-of-way. 
(1)  Street right-of-way width shall be consistent with the comprehensive plan and official map, and shall conform to county and state standards for trunk highways. If no such plans or standards are applicable, right-of-way widths shall not be less than the following: 
Street Classifications Right-of-Way Width (feet) Pavement Width (feet) Measr'd from back of curb Arterial 100 36 to 44 Parkway 80 42 (outside to outside minimum) Local Collector 80 36 Local Street 60 28-32 Cul-de-sac diameter 195 32  
(2)  Right-of-way width may be increased to provide additional parking, traffic calming, etc. as is necessary to promote the health, safety, and general welfare. 
(3)  The use of landscaped center islands within cul-de-sac bulbs and traffic calming islands is encouraged. Such islands shall be placed so as to provide adequate emergency and maintenance access. 
(c)  Intersections. Streets shall intersect at right angles. In no case shall the angle formed by the intersection of two streets be less than 60 degrees. Intersections having more than four entering street segments are prohibited. 
(d)  Centerline grades. All centerline grades shall be at least five-tenths (.05) percent and shall not exceed five percent for arterials and seven percent for all other streets and alleys. Whenever possible, grades within 30 feet of intersections or railroad crossings shall not exceed three percent. 
(e)  Access, arterial/collector streets. Where a proposed residential subdivision is adjacent to an arterial or collector street, there shall be no direct vehicular access from individual lots to such arterial or collector streets. Access to arterial streets shall be at intervals of not less than 1/4 mile and through existing and established crossroads. Access along collector streets will be restricted and controlled on the final plat. 
    Access to commercial or industrial subdivisions shall be provided to maximize safe efficient travel within and adjacent to the subdivision. 
(f)  Half streets. Half streets shall not be approved. 
(g)  Private streets. Private streets shall not be approved. 
(h)  Cul-de-sacs. The use of cul-de-sacs is discouraged except, where to further the intent of this chapter, cul-de-sacs are appropriate due to existing topography, vegetation, etc. In no case shall a street ending in a cul-de-sac exceed 300 feet. Where a cul-de-sac is deemed appropriate, such cul-de-sac right -of-way shall include the following: 
(1)  Fifteen feet of right-of-way boulevard area; 
(2)  Thirty-two-foot wide street (back of curb to back of curb); 
(3)  One hundred-foot diameter circle landscaped island. Such island may be teardrop shaped to correspond to traffic patterns. 
(i)  Street jogs. Street jogs with centerline off sets of less than 125 feet shall be prohibited. Greater offsets may be required for collector and arterial streets to accommodate turn lanes. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02; Ord. No. 249, §§ 7, 8, 8-26-03) 
Sec. 52-128. - Arrangement of streets. 
    The arrangement of streets in new subdivisions or plats shall be laid out so as to provide a continuation of existing streets of adjoining areas, whether in the city or in adjoining governmental subdivisions or the projection of east-west or north-south streets of the city if there are no adjoining streets. The width of the streets in new subdivisions shall not be less than the minimum street width established herein. Offset or irregular streets are prohibited. Streets shall be extended to the subdivision property line where required. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 52-129. - Street signs. 
    Streets signs of a standard design approved by the city shall be installed at each intersection. Regulatory (no parking, stop, yield, etc.) signs shall be installed as required prior to issuance of a building permit. Such funds as are necessary to complete the signage shall be included in the subdivision security requirements. This requirement shall not apply for those lots identified as model homes in the development agreement. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 52-130. - Sub-base, grading. 
    Every street shall have adequate sub-base and shall be improved with a bituminous or concrete surface in accordance with the design standards specified by the city. Except in areas where topography or tree cover dictate otherwise, grading shall provide for installation of sidewalks. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 52-131. - Alleys. 
    Alleys may be required in blocks greater than 900 feet in length. Alley rights-of-way and pavement width shall conform to the following minimum standards: 
Classification Right-of-way (in feet) Pavement (in feet) Residential (two-way) 20 16.5  
    The city council may reduce the width of the alley right-of-way or pavement width. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 52-132. - Blocks. 
    The length and width of blocks shall be sufficient to provide a convenient and safe access, circulation, control and street design. Blocks shall not be longer than 1,800 feet, or shorter than 300 feet except where topography of surrounding development limits the ability to strictly comply or as specifically approved by the city council to foster innovative design consistent with sound planning principles. Pedestrian ways may be required on blocks longer than 900 feet or in other areas to provide access to schools, parks and other destination points. Easements for pedestrian ways shall be at least 20 feet wide and shall be located to minimize intersections with streets. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 52-133. - Lots. 
(a)  All lots shall abut a publicly dedicated street for their full required minimum frontage as required by the zoning ordinance. 
(b)  Side lines of lots shall be substantially at right angles to straight street lines or substantially radial to curved streets. 
(c)  Lots shall be graded to drain away from building locations. 
(d)  Lots shall be placed to preserve and protect natural amenities, such as vegetation, wetlands, steep slopes, water courses, and historic areas. 
(e)  Lot remnants are prohibited. 
(f)  Street arrangements for the proposed subdivision shall not cause undue hardship to owners of adjoining property in subdividing their own land. 
(g)  Lot layouts should take into consideration the potential use of solar energy design features. 
(h)  Driveway slope shall be a minimum of 1/2 percent and a maximum grade of ten percent. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 52-134. - Trail, access and conservation easement. 
    Where any proposed plat adjoins a lake, wetland, pond, river or stream, including streams that flow only intermittently, the city may require that a strip of land running along all sides thereof that are contiguous to such lake, wetland, pond, river or stream, be dedicated to the city for public use, or subject to a perpetual easement in favor of the city for purpose of protecting its hydraulic efficiency and natural character and beauty. There shall also be granted to the city the right of ingress and egress from the dedicated land. Conservation easements may also be utilized along buffer areas as required by this section. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02; Ord. No. 249, § 9, 8-26-03) 
Sec. 52-135. - Trails. 
(a)  Width. Trail width shall be eight feet unless otherwise required by the city council 
(b)  Material. Trails shall be constructed of bituminous or concrete material in accordance with the design standards as adopted by the city. 
(c)  Lighting. The city may require accent or security lighting. Such lighting shall be in a form and style approved by the city council. 
(d)  Landscaping. Trails shall be located within easements or dedicated right-of-way. Trail improvements shall provide definition to discourage trespassing onto private property. Such definition may include open fencing, landscaping, and/or berms. One overstory or one evergreen tree shall be installed for each 40 feet of trail length. Such trees may be grouped. Tree sizes shall be a minimum caliper of 2-1/2 inches for overstory shade trees or six feet in height for evergreen trees. Berming and lot grading shall not direct surface drainage over the trail surface. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 52-136. - Water supply. 
    Water mains shall be extended to the subdivision property lines as may be required by the city and all necessary fire hydrants shall be provided. Extensions of the public water supply systems shall be designed to provide public water service to each lot with the minimum distance necessary and shall be in accordance with applicable city requirements. Water mains shall be routed so as to provide a loop of the city water system, promoting the water quality and fire safety. Fire hydrants shall be provided as required in the uniform fire code. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 52-137. - Sanitary sewer. 
    Public sanitary sewer main and service connections shall be approved by the city engineer and installed to serve all lots in the subdivision. Lot service connections shall be the minimum distance necessary. Service cleanouts and inspection manholes shall be provided as directed by the city. Sanitary sewer mains shall be extended to the subdivision property line as may be required by the city. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 52-138. - Storm drainage. 
    A system that will adequately accommodate surface water runoff within the subdivision shall be provided. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 52-139. - Stormwater detention. 
    The surface water discharge rate from the subdivision is to be retained at the predevelopment rate for a 100-year, 24-hour storm event through the use of surface water detention/retention facilities or other appropriate means as approved by the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 52-140. - Other utilities. 
    All utility lines, including those for telephone and electrical service, shall be placed underground. Utility lines, to the extent practical, shall be located in the rear yards. In areas where topography or vegetative conditions restrict, utility boxes shall be located no closer to the street than the building setback lines for that district. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 52-141. - Sediment and erosion control. 
    It is the policy of the city to control soil erosion and sedimentation caused as the result of development activities within the city. A minimum of six inches of topsoil shall be placed on all disturbed areas prior to issuance of a certificate of occupancy. 
(1)  Generally. 
a.  Erosion control plans shall be submitted for review and approval at the time of development plan review. 
b.  Development shall be related to the topography and soils of the site so as to create the least potential for soil erosion. Areas of steep slopes and where high cuts and fills may be required should be avoided wherever possible, and natural contours should be followed as closely as possible. 
c.  Natural vegetation should be retained and protected wherever possible. Areas immediately adjacent to natural watercourses and wetlands should be left undisturbed whenever possible. 
d.  Disturbed areas shall be stabilized no more than five days following grade determination. Disturbed areas in drainage ways or concentrated flow areas shall be stabilized no more than 72 hours following grade determination. 
e.  Sediment basins, debris basins, silt traps or filters must be installed and maintained to eliminate sediment run-off. 
f.  In the design of erosion control measures, the requirements of continuing maintenance shall be considered. 
g.  Drainage ways shall be designed so that final gradients and velocities will not create additional erosion. 
h.  Erosion and sediment controls may include, but are not limited to the following components: 
Silt fencing, gravel drives, straw mulch, vegetation, sediment basins, rock check dams, regular street sweeping. 
(2)  Maintenance. Soil erosion control shall be installed prior to issuance of a building permit Erosion control systems shall be maintained at all times. To guarantee maintenance of erosion control systems, the developer shall provide escrow funds or letter of credit in an amount determined from time to time by the city council. 
    Following an erosion event, i.e. rainfall, wind storm; the erosion control measures shall be inspected by the property owner. Erosion control measures shall be maintained as necessary, or within 48 hours following notification of maintenance requirements. 
    Such erosion control measures not employed or functional following such notification shall constitute a misdemeanor and may result in the use of the escrow funds, and or the issuance of a stop work order. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02) 
Division 2. - TREE PRESERVATION[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 305, § 1, adopted May 22, 2007, repealed § 52-142 in its entirety and added new provisions to read as herein set out. In keeping with the numbering style of the Code, these provisions have been set out as Art. III, Div. 2, §§ 52-142-52-148, and renumbered §§ 52-143, 52-144 as §§ 52-149, 52-150, at the discretion of the editor. Former Art. II, § 52-142, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from 0rd. No. 230, adopted Jun. 11, 2002 and Ord. No. 249, § 10, adopted Aug. 26, 2003. 

Sec. 52-142. - Tree preservation requirements. 
(a)  Policy. It is the policy of the city to preserve natural landscaping and woodland areas throughout the city. All efforts shall occur in the architectural layout and site design of a proposed development to preserve existing trees, most especially mature trees, specimen trees, tree groves, and tree lines. It is therefore the purpose of this section to provide regulations related to the cutting, removal, or killing of trees on construction and development sites and to ensure the protection and preservation of the natural environment and the beauty of [the City of] Watertown. 
(b)  Clear cutting. No clear cutting of land shall be permitted except as approved by the city council as part of an approved development plan. 
(c)  Evaluation standards. The following standards shall be used in evaluating subdivisions and development plans: 
(1)  To the extent practical, site design shall preserve woodland areas and significant trees. Special priority for tree preservation shall be given to areas within floodplains, wetlands, stream corridors, wooded slopes, and along collector and arterial roadway corridors. 
(2)  Minimizing tree loss should be achieved by any combination of the following: 
a.  Realignment of streets, utilities and lot lines. 
b.  Consideration of alternative utility configurations such as the use of ejector pumps, force mains, or revised home elevations to minimize grading. 
c.  An increase in street grade up to ten percent when the applicant can demonstrate that significant trees preservation is directly related to the modification. 
d.  Variation in street radius and design speed. 
e.  Modified grading plans. 
(Ord. No. 305, § 1, 5-22-07) 
Sec. 52-143. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Caliper inches. See Stem caliper 
    Critical root zone of a tree means the area of a circle around a significant tree with a radius that is equal to 1.5 feet for every inch in stem diameter. 
    Developer means the developer, subdivider, owner of the land or person who is applying for tree removal and who does not meet the definition of a homeowner. 
    Diameter at breast height (DBH) The diameter of a tree measured at four and one-half feet above the existing grade (or circumference divided by pi). Diameter at breast height or DBH is used in reference to established plantings in the field. Trees that branch below one foot will be considered to have multiple stems and the diameter of the tree will equal the sum of the diameters of each stem. 
    High tree density means a parcel of land containing six or more total caliper inches of significant trees per 1,000 square feet of land. 
    Homeowner means the owner or owner's agent of a single family house, duplex, or lot which was previously subdivided by a previous owner pursuant to Chapter 28 of the City of Watertown Municipal Code. 
    Homeowner significant tree means any deciduous or coniferous tree measuring ten caliper inches or greater in diameter (DBH) or greater which is not dead or actively infected with oak wilt or Dutch elm disease. 
    Low tree density means a parcel of land containing less than six total caliper inches of significant trees per 1,000 square feet of land. 
    Replacement tree means a tree planted as part of the tree replacement plan, which must be at least three caliper inches measured 12 inches from the ground and which otherwise meets the requirements of this section, except bur oak, swamp white oak, pagoda dogwood, ironwood and similar trees accepted by the city which may be two caliper inches. A coniferous tree seven feet high will meet the three minimum caliper inches required. (See exceptions for steep slopes.) 
    Developer significant tree means any deciduous or coniferous tree measuring six caliper inches in diameter (DBH) or greater which is not dead or actively infected with oak wilt or dutch elm disease, except bur oak, swamp white oak, red maple, sugar maple, black maple, pagoda dogwood, ironwood and similar trees designated by the city shall be considered significant at four caliper inches in diameter or greater. 
    Stem caliper means the diameter of a tree measured at six inches above the ground for stems less than or equal to four inches and at 12 inches for stems greater than four inches in diameter. 
    Tree removal means any excavating, grading, clearing, filling or other earth change or any cutting, which may result in removal or killing of more than ten percent of the significant tree caliper inches on any land within any period of five years. 
    Tree trunk means the stem portion of a tree from the ground to the first branch thereof. Any term used in this division and not defined in this section shall have the meaning as otherwise defined in this Code. 
Sec. 52-144. - Permit required. 
(a)  Required. It is unlawful for a homeowner to use land for, or to engage directly or indirectly in, tree removal of a significant tree unless the homeowner shall first have applied for and obtained from the city, in the manner provided in this section, a permit authorizing tree removal. Provided, however, that no permit shall be required by a homeowner for removal of a tree that was damaged due to a natural disaster or for excavation in conjunction with a building: 
(1)  For which there has been issued an appropriate building permit; and 
(2)  Which is to be constructed: 
a.  Upon land for which a permit for tree removal under this division has previously been issued; and 
b.  In accordance with such permit. 
(b)  Failure to obtain. Failure to obtain a permit shall be cause to deny issuance of a building permit, prohibiting continuation of any construction of the property, connection or extension of any utilities on the property or on any adjacent streets, issuance of a certificate of occupancy and to require remedial action in accordance with the tree replacement table to replace significant trees lost or expected to be lost as a result of activity on the site. 
(c)  Application. Application for a tree removal and replacement permit shall be made in writing using the form provided by the city. The application shall include: 
(1)  The name, address and signed concurrence from the owner of land. 
(2)  Using a current survey at a suitable scale of the property, include: 
a.  The existing and proposed buildings and structures on the site; 
b.  The location, size and type (species) of all significant trees on the property; 
c.  The location, size and type (species) of all significant trees proposed to be removed/lost; and 
d.  Location and type of protection measures used to prevent damage to the critical root zone of significant trees to be protected. 
Significant trees shall be considered lost as a result of grade change, including grading or filling, whether temporary or permanent, affecting 55 percent or more of the tree's critical root zone; cutting of 45 percent or more of the tree's roots within the critical root zone; mechanical injury to the trunk causing loss of more than 40 percent of the circumference of any portion of the tree bark; compaction to a depth of six inches or more of 45 percent or more of the surface of the soil within a significant tree's critical root zone. 
(3)  Trees designated for preservation shall be protected by snow fence (see tree protection fence diagram) or other means acceptable to the city. The protective measures must protect at least the entire root zone of the trees. 
(4)  The estimated period of time within which the tree replacement will be conducted. 
(c)  Replacement required. Tree replacement for homeowners shall be in accordance with the provisions established within section 52-142.5 unless subject to one of the following: 
(1)  Trees to be removed are diseased or dying. 
(Ord. No. 305, § 1, 5-22-07) 
Sec. 52-145. - Tree inventory. 
    A tree inventory shall be required to be submitted as a part of a preliminary plat submittal or as a part of the site plan review submittal to the city. The developer shall have a tree inventory prepared by a certified registered land surveyor, landscape architect or forester depicting: 
(a)  The size, species, condition and location on the land of all significant trees. On large wooded sites, forest mensuration methods may be used to determine the total diameter inches of trees on the property. 
(b)  Significant trees which will be lost due to the proposed activities. Significant trees shall be considered lost as a result of: 
(1)  Grade change, including grading or filling, whether temporary or permanent, affecting 55 percent or more of the tree's critical root zone. 
(2)  Utility construction (i.e., sewer, water, storm sewer, gas, electric, telephone, cable TV, fiber optics or similar facilities) resulting in the cutting of 45 percent or more of the tree's roots within the critical root zone. 
(3)  Mechanical injury to the trunk of a significant tree causing loss of more than 40 percent of the circumference of any portion of the trunk bark. 
(4)  Compaction to a depth of six inches or more of 45 percent or more of the surface of the soil within a significant tree's critical root zone. 
(c)  The location, number, type and size of replacement trees required to be replaced pursuant to this division. 
(Ord. No. 305, § 1, 5-22-07) 
Sec. 52-146. - Tree preservation, protection and replacement. 
(a)  Tree preservation. Trees designated for preservation shall be protected by snow fence or other means acceptable to the city. The protective measures must protect the entire critical root zone of the trees, unless less protection is necessary due to the proximity of a structure, road or similar obstruction to be a part of the development, in which case at least 55 percent of the critical root zone of the tree must be protected. 
(b)  Developer required to replace lost trees. A developer shall replace live significant trees lost or reasonably anticipated to be lost as a result of grading, building upon or any other alteration of the land immediately or in the future, by the developer, developer's agent or subcontractor by planting that number of trees ("replacement trees") determined in accordance with the tree replacement table in addition to boulevard trees or others as required by chapter 28 of the city Code. 
(c)  Tree replacement table. The following table identifies the required amount of tree replacement.

(d)  Location of replacement trees. Replacement trees shall be planted: 
(1)  On the site based on the proposed use with special consideration to restoration areas including steep slopes, common areas, buffer zones between different land uses and/or activities and project entrance areas. 
(e)  Sizes and types of replacement trees. Replacement trees must be no less than the following sizes:

Sec. 52-147. - Site plan approval required. 
    Site Plan approval shall be required in accordance with section 62-611 through 62-622 of the Municipal Code of Watertown. 
(Ord. No. 305, § 1, 5-22-07) 
Sec. 52-148. - Tree protection. 
(a)  Tree protection. Tree protection fencing shall be noted on engineering and site plans. Fencing shall be located at the limits of construction area. (NOTE: It may not always be outside of the critical root zone). 
(1)  The installation of fencing shall be in accordance with city requirements. The fence shall consist of and be installed in accordance with the tree protection fence diagram. All tree protection fencing shall be in addition to erosion control fence where the two overlap. The tree protection fence shall be installed on the tree side of the erosion control fence. Erosion control fence, in conjunction with tree protection fencing, must not be trenched into the ground. An alternative city approved method may be utilized. At a minimum, signs which are legible at ten feet shall be posted and maintained at intervals no less than 30 feet which clearly state "Tree Save Area. Do not enter. Do not move or alter fence. Violation subject to fine and work stoppage". The city may, at its option, install the fencing utilizing funds deposited with the city by the developer for that purpose. All tree protection fencing must be installed and maintained prior to any construction as approved by the city as part of the approval process. In no case shall tree protection fencing be removed, breached, temporarily removed, altered, or relocated without written authorization from the city. 
(2)  The removal, temporary removal, alteration, or relocation of an installed tree protection fence without written authorization from the city shall incur a penalty of $100.00 per occurrence. The developer and/or builder shall be responsible for paying this penalty. 
(3)  Entering a tree protection area that was required to be fenced shall result in an additional penalty of $50.00 per diameter inch for any tree that is damaged in the opinion of the city, including, but not limited to, grading, trenching, limb or bark removal, storage of materials or parking of vehicles. The cost of any necessary remedial tree care action, in the opinion of the city, shall be the responsibility of the developer and/or builder. 

Tree Protection Fence Diagram 
(Ord. No. 305, § 1, 5-22-07) 
Sec. 52-149. - Landscaping. 
    Landscaping shall be as provided in the landscaping chapter of the Watertown Municipal Code. 
All required trees shall be installed prior to receiving a certificate of occupancy. If it is determined that permitting occupancy prior to completion and acceptance of required improvements is in the best interest of the city, financial guarantees acceptable to the city shall be provided to ensure timely installation. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02) 
Cross reference- Landscaping, ch. 28. 
Note- See editor's note for Art III, Div. 2. 
Sec. 52-150. - Wetland protection. 
    It is the purpose of this section to preserve and protect the natural amenities, including vistas, timber areas, flood ways and wetlands in and adjacent to watertown. it is important to the community's character that these areas be retained as public amenities in perpetuity. 
(1)  No subdivision of land shall occur which creates a lot extending into a delineated wetland. 
(2)  A buffer of no less than that currently required by watershed district shall completely surround a wetland. Such buffer shall remain free from development, including grading, filling, excavation, and accessory structure construction. The buffer shall protect the wetland from inadvertent encroachments due to soil, water erosion, public and private development. 
(3)  For all buildings and structures, accessory and otherwise, a minimum setback of 50 feet shall be maintained from the delineated edge of the wetland. 
(4)  No subdivision of land shall occur which creates a lot extending into a delineated floodway. 
(Ord. No. 249, 11, 8-26-03; Ord. No. 305, § 1, 5-22-07) 
Note- See editor's note for Art III, Div. 2. 
Secs. 52-151-52-165. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DONATIONS 

Sec. 52-166. - Parks. 
(a)  Parkland dedication requirements. 
(1)  As a prerequisite to subdivision approval, the developer shall dedicate land for parks, playgrounds, public open spaces and trails. The city may accept a cash equivalent in lieu of land dedication. The city will determine whether land or cash will be accepted. 
(2)  Land to be dedicated shall be reasonably suitable for its intended use and shall be at a location convenient to the people to be served. Factors used in evaluating the adequacy of proposed park and recreation areas shall include size, shape, topography, geology, hydrology, tree cover, access, and location. The city shall determine location of parkland. 
(3)  When a proposed park or other public ground is to be dedicated to the city, such land shall be designated on the plat as an outlot. 
(4)  When a proposed park, or other public ground has been indicated in the city's official map or comprehensive plan and is located in whole or in part within a proposed plat, or will otherwise be dedicated to the city, it shall be designated and dedicated as an outlot on such plat. If the developer elects not to dedicate an area in excess of the land required hereunder for such proposed public site, the city may consider acquiring the site through purchase or condemnation. 
(5)  Land area conveyed or dedicated to the city shall not be used in calculating density requirements of the city zoning ordinance and shall be in addition to and not in lieu of open space requirements as applicable. 
(6)  Where private open space for park and recreation purposes is provided in a proposed subdivision, such areas may be used for credit, at the discretion of the city council, against the requirement of dedication for park and recreation purposes, provided the city council finds it in the public interest to do so. 
(7)  The city, upon consideration of the particular type of development, may require larger or lesser parcels of land to be dedicated if the city determines that present or future residents would require greater or lesser land for park and playground purposes. 
(b)  Park dedication. 
(1)  Residential. 
a.  Neighborhood parks. In residential plats, one acre of usable land area shall be provided for every 25 residential units, or 1,750 square feet per dwelling unit shall be conveyed to the city by warranty deed for a neighborhood park. Such park shall be sited to provide active and passive recreational facilities for the immediate neighborhood. 
b.  Community parks. In residential areas, land area equal to five percent of the gross land area shall be conveyed to the city for use as a community park. Such park shall be sited to reflect the access, active and passive recreational needs of the community as a whole. 
(2)  Commercial/industrial. In plats other than residential plats ten percent of the gross area of land being platted shall be conveyed to the city. 
(3)  Cash in lieu of land. In lieu of a parkland donation, at its discretion, the city may require an equivalent cash donation based upon the fair market value of the undeveloped property. 
(4)  Determination of fair market value. "Fair market value" shall be determined as of the date of the final plat in accordance with the following: 
a.  The city and the developer may agree as to the fair market value, or 
b.  The fair market value may be based upon a current appraisal submitted to the city by the developer at the developer's expense. 
c.  If the city disputes such appraisal the city may, at the developer's expense, obtain an appraisal of the property by the qualified real estate appraiser, which appraisal shall be conclusive evidence of the fair market value of the land. 
(5)  Mixed use developments. Developments with mixed land uses shall make cash and/or land contributions in accordance with this section based upon the percentage of land and dwelling units devoted to the various uses. 
(6)  Payment. The park and trail cash contribution, as required herein, shall be paid contemporaneously with the city's approval of the final plat. The cash contributions for parks and trails shall be used only for park acquisition or development and trail acquisition or development. 
(7)  Areas not considered as parkland dedication. Wetlands, floodplain, ponding areas and drainage ways accepted by the city shall not be considered in the parkland contribution to the city. 
(c)  Recreation facilities and equipment. For each new residential lot included within a final plat for which a preliminary plat did not receive approval prior to June 1, 2002, a fee shall be paid in accordance with the following: 
The developer shall pay a minimum of one-third of the total facility fee prior to recording of the final plat and may elect to defer the remainder of the total facility fee to be divided among the building sites to be paid by the builder of the individual lots upon receipt of the building permit for the principal structure. If the remainder is not deferred to the building permit, the total fee shall be collected at the time of final platting. In the event where a development is proposed in phases, the payment shall be collected in the same manner as the first phase for that particular development for all subsequent phases. Such payment shall be for the improvement of the city's recreational facilities and recreational property only. 
Such payment shall be as defined below: 
Density Payment Amount 0-1 units per acre $1,500.00 per acre 1.1-2.9 units per acre $3,500.00 per acre 3-4.9 units per acre $4,200.00 per acre More than 5 units per acre $6,000.00 per acre  
All land, including streets, parks, and private parcels will be used in calculating density. 
All land, including streets and private parcels, will be used in calculating per acre payment amount. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02; Ord. No. 249, § 12, 8-26-03) 
Sec. 52-167. - Trails. 
    The use and availability of trails and pathways throughout the community has been identified as an asset and is harmonious with the goals and ideals of the City of Watertown. Therefore, new developments within the city shall provide trails and pathways as directed by the City of Watertown Trail Map, or as otherwise directed by the planning commission and city council. Trails shall be sited to provide connections from new and established residential neighborhoods to new and existing commercial, cultural, recreational, and employment centers throughout the city. 
    Developers of land abutting property that has been designated in the city's comprehensive trail plan for the installation of a trail shall be required to dedicate the land for the trail to the city and construct the trail. 
    In lieu of a trail donation, trail construction, or trail easement dedication, the city may require a cash donation for the trail system. The cash dedication requirement shall be established annually by the city council. Trail or sidewalk construction shall not be used for the calculation of park dedication or cash in lieu of park dedication. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 52-168. - Dedication of land or contribution in cash for public purposes. 
    In every plat or subdivision the developer may be required to dedicate to the public streets, easements for sewers, electric, gas, water facilities, stormwater drainage, holding ponds and similar utilities and improvements. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 52-169. - Easements. 
(a)  All easements shall be dedicated by appropriate language on the final plat in accordance with this section. 
(b)  Easements at least ten feet wide along all street right-of-way lines, five feet along both sides of rear and side lot lines, shall be provided for utilities where necessary. If appropriate, easements of lesser or greater width may be required by the city. All utility easements shall have continuity of alignment from block to block. 
(c)  Easements shall be provided along each side of the centerline of any watercourse or drainage channel, to a width sufficient to provide proper maintenance and protection and to provide for stormwater run-off from a 100-year storm of 24-hour duration. Where necessary, drainage easements corresponding to lot lines shall be provided. Such easements for drainage purposes shall not be less than twenty feet in width. 
(d)  The construction of principal or accessory structures, including; but not limited to decks, fences, sheds, signs, shall not be permitted to encroach into a duly recorded easement. Therefore, the locations of easements shall be the minimum required to provide necessary services and access to the subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02) 
Secs. 52-170-52-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 52-191. - Required improvements. 
(a)  Plans and specifications. The developer shall submit engineering plans and specifications satisfactory to the city for all required improvements, as listed or as specified in this chapter and as may be required in the development agreement. These improvements must be initiated within one year of final plat approval and completed within two years or prior to issuance of a certificate of occupancy, which ever comes first. 
(b)  Required public improvements. The following public improvements are required in every subdivision: 
(1)  All subdivision boundary corners, block and lot corners, road intersection corners and points of tangency and curvature shall be marked with durable iron or steel monuments meeting the minimum requirements of state law. The city may, when a subdivision is essentially complete, require a development to have the plat restaked to replace the original monuments destroyed or removed during the construction process. 
(2)  Surface discharge shall be approved by the city engineer. 
(3)  Sub-base shall conform to the requirements outlined within the City of Watertown Standards Manual. 
(4)  Concrete curb and gutter. 
(5)  Sidewalks and or a trail may be required. 
(6)  Water supply shall be approved by the city engineer. 
(7)  Street lighting of a type approved by the city shall be required at intersections and other locations. 
(8)  Public sanitary sewer main and service connections shall be approved by the city engineer. 
(9)  Street signs shall conform to the requirements outlined within the City of Watertown Standards Manual. 
(10)  All utility lines for cable, electric, telephone and electrical service shall be approved by the city engineer. 
(11)  Utility services shall be provided in the rear yard. Where existing vegetation, topography renders this requirement unreasonable, utility services shall be installed in the side yard no closer to the street the appropriate front yard building setback line. 
(12)  All buffer requirements as required by the landscaping code. 
(c)  Guarantee. Prior to the city signing the final plat and prior to the construction of any improvements, the developer shall provide the city with a letter of credit or cash escrow to insure that all improvements required by this chapter will be installed and paid for at no city expense. For improvements to be installed by the developer, the developer is obligated to install and complete all such improvements at his own expense and under the supervision and inspection of the city. For improvements that the city agrees to install, the developer shall pay the cost of such improvements through payment of special assessments. As security to the city for installation of the improvements of the payment of special assessments, the developer shall be required to file a cash escrow or letter of credit in an amount and form acceptable to the city to cover the cost of all public improvements and special assessments. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02) 
Secs. 52-192-52-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - BUILDING DESIGN GUIDELINES 

Sec. 52-211. - Intent and scope. 
    The intent of this article is to establish minimum standards for the design and construction of buildings and related structures in all zoning districts. The quality of architecture and building construction shall be considered important to the preservation and enhancement of building and property values, prevention of the physical deterioration of buildings and the promotion of the image of the community and the general welfare of the city. 
    It is not the intent of the city to restrict design, however, it is in the best interest of the city to promote standards for architectural design and compatibility with other development. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 52-212. - General regulations. 
(a)  As part of the submittal for development plan approval within any zoning district, architectural plans shall be submitted for review by the planning commission and approved by the city council. 
(b)  Architectural elevations showing the building's design and a description of structural and exterior material proposed shall be provided in accordance with this chapter and consistent with the requirements as outlined herein. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 52-213. - Design standards. 
(a)  Building orientation. The orientation of any proposed building shall be carefully considered so as to mitigate the visual and audible impact of service areas, loading areas, or similar operations on the adjoining properties and general public. 
(1)  Buildings shall not be designed or oriented to expose loading docks, service areas, or nonresidential overhead doors to the public right-of-ways. 
(2)  Buildings proposed in commercial districts that are adjacent to residential developments shall not be designed or oriented to expose loading docks, service areas, or similar operations towards the adjacent residential developments. 
(3)  If it is not feasible to design or orient the loading docks, service areas, or similar operations away from the residential developments, additional landscape buffering, screening walls, fences, and setbacks in addition to those required may be approved by the city council provided a favorable recommendation from the planning commission is provided. 
(b)  Exterior material selection. The building's exterior material shall be compatible with other buildings and structures in adjoining developments. The use of metal for all or a majority of the exposed building surface area shall be prohibited. For the purposes of this section, calculation of the building surface area shall not include glazed surfaces or roof. The use of metal may only be used as trim or an accent to other materials. Other minimum requirements shall be as follows: 
(1)  Metal roofs shall be permitted in R-1, R-2, and R-3 districts, provided: 
a.  The metal roof shall not have exposed fasteners, semi-concealed fasteners, or any fastener system that does not adhere directly to the support system. 
b.  Any metal roof that is not a high-quality commercial thickness/weight is prohibited. 
c.  Any metal roof that has not been treated with a factory applied color-coating system against any applicable degradation is prohibited. 
(2)  Residential districts. In R-1, R-2, and R-3 districts, primarily residential construction materials such as brick, stone, wood, lap siding, and architectural shingles, shall be utilized in the design. 
a.  All attached dwelling structures (townhomes, twin homes) shall incorporate, at a minimum, 20 percent brick, stone, or similar substantial material in the overall building design. The percentage requirement shall be calculated on the total exterior surface area exclusive of glazed surfaces. 
b.  Multiple family structures shall incorporate at a minimum, 30 percent brick, stone, or similar substantial material into the overall building design. The percentage requirement shall be calculated on the total exterior surface area exclusive of glazed surfaces. 
(3)  Central business and industrial districts. In the "CBD" and "I" districts, the architectural material selection shall be dominated with permanency and strength of materials in proportion to the aesthetic characteristics of the building's bulk and shape. Structures in these districts shall incorporate at a minimum, 30 percent brick, stone, or other similar substantial material into the overall building design. The percentage requirement shall be calculated on the total exterior surface area exclusive of glazed surfaces. 
(c)  Architectural elements. In order to reduce the negative aesthetic impacts of large buildings, additional architectural elements shall be incorporated into the overall building design. Physical offsets when used in columns shall be 12 inches minimum, in all other cases, shall be three feet minimum. 
(1)  Commercial. 
a.  Commercial buildings shall incorporate architectural design elements, materials, and colors into the side and rear building elevations, similar to those used in the front building elevation. 
b.  Commercial buildings shall incorporate facade modulation in all building elevations in order to preserve building scale and reduce the aesthetic impact of long, large expansive wall surfaces. The variation in wall surfaces can be accomplished either by physical offsets or by the use of color, pattern, or texture. 
(2)  Central business district. 
Reserved. 
(3)  Industrial. 
a.  Industrial buildings shall incorporate architectural design elements, materials, and colors into the side and rear building elevations, similar to those used in the front building elevation. 
b.  Industrial buildings shall incorporate facade modulation in all building elevations in order to preserve building scale and reduce the aesthetic impact of long, large expansive wall surfaces. The variation in wall surfaces can be accomplished either by physical offsets or by the use of color, pattern, or texture. 
(4)  Residential. The use of building designs that minimize the visual impact of garage doors on the streetscape is encouraged. 
a.  Attached single-family. 
Townhome [row house] development guidelines: 
No more than two adjacent dwelling units in a single family attached structure shall have the same front or rear building lines. The minimum variation in building line shall not be less than four feet. Each structure shall encompass at least three dwelling units but not more than eight dwelling units. 

Townhome 
b.  Other attached single-family residential. 
A distance not less than 25 feet shall separate attached single-family buildings within a complex. 
(5)  Commercial adjacent to residential. Buildings proposed in commercial districts that are adjacent to residential developments are recommended to include an articulated roofline, giving emphasis to architectural elements that will help divide the mass of a large building into smaller, identifiable pieces. Flat roof buildings shall not be encouraged, and only be approved by the city council following a favorable recommendation from the planning commission. 
(6)  All districts. 
a.  Roof-mounted mechanical units, satellite dishes, or other similar equipment shall be screened from the public view by the extension of a parapet wall or other roof structure. 
b.  In the case where the parapet wall cannot feasibly screen the roof-mounted equipment, point-in-place or other appropriate screening shall be required. Such screening shall have similar design features as the building including material, shape, and color considerations. Wooden fences or similar screen shall not be considered appropriate. 
Understanding the operational requirements of satellite dishes and antennas, such units shall be screened to minimize the visual impact on surrounding properties. 
(d)  Exterior color selection. The building's exterior color scheme shall utilize primarily muted, neutral, or earth tone type colors. The primary use of bright, intense, or extreme colors not consistent with the adjoining developments shall not be permitted in any zoning district. This regulation is not intended to restrict the use of contrasting color in architectural detailing. 
    The city council reserves the right to waive or modify to a lesser restriction any provision or requirement of architectural design elements contained in this chapter in any redevelopment of property within the city, provided a favorable report on such change is approved by the planning commission, and further provided said waiver or modification does not adversely affect the intent of these regulations to adequately safeguard the general public and surrounding property. Exceptions will only be considered for those areas where special circumstances warrant a change and where the modification or waiver is determined to be in the best interest of the general public. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02; Ord. No. 344, § 1, 9-22-09) 
Secs. 52-214-52-235. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - SITE DESIGN AND OPERATION 

Sec. 52-236. - General regulations. 
(a)  Key boxes. Structures in all districts, except one and two family dwellings shall provide a key box in a location specified by the fire chief. Such box shall provide emergency personnel access to the building at all times. 
(b)  Fire lanes. Structures in all districts, except one- and two-family residential dwelling units shall provide a fire lane as required by the fire chief, promoting safe and efficient access to the site while preserving the health and safety of the inhabitants and surrounding properties. 
(c)  Address identification. Address identification shall be maintained so as to be legible from the street at all times. 
(d)  Corner and double frontage lot enlargement. Due to additional setback constraints on double frontage and corner lots, the following must be maintained. 
(1)  Corner lots shall be platted with 20 additional feet of front yard width. 
(2)  Double frontage lots shall be platted with a minimum of 30 feet between a buffer and the rear of the house to permit usable yard area with screening and buffering. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02; Ord. No. 249, § 13, 8-26-03) 
Sec. 52-237. - Occupancy. 
(a)  Certificate of occupancy. A certificate of occupancy will be granted upon completion of new construction or completion of alterations or additions to existing structures. No certificate of occupancy shall be issued until such time as all site improvements and building construction is completed in compliance with all provisions identified on the approved development plan and within all applicable building codes. 
(b)  Temporary certificates of occupancy. 
(1)  Temporary certificate of occupancy may be issued prior to completion of the project if, in the opinion of the city planner or city administrator, the remaining items could not be completed due to circumstances beyond the applicants control and the issuance of a temporary certificate of occupancy will not inhibit the completion of the total project, nor have an adverse effect on persons in the immediate area or nearby properties, or affect the safety of the occupants. 
(2)  The applicant will be required to sign an agreement to complete and post sufficient security to complete the remaining items. The security will be returned to the applicant with the issuance of the final certificate of occupancy. The agreement to complete shall be approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 52-238. - Fees. 
    Each development application shall include the appropriate fees. Fees shall be in an amount determined by the city council from time to time. 
    In addition to the application fee, the applicant for development plan review must also pay all costs incurred by the city including city staff time, legal, engineering, administrative, building inspection services, and services of other persons or entities employed or contracted by the city for, or in any way involved in, the review and inspection of the development plan and public utility extensions contemplated thereby, including but not limited to streets, sidewalks, trails, water lines, sanitary sewer lines, storm sewer lines, street lights, electric and gas lines, water retention areas and all other improvements intended for public use or benefit constructed or caused to be constructed by the owner and under no condition shall the fee be refunded for the failure of the city to approve the development plan. All charges incurred for this review shall be the sole responsibility of the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02; Ord. No. 332, § 1, 2-24-09) 
Sec. 52-239. - Waivers. 
    The planning commission may recommend and the city council may grant a waiver from the regulations contained in this chapter, provided such waiver shall not violate the purpose and intent of the comprehensive plan and zoning ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 52-240. - Violations and penalty. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. The city may withhold, revoke or deny any permits, approvals or any action may be stopped if there is a violation of this chapter. Each day during which the violation exists shall constitute a separate violation. The city may apply to the district court for injunctive relief for violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 230, 6-11-02) 
Chapter 54 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Possession of open containers in vehicles prohibited, § 6-3; vegetation which prevents an unobstructed clear view of all traffic declared public nuisance, § 26-30; junked, wrecked, abandoned vehicles, § 26-66 et seq.; planning, ch. 46.5. 
State Law reference- Traffic regulations, M.S.A. ch. 169; local authority, M.S.A. § 169.04. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 54-1. - State highway regulations adopted. 
    The Minnesota Highway Traffic Regulation Act (M.S.A. ch. 169) is hereby adopted in its entirety as the law governing the driving, operation and control of motor vehicles within the city, and such act is hereby incorporated and made a part of this chapter by reference, except that M.S.A. §§ 169.23 and 169.24 are hereby specifically excepted. There shall be kept in the office of the clerk-treasurer a copy thereof, marked "City of Watertown." 
(Ord. No. 49, § 6, 2-7-67) 
State Law reference- State highway traffic regulation act, M.S.A. ch. 169; uniform traffic ticket, M.S.A. § 169.99. 
Sec. 54-2. - Bus stops and taxi stands. 
(a)  The city council may from time to time, by motion adopted by a majority vote, designate bus stops and/or taxicab stands in the city. 
(b)  The driver of a bus or taxicab shall not stand or park the vehicle operated by him or under his control upon any street or public thoroughfare in the business area of this city at any place other than a bus or taxicab stand, respectively, if such stand has been designated by the council under subsection (a) of this section, except that this provision shall not prevent the driver of any such vehicle from temporarily stopping in accordance with other stopping or parking regulations at any place for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers. 
(c)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle other than a bus in a bus stop or other than a taxicab in a taxicab stand when any such stop or stand has been officially designated by appropriate signs posted on each end thereof, except that no person is hereby prohibited from temporarily stopping the vehicle operated by him in such stop or stand for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers when such stopping does not interfere with any bus or taxicab waiting to enter or about to enter such zone. 
(Ord. No. 49, § 10, 2-7-67) 
Sec. 54-3. - Vehicles with lugs or sharp-shod horses prohibited on improved streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any tractor, engine or other machine having metal lugs upon the outside surface of its wheels upon any street, alley, sidewalk or crosswalk which has been improved by having a surface covering placed thereon of concrete, asphalt, or any other such surfaces or to drive or permit to be driven any horse or other draft animal shod with sharp spikes, cleats or other sharp attachments along any of the streets, alleys, sidewalks or crosswalks in this city which have been so improved. 
(Ord. No. 49, § 16, 2-7-67) 
Sec. 54-4. - Skateboards, rollerskates and similar devices. 
(a)  The operation of skateboards, rollerskates, rollerblades, skate-type shoes, skis running on wheels, and similar devices within the corporate limits of the city shall be regulated pursuant to M.S.A. § 169.222. 
(b)  In addition, it shall be unlawful to operate skateboards, rollerblades, rollerskates, skate-type shoes, skis running on wheels and similar devices under the following circumstances: 
(1)  On private property without the express permission to do so by the owner or occupant of such property. 
(2)  In any careless, reckless or negligent manner, so as to endanger or be likely to endanger the safety of any person or property. 
(3)  Upon any public sidewalk, street and parking lot in the downtown area without permission of the city council. The downtown area is defined as an area bounded on the west by Angel Street, to the north by State Street, to the east by the Crow River, and to the south by Kieffer Street. 
(4)  On a public street, sidewalk or alley after sunset and before sunrise. 
(c)  Impoundment. Violation of this section shall be punishable by impoundment of such device by a law enforcement officer for storage and safekeeping for a period of three days for the first offense, seven days upon the second offense, and 30 days for the third offense. Subsequent offenses are punishable as a petty misdemeanor. Such device may be recovered upon an impound fee payment of $25.00 to the city; and if the owner thereof is under age 18, the accompaniment of a legal guardian is also required. 
(Ord. No. 171, §§ 1-3, 4-11-89) 
State Law reference- State highway traffic regulation act, rollerskates, etc., M.S.A. § 169.222. 
Sec. 54-5. - Posting of traffic control signs restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person other than an employee of the state highway department, county highway department, or city engineer or county sheriff's department to erect, post, maintain or display any traffic control sign or signal, or parking restriction or limitation sign, on any of the streets, highways, public alleys, public parking lots or public thoroughfares in the city. 
(Ord. No. 49, § 17, 2-7-67) 
Sec. 54-6. - Posting of signs resembling traffic control devices. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person other than a state highway department employee, county employee, or city employee to erect, post, maintain or display any signs resembling any state highway department, county highway department or city traffic control sign or signal or parking limitation sign upon any of the streets, highways, public parking lots, public alleys or public thoroughfares in the city. 
(Ord. No. 49, § 18, 2-7-67) 
Secs. 54-7-54-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OPERATION OF VEHICLES GENERALLY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Traffic-control devices, M.S.A. § 169.06; right-of-way, M.S.A. § 169.20. 

Sec. 54-31. - Careless driving off highways. 
    Any person who drives any vehicle in such a manner on any public or private grounds or parking lot or on the frozen surface of any body of water within the corporate limits of the city or adjacent to the corporate limits of the city so as to indicate a disregard for the safety of persons or property shall be guilty of careless driving. 
(Ord. No. 49, § 7, 2-7-67) 
Sec. 54-32. - Unnecessary speed; exhibition driving. 
    No person shall operate any motor vehicle with unnecessary exhibition of speed on any public or private way within the city limits. Prima facie evidence of such unnecessary exhibition of speed shall be any or all of the following: 
(1)  Unreasonable squealing or screeching sounds emitted by the tires; 
(2)  The throwing of sand or gravel by the tires of the vehicle; 
(3)  Unreasonable skid, sway or slide upon acceleration or stopping. 
(Ord. No. 88, § 2, 4-20-76; Ord. No. 280, § 1, 3-14-06) 
Secs. 54-33-54-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING GENERALLY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Stopping, standing, parking, M.S.A. § 169.32 et seq. 

Sec. 54-56. - Designation of no parking zones and limited parking zones. 
    The city council may, from time to time, by resolution adopted by a majority vote, designate certain streets or portions thereof as no parking zones or as limited parking zones as to period of time and purpose (such as snow removal and otherwise) and direct the public works superintendent or the county sheriff's department to accordingly place proper signs thereon and/or appropriately paint the curbs thereby to indicate their character. 
(Ord. No. 49, § 13, 2-7-67) 
Sec. 54-57. - Special parking provisions. 
(a)  Overnight parking generally. No person shall park or leave standing any vehicle, whether attended or unattended, upon any public street, avenue, alley or municipal parking lot within the city for a period of time longer than 24 consecutive hours. 
(b)  Winter parking. No person shall park or leave standing any vehicle, whether attended or unattended, upon any public street, avenue, alley or municipal parking lot within the city between the hours of 2:30 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. from November 1 to April 1. 
(c)  Downtown business district. The following restrictions apply in the areas as noted in the downtown business district: 
(1)  No person shall park or leave standing any vehicle, whether attended or unattended, upon any part of Lewis Avenue between the intersection of Fremont Street SW and Angel Avenue SW and Territorial Street or upon the south side of Territorial Street between Angel Avenue and the Crow River Bridge, as marked, for a period of more than two hours between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m., except on Sundays and holidays. 
(2)  No vehicle shall be parked or left standing at any time on the north side of Territorial Street between Angel Avenue and the Crow River Bridge. 
(d)  Trucks, trailers, buses, recreational vehicles and commercial vehicles.
