No person shall park or leave standing any truck of one ton or larger, trailer, bus, recreational or commercial vehicle, whether attended or unattended, upon any public street, avenue, alley, or municipal parking lot within the city unless it is in the actual process of being loaded or unloaded and only for the reasonable time of such loading or unloading. 
(e)  Loitering in municipal parking lots. No person shall loiter or congregate in any municipal parking lot within the city. 
(Ord. No. 147, §§ 1, 2, 12-18-84; Ord. No. 386, § 1, 5-26-15) 
State Law reference- Manner of parking, M.S.A. § 169.35. 
Sec. 54-58. - Disposing of illegally parked vehicles. 
(a)  Notice of impoundment. Any person who owns or is in control of any vehicle which is in violation of the terms and provisions of this chapter shall be subject to having the vehicle ticketed and towed by the county sheriff's department and removed. All costs incurred in the removal and the storage of any vehicle parked in violation of this chapter and the fine for the parking violation shall be paid prior to the release of the vehicle. When a vehicle is removed and stored pursuant to provisions of this section, the clerk-treasurer or county sheriff's department shall give or cause to be given, within ten days of the taking, written notice setting forth the date and place of taking, the year, make, model and serial number of the vehicle, if such information can be reasonably obtained, and the place where the vehicle is being held; shall inform the owner and any lienholders of their right to reclaim the vehicle under subsection (b) of this section and shall state that failure to exercise their right to reclaim the vehicle shall be deemed a waiver by them of all right, title and interest in the vehicle and a consent to the sale of the vehicle at public auction in accordance with the provisions of section 26-77, relating to abandoned and inoperative vehicles. Any notice required in this section may be made in person or by mail addressed to the last known home address that can be reasonably obtained. 
(b)  Right to reclaim. The owner or any lienholder of a vehicle removed pursuant to provisions of this section shall have a right to reclaim such vehicle from the city upon payment of all towing and storage charges and an administrative fee of $10.00 and payment of all fines for the parking violation within 15 days after the date of the notice required under subsection (a) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 147, § 3, 12-18-84) 
Sec. 54-59. - Parking tickets and fines, county's responsibility. 
    All parking tickets, fines, and the collection thereof shall be issued, processed and collected by the county and the county sheriff's department according to methods for issuance, amount of fines, and the processing and collection policies which have been established by the county pursuant to an agreement between the city and county. 
(Ord. No. 147, § 4, 12-18-84) 
State Law reference- Uniform traffic ticket, M.S.A. § 169.99. 
Secs. 54-60-54-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - TRUCK ROUTES 

Sec. 54-91. - Authority to designate; posting of signs. 
(a)  The city council may from time to time, by resolution adopted by a majority vote, designate certain streets as through highways and/or truck routes and indicate school stops at street intersections or indicated school crossings, or vacate prior through highways and/or truck routes and school stop designations, and direct the public works superintendent or the sheriff's department to accordingly place or remove proper signs upon such streets and their intersections to indicate their character and notify the drivers of vehicles of the requirement to stop. 
(b)  Except for any necessary utility, gas, fuel, refuse, building construction, bus, automobile service, fire and emergency vehicles in the act of providing services, no person shall operate any farm vehicle, commercial vehicle or truck greater than one ton upon any public street other than those streets designated and posted as truck routes within the city without written permission from the city council. 
(Ord. No. 112, § 1, 6-28-79; Ord. No. 120, § 1, 6-17-80) 
Sec. 54-92. - Enumerated. 
(a)  The following streets or portions of streets in the city are hereby designated as truck routes: 
(1)  All of State Highway No. 25 within the city limits. 
(2)  All of C.S.A.H. No. 10 within the city limits. 
(3)  That part of Lewis Avenue from Kieffer Street to the northerly city limit. 
(4)  That part of Mill Avenue from Territorial Street (C.S.A.H. No. 10) to the northerly city limit. 
(5)  That part of Newton Avenue N.E. from Carter Street to C.S.A.H. No. 20. 
(6)  That part of Madison Street from Jefferson Avenue (State Highway No. 25) to Lewis Avenue. 
(7)  That part of C.S.A.H. No. 20 from the easterly city limit to Territorial Street (C.S.A.H. No. 10). 
(b)  The city shall forthwith place and install proper signs upon the streets designated as truck routes under this section to identify the portions of such streets as are so designated as truck routes. 
(Res. of 6-19-79; Ord. No. 203, § 1, 8-8-95) 
Secs. 54-93-54-115. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SNOWMOBILES, ATVs, AND RECREATIONAL VEHICLES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 380, § 1, adopted Oct. 28, 2014, changed the title of Art. II from "Snowmobiles and ATVs" to read as set out herein. 
State Law reference- Recreational vehicles, M.S.A. § 84.81 et seq.; authority to regulate, M.S.A. § 84.87. 

Sec. 54-116. - Intent. 
    It is the intent of this article to supplement M.S.A. §§ 84.81-84.928, and M.S.A. ch. 169, with respect to the operation of snowmobiles, ATVs, and recreational vehicles. Such statutes are incorporated in this article by reference. This article is not intended to allow what the state statutes prohibit. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 1, 2-2-82; Ord. No. 380, § 1, 10-28-14) 
Sec. 54-117. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    All-terrain vehicle (ATV) means a motorized flotation tired vehicle of not less than three low-pressure tires, but not more than six tires, also known and referred to in this article as an ATV. 
    Deadman throttle or safety throttle means a device which, when pressure is removed from the engine accelerator or throttle, causes the motor to be disengaged from the driving mechanism. 
    Operate means to ride in or on and control the operation of a snowmobile, recreational vehicle, or all-terrain vehicle. 
    Operator means every person who operates or is in actual physical control of a snowmobile, recreational vehicle, or all-terrain vehicle. 
    Owner means a person, other than a lienholder, having the property in or title to a snowmobile, recreational vehicle, or all-terrain vehicle, or entitled to the use or possession thereof. 
    Recreational vehicle means any self-propelled vehicle and any vehicle propelled or drawn by a self-propelled vehicle used for recreational purposes, including but not limited to snowmobiles, trail bikes all-terrain vehicles, mini-bikes, pocket bikes, motorized scooters, hovercrafts, or motor vehicles licensed for highway operation, which is being used for off-road recreational purposes. 
    Right-of-way means the entire strip of land traversed by a street in which the public owns the fee or an easement for roadway purposes. 
    Snowmobile means a self-propelled vehicle designed for travel on snow or ice, steered by skis or runners. 
    Street means a public thoroughfare, highway, roadway, alley or trail used for motor vehicle traffic. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 2, 2-2-82; Ord. No. 380, § 1, 10-28-14) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 54-118. - Owner responsible. 
    It is unlawful for the owner of a snowmobile, recreational vehicle, or ATV to permit the snowmobile, recreational vehicle, or ATV to be operated in any manner contrary to any provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 10, 2-2-82; Ord. No. 380, § 1, 10-28-14) 
Sec. 54-119. - Prohibited operation; exceptions. 
    Except as specifically permitted and authorized in this article, it is unlawful for any person to operate a snowmobile, recreational vehicle, or ATV within the limits of the city: 
(1)  On any public street, except that a snowmobile may operate upon the most right-hand lane of a street and may, in passing or in making a left turn, operate on other lanes which are used for vehicle traffic in the same direction, for the purpose of going in the most direct, practicable route possible from a point outside the city to a specific destination within the city, or from a point within the city to a specific destination outside the city limits. Operation of a snowmobile without regard to a specific destination and on an aimless, nondirect route constitutes a violation of this article. 
(2)  On a public sidewalk or boulevard within any public right-of-way, provided that a snowmobile operator may cross a public sidewalk, boulevard or other public right-of-way to obtain access to a street if such crossing is made at an angle of approximately 90 degrees to the direction of the sidewalk, boulevard or right-of-way and, provided further, that such operator yields the right-of-way to all pedestrians or vehicle traffic. 
(3)  On private property, except that an ATV may be operated for home maintenance such as snow removal, lawn maintenance, and moving of trailers. 
(4)  On private property for recreational purposes for more than 15 minutes per day. 
(5)  On private property of another without specific permission of the owner or person in control of such property. 
(6)  Upon any school grounds, except as permission is expressly obtained from responsible school authorities. 
(7)  On public property, playgrounds, parks and recreation areas without the express provision or permission to do so by the proper public authorities. 
(8)  On streets as permitted by this article at a speed exceeding 15 miles per hour. However, in no event shall the rate of speed be greater than reasonable or proper under all of the surrounding circumstances. 
(9)  In a careless, reckless or negligent manner so as to endanger the personal property of another or to cause injury or damage thereto. 
(10)  While under the influence of alcoholic beverages or narcotics or drugs, as prohibited in state law. 
(11)  In such a manner so as to create loud, excessive, unnecessary or unusual noise or in any way which shall unduly disturb the peace and privacy of the residents of the city or in any manner create a public nuisance. 
(12)  Without a lighted headlight and taillight when required for safety. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 3, 2-2-82; Ord. No. 380, § 1, 10-28-14) 
Sec. 54-120. - Traffic ordinances and laws to be observed. 
    City traffic ordinances and state laws shall apply to the operation of snowmobile, recreational vehicles, and ATVs upon all streets, if permitted by this ordinance to operate on public streets within the city limits. In addition thereto, no snowmobile, recreational vehicle, or ATV shall enter any uncontrolled intersection without making a complete stop. The operator shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles or pedestrians at the intersection or so close as to constitute a hazard. All streets shall be crossed at an angle of approximately 90 degrees to the direction of the street. If more than one snowmobile, recreational vehicle, or ATV is traveling in the same direction, they shall travel in a single file. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 4, 2-2-82; Ord. No. 380, § 1, 10-28-14) 
Sec. 54-121. - Operation by minors. 
    No person under 14 years of age shall operate on the streets or make a direct crossing of a city street as the operator of a snowmobile, recreational vehicle, or ATV. A person 14 years of age or older, but less than 18 years of age, may operate a snowmobile, recreational vehicle, or ATV on streets as permitted under this article and state law, and make a direct crossing of such streets, only if he complies with the licensing provisions as may be required in state law. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 5, 2-2-82; Ord. No. 380, § 1, 10-28-14) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, M.S.A. § 84.872. 
Sec. 54-122. - Towing. 
(a)  No sleds, toboggans and sleighs or similar items, shall be towed behind a snowmobile, recreational vehicle, or ATV permitted to be upon any public street within the city limits between the hours of one-half hour after sunset to one-half hour before sunrise unless it is equipped with at least one taillamp meeting the requirements of the equipment for a snowmobile, recreational vehicle, or ATV as provided in the regulations in state law. 
(b)  No snowmobile, recreational vehicle, or ATV should be used for towing unless it shall have attached to the rear of the snowmobile, recreational vehicle, or ATV a rigid tow bar. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 6, 2-2-82; Ord. No. 380, § 1, 10-28-14) 
Sec. 54-123. - Equipment. 
    It is unlawful for any person to operate a snowmobile, recreational vehicle, or ATV any place within the limits of the city unless it is equipped with the following: 
(1)  Brakes adequate to control the movement of, and to stop and hold, the snowmobile, recreational vehicle, or ATV under any condition of operation. 
(2)  A safety or so-called deadman throttle in operating condition. 
(3)  When operated between the hours of one-half hour after sunset to one-half hour before sunrise, or at times of reduced visibility, lights shall be used as provided in state law. Such lights shall be so aimed that glaring rays are not projected into the eyes of an oncoming vehicle operator. It shall also be equipped with a red taillamp as required in state law. 
(4)  Reflective material at least 16 square inches on each side, forward of the handlebars, so as to reflect lights at a 90-degree angle. 
(5)  All other equipment and safety requirements as prescribed by M.S.A. § 84.81 et seq. and the rules and regulations of the state. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 7, 2-2-82; Ord. No. 380, § 1, 10-28-14) 
Sec. 54-124. - Emergency use of streets permitted. 
    Notwithstanding any prohibitions in this article, a snowmobile, recreational vehicle, or ATV may be operated on a public street in an emergency situation during the period of time when, and at locations where, snow upon the street renders travel by automobile impractical. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 8, 2-2-82; Ord. No. 380, § 1, 10-28-14) 
Sec. 54-125. - Securing. 
    Every person leaving a snowmobile, recreational vehicle, or ATV on a public place shall lock the ignition, remove the key and take the key with him. 
(Ord. No. 131, § 9, 2-2-82; Ord. No. 380, § 1, 10-28-14) 
Secs. 54-126-54-145. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - BICYCLES 

Sec. 54-146. - Traffic rules to be observed. 
    Every person riding or propelling a bicycle upon any street or public thoroughfare in the city shall observe all traffic rules and regulations applicable thereto as the same are set forth in M.S.A. ch. 169, and all laws supplemental thereto or amendatory thereof, as the same are incorporated by reference by section 54-1, including, but not being limited to, the regulations set out in this article. 
(Ord. No. 49, § 21, 2-7-67) 
Sec. 54-147. - Restrictions. 
(a)  Definition: As used in this section, the "downtown business district" is defined as Lewis Avenue from Kieffer Street to Territorial Street. 
(b)  No person riding upon any bicycle, coaster, rollerskates, rollerblades, sled or toy vehicle shall attach the same or himself to any vehicle upon any roadway. 
(c)  No person shall ride a bicycle upon any sidewalk within the downtown business district. 
(d)  Whenever any person is riding a bicycle upon a sidewalk other than in the downtown business district, such person shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian and shall give an audible signal before overtaking and passing any pedestrian. 
(e)  Every person riding or propelling a bicycle upon any street or other public thoroughfare in the city shall also be subject to the following: 
(1)  No bicycle shall carry more than one person, unless it has more than two driving sprockets, in which event as many riders as driving sprockets shall be allowed, or unless there shall be a specially constructed seat mounted on the rear fender of the bicycle, in which event an adult driver of a bicycle may carry one child in such seat. 
(2)  No bicycle shall be ridden faster than is reasonable and proper, but every bicycle shall be operated with reasonable regard for the safety of the operator and all other persons upon the sidewalks, streets and other public thoroughfares of the city. 
(3)  Every person riding or propelling a bicycle upon any street or other public thoroughfare in the city shall turn only at intersections and shall signal all turns. 
(Ord. No. 49, § 21, 2-7-67) 
Chapter 58 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; environment, ch. 26; planning, ch. 46.5; solid waste, ch. 50; subdivisions, ch. 52. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 58-1. - Contract with city. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall be deemed a part of a contract with every person or owner of the property supplied with water or sewer through the water and sewer systems of the city and every such water and/or sewer user shall be considered as having consented to be bound by the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 87, § 1, 12-16-75) 
Sec. 58-2. - Permit to connect to system required. 
    No person shall make, construct or install any water or sewer installation or make use of any water or sewer service connected to the city water and sewer system, except those connected on December 16, 1975, to the system by permission of the city, without application and permit as provided by the city. No person shall otherwise make use of any installation connected to the city water and sewer system contrary to the regulations of this chapter. No person except an authorized city employee shall turn on any water supply at any valve or stop box without a permit from the city. 
(Ord. No. 87, § 2, 12-16-75) 
Sec. 58-3. - Application for service. 
    All applications for service installations and for water and sewer service shall be made to the city on forms prescribed by the city and shall contain the name of the owner; description of the property to be served by lot, block and addition; the name of the street upon which the property fronts; the official street number assigned to the premises as shown by the records of the city, if any; and the signature of the applicant. Every person applying for water and/or sewer service, and every owner of property for which such application is made, shall be deemed by such application to consent to this chapter and all ordinances, rules and regulations of the city relating to the municipal water and sewer systems. All service connections shall be made and installed according to regulations established by the city. 
(Ord. No. 87, § 3, 12-16-75) 
Sec. 58-4. - Accounts in name of owner; lien. 
    All utilities accounts shall be in the name of the owner of the property served by the water or sewer service. The city, at its option, upon request of the owner or applicant, may for the convenience of billing send bills in the name and address of the agent or tenant of the owner. The owner shall at all times be liable for water and sewer service consumed upon the premises whether he is occupying the premises or not and any charges not paid promptly shall be a lien upon the premises and may be certified and collected as taxes as set forth in section 58-187. 
(Ord. No. 87, § 4, 12-16-75) 
Sec. 58-5. - Connections outside city limits. 
    The city council may make such further rules and regulations pertaining to connections and rates for srvice for water and sewer to premises lying outside the city limits as the council shall deem appropriate. However, it is the general policy of the city to not provide water or sewer service to premises not located within the city limits. 
(Ord. No. 87, § 19, 12-16-75) 
Sec. 58-6. - Taking services without authority; violations. 
    It is hereby declared a violation of this chapter for any person to take any service described in this chapter without proper authority therefor or for any violation of this chapter and upon conviction thereof in addition to other penalties provided herein, shall be punishable as provided in section 1-13. 
(Ord. No. 87, § 20, 12-16-75) 
Sec. 58-7. - Additional rules and regulations. 
    The city council shall have authority to make and adopt any other rules and regulations in furtherance of the purposes of this chapter as it deems appropriate not inconsistent with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 87, § 21, 12-16-75) 
Sec. 58-8. - Establishment of fees, rates and charges. 
    All fees, rates or charges of any kind or however described as set forth, referred to or contemplated by chapter 58 of this Code may be established, modified or changed from time to time by resolution adopted by the city council and shall be effective as of the date set forth in such resolution. 
    The establishment of such fees, rates or charges by resolution of the council shall supersede any such fees, rates or charges that may be set forth in this chapter as of the date of the adoption of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 208, § 1, 9-23-97; Ord. No. 208, § 1, 9-23-97) 
Secs. 58-9-58-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SANITARY SEWERS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Public nuisances affecting health, § 26-29. 
State Law reference- Federal Water Pollution Control Act (33 U.S.C. § 1251 et seq.), by the Federal Water Pollution Control Act Amendments of 1972 (Public Law 92-500 and Public Law 93-243), or as modified by M.S.A. chs. 115 and 116. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 58-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Act means the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, also referred to as the Clean Water Act (33 U.S.C. 1251 et seq.), as amended. 
    Biochemical oxygen demand or BOD means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedures in five days at 20 degrees Celsius and as expressed in terms of milligrams per liter (mg/l). 
    Building drain means that point of a building which conveys wastewater to the building sewer, beginning immediately outside the building wall. 
    City means the area within the corporate boundaries of the city. When used in this article, the term "city" may also refer to the city council or its authorized representative. 
    Connection charge means a service connection charge assessed against all new sanitary sewer service connections. 
    Debt service charge means a charge levied on users of the wastewater treatment facility for the purpose of repaying system capital costs. 
    Equivalent residential unit (ERU) means a debt service billing unit used to equate nonresidential users to residential users for the purpose of assigning a debt service charge. The unit represents a wastewater volume of 100 gallons per day at a strength not greater than NDSW. 
    Industrial user means: 
(1)  Any entity as defined in the Standard Industrial Classification Manual (latest edition), as categorized, that discharges wastewater to the public sewer. 
Division A: Agriculture, forestry and fishing. Division B: Mining. Division D: Manufacturing. Division E: Transportation, communications, electric, gas and sanitary sewers. Division I: Services.  
(2)  Any user whose discharges, singly or by interaction with other wastes: 
a.  Contaminate the sludge of the wastewater treatment system; 
b.  Injure or interfere with the treatment process; 
c.  Create a public nuisance or hazard; 
d.  Have an adverse effect on the waters receiving wastewater treatment plant discharges; 
e.  Exceed NDSW limitations; or 
f.  Exceed normal residential unit volumes of wastewater. 
    Infiltration/inflow (I/I) means water other than wastewater that enters the sewer system from the ground or from surface runoff, as defined in Minnesota Rules. 
    Liquid waste hauler means a licensed hauler that transports waste for the purpose of discharge to the wastewater treatment facilities and who has obtained a waste disposal permit from the city. 
    MPCA means the Minnesota Pollution Control Agency. 
    National categorical pretreatment standards means federal regulations establishing pretreatment standards for introduction of pollutants in publicly owned wastewater treatment facilities (section 307(b) of the act). 
    National pollutant discharge elimination system (NPDES) permit means a permit issued by the MPCA, setting limits on pollutants that a permittee may legally discharge, pursuant to sections 402 and 405 of the act. 
    Natural outlet means any outlet, including storm sewers and combined sewers, which flows into a body of surface water or groundwater. 
    Nonresidential user means a user of the treatment facility whose building is not used as a private residence, and discharges NDSW. 
    Normal domestic strength waste (NDSW) means wastewater that is primarily introduced by residential users with BOD concentrations not greater than 300 mg/l and total suspended solids (TSS) concentrations not greater than 300 mg/l. 
    Operation, maintenance and replacement costs (OM&R) means expenditures necessary to provide for the dependable, economical and efficient functioning of the treatment facility throughout its design life, including operator training and permit fees. "Replacement" refers to equipment replacement costs, not the cost of future replacement of the entire facility. 
    Residential user means a user of the treatment facility whose building is used primarily as a private residence and discharges NDSW. 
    Sewer means a pipe or conduit that carries wastewater or drainage water. 
    Building sewer means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal, also referred to as a service connection. 
    Sanitary sewer means a sewer designed to carry only liquid and water-carried wastes from residential, nonresidential and industrial sources, together with minor quantities of I/I. 
    Storm sewer means a sewer intended to carry unpolluted surface and subsurface water from any source. 
    Sewer service charge means the total of the user charge and debt service charge. 
    Slug means a discharge of water or wastewater which in concentration or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer than 15 minutes, more than five times the average 24-hour concentration or flows during normal operations. 
    State disposal system (SDS) permit means a permit issued by the MPCA pursuant to M.S.A. § 115.07 for a disposal system as defined by M.S.A. § 115.01, Subd. 8. 
    Total suspended solids (TSS) means the total suspended matter that either floats on the surface of, or is in suspension in, water, wastewater or other liquids, and is removable by laboratory filtering as prescribed in Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater, published by the American Public Health Association (latest edition). 
    Unpolluted water means water of a quality equal to or better than the effluent criteria then in effect, or water that would not cause violation of receiving water quality standards. An example could be noncontact cooling water. 
    User charge means a charge to users of a treatment facility for the user's proportionate share of the cost of operation and maintenance, including replacement. 
    Wastewater means liquid and water-carried wastes from residential, nonresidential and industrial users, together with any groundwater, surface water and stormwater that may be present. 
    Wastewater treatment facilities or treatment facilities means the land, devices, facilities, structures, equipment and processes owned or used by the city for the purpose of the transmission, storage, treatment, recycling and reclamation of municipal wastewater, and the disposal of residues resulting from such treatment. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. I, §§ 1-26, 2-23-93; Ord. No. 357, § 2, 4-12-11) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 58-27. - Control by authorized representative. 
    The city council shall appoint the public works superintendent to provide control and general supervision of all public sewers and service connections in the city and shall be responsible for administering the provisions of this article to ensure that a proper and efficient public sewer is maintained. The authorized representative may delegate responsibilities to designated representatives. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. II, 2-23-93) 
Sec. 58-28. - Use of public sewers required. 
(a)  Within 30 days of receiving official notification, the owners of all properties within 500 feet of a sanitary sewer collection system shall install a suitable service connection, at their own expense, in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  If an owner shall fail to connect to a public sewer in compliance with a notice given pursuant to this article, the city will have such connection made and shall assess the cost against the benefitted property. 
(c)  Except as provided in this article, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any private facility intended or used for the disposal of wastewater. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. III, 2-23-93) 
Sec. 58-29. - Damaging facilities. 
    No person shall willfully or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or equipment which is part of the wastewater treatment facilities. Any person violating this section shall be subject to immediate arrest and punished as prescribed in section 1-13. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. VII, 2-23-93) 
Sec. 58-30. - Powers and authority of inspectors. 
(a)  Duly authorized employees of the city, bearing proper credentials and identification, shall be permitted to enter all properties for inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, testing, repair and maintenance in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Industrial users shall be required to provide information concerning industrial processes which have a direct bearing on the type and source of discharge to the collection system. An industry may withhold information considered confidential. However, the industry must establish that the information in question might result in an advantage to competitors and that the industrial process does not have deleterious results on the treatment process. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. VIII, 2-23-93) 
Sec. 58-31. - Notice of violation; penalties. 
(a)  Upon determination that a user has violated or is violating applicable provisions of this article or related permits, the authorized representative may issue a notice of violation. Within 30 days of such notification, the violator shall submit to the authorized representative an adequate explanation for the violation and a plan for the correction and prevention of such occurrences, including specific action required. Submission of such a plan in no way relieves the violator of liability for any violations occurring before or after the issuance of the notice of violation. 
(b)  Any violation of this article is subject to a penalty as prescribed in section 1-13. Each day in which any such violation occurs shall be deemed as a separate offense. Such penalty or fines may be added to the user's next sewer service charge, and will hence be subject to the same collection regulations as specified in section 58-125(f) of this article. Users desiring to dispute a fine must file a request for the authorized representative to reconsider within 30 days of the issuance of the fine. If the authorized representative believes that the request has merit, a hearing on the matter shall be convened within 30 days of the receipt of the request. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. XIII, §§ 1, 2, 2-23-93) 
Sec. 58-32. - Violation; additional penalty. 
    In addition to the penalty provided in section 58-31, any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall become liable to the city for any expense, loss or damage occasioned by the city by reason of such violation. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. XIII, § 4, 2-23-93) 
Secs. 58-33-58-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BUILDING SEWERS, CONNECTION CHARGE AND CONNECTION DESIGN 

Sec. 58-41. - Connection permit required. 
    No person shall make any alterations to the public sewer or any appurtenances thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the city. In the case of a new building, the sewer connection permit is part of the building permit. No private building drain shall extend beyond the limits of the building or property for which the permit has been given. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. V, § 1, 2-23-93) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; manufactured housing, ch. 30. 
Sec. 58-42. - Service connection charge; requirement for new connections. 
(a)  A service connection charge will be assessed at the time a building permit or sewer connection permit is issued for all buildings to be constructed or connected to the sewer system. No charge shall be due upon issuance of a connection permit if a charge was paid upon issuance of a building permit. The connection charge for each building or structure shall be equal to the number of equivalent residential units as outlined by the provisions of this article multiplied by $750.00. 
(b)  Any new connection to the sanitary sewer system shall be prohibited unless sufficient capacity is available in all downstream facilities, including, but not limited to, capacity for flow, BOD and TSS, as determined by the authorized representative. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. V, § 2, 2-23-93) 
Sec. 58-43. - Independent building sewers required; exception; elevation. 
(a)  A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for each building. Old building sewers may be used to service new buildings only when they are found to meet all requirements of this article. 
(b)  Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, wastewater shall be lifted by an approved means and discharged to the building sewer. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. V, § 3, 2-23-93) 
Sec. 58-44. - Construction specifications. 
    The construction and connection of the building sewer to the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the state building and plumbing code, applicable rules and regulations of the city, and materials and procedural specifications set forth in the American Society of Testing Materials (ASTM) and the Water Pollution Control Federation (WPCF) Manual of Practice No. 9. All such connections shall be made gastight and watertight, and verified by the proper testing to prevent I/I. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. V, § 4, 2-23-93) 
Sec. 58-45. - Unpolluted water sources. 
    No unpolluted water sources shall be connected to the sanitary sewer. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. V, § 5, 2-23-93) 
Sec. 58-46. - Supervision of connection by city. 
    The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the city when the building sewer is ready for connection to the public sewer. The connection shall be made under the supervision of the public works superintendent or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. V, § 6, 2-23-93) 
Sec. 58-47. - Construction license. 
(a)  Required. An appropriate construction license is required to install a service connection. Any person desiring a license shall apply in writing to the city council, providing satisfactory evidence of the applicant's qualifications. If approved by the council, the license shall be issued by a designated representative upon the filing of a bond as provided in this section. 
(b)  Bond. A license for sewer service connection installation shall not be issued until a $2,000.00 bond or a $300.00 cash bond to the city is filed and approved by the council. The licensee will indemnify the city from all suits, accidents and damage that may arise by reason of any opening in the streets, alleys or public grounds made by the licensee or by those in the licensee's employment. 
(c)  Fee. The cost of a license for making service connections is $100.00. The license shall be in effect indefinitely, but is not transferable. 
(d)  Suspension or revocation. The council may suspend or revoke any license issued under this article for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Giving false information in connection with the application for a license. 
(2)  Incompetence of the licensee. 
(3)  Willful violation of any provisions of this article or any rule or regulation pertaining to the making of service connections. 
(4)  Failure to adequately protect and indemnify the city and the user. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. V, §§ 7-10, 2-23-93) 
Secs. 58-48-58-59. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SEWER USE REGULATIONS 

Sec. 58-60. - Certain discharges prohibited. 
(a)  Unless otherwise permitted by section 58-72 herein, no person shall discharge or cause to be discharged directly or indirectly, any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage or waste from on-site disposal systems into the sanitary collection system of the city. No person shall have a roof drain, sump pump, unauthorized swimming pool discharge, cistern overflow pipe or surface drain connected and/or discharging into the sanitary sewer and shall have disconnected and removed any piping or system conveying such water to the sanitary sewer system before October 1, 1991. 
(b)  A surcharge as established by resolution of the city council is imposed and shall be added to every sewer billing mailed on or after October 1, 1991, to properties not in compliance with this section. The surcharge shall be added to every quarterly billing until the property is in compliance. Compliance shall occur through inspection by authorized city employees or agents of all properties or structures connected to the sanitary sewer system. Upon verified compliance with this section, the city reserves the right to inspect such property or structure at least yearly to confirm continued compliance. Any person refusing to allow their property to be inspected shall immediately become subject to the surcharge. Any owner of property found to violate this section shall make the necessary changes to comply with this section and such changes shall be verified by authorized city employees or agents. 
(c)  All sump pumps shall have a discharge pipe installed to the outside wall of the building with a one inch inside minimum diameter. The pipe attachment must be a permanent fitting type such as PVC pipe with glued fittings. The discharge pipe shall extend at least three feet outside of the foundation and must be directed toward the front yard or rear yard of the property. Any disconnects or openings in the sanitary sewer shall be closed or repaired in compliance with applicable codes. 
(d)  The imposition of the surcharge shall not limit the right of the city to seek an injunction in district court ordering the person to disconnect the nonconforming connection to the sanitary sewer or from pursuing any other available legal remedies. 
(Ord. No. 185, § 1, 7-23-91; Ord. No. 357, § 1, 4-12-11) 
Sec. 58-61. - Stormwater, unpolluted water restricted. 
    No unpolluted water or stormwater shall be discharged to the sanitary sewer. Such water shall be discharged only to storm sewers or natural outlets approved by the city and other regulatory agencies. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. VI, § 1, 2-23-93) 
Sec. 58-62. - Prohibited discharges. 
    No person shall discharge any of the following substances to the public sewer: 
(1)  Liquids, solids, gases, or other substances which singly or by interaction with others may cause fire or explosion. 
(2)  Solid or viscous substances which may cause obstruction to the flow in a sewer. 
(3)  Wastewater having a pH of less than 5.0 or greater than 9.5 or having any other corrosive or caustic property capable of causing damage or hazard. 
(4)  Wastewater containing toxic pollutants, as defined in section 307(a) of the water pollution control act and M.S.A. § 115.01, Subd. 14. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. VI, § 2, 2-23-93) 
Sec. 58-63. - Discharge limitations. 
    Discharges of the following substances shall be limited to concentrations or quantities which will not harm the wastewater facility, streams, soils, vegetation or groundwater, and will not otherwise create a hazard or nuisance. The authorized representative may set limitations lower than the prohibition limits outlined below. Consideration will be given to such factors as the quantity of waste in relation to flows and velocities, materials of construction, the city's NPDES and SDS permits, capacity of the treatment plant, degree of treatability of wastes and other pertinent factors. 
(1)  Wastewater having a temperature greater than 150 degrees Fahrenheit (65.6 degrees Celsius), or causing, individually or in combination with other wastewater, the influent at the treatment facilities to have a temperature exceeding 104 degrees Fahrenheit (40 degrees Celsius), or having heat in amounts which will be detrimental to biological activity in the treatment facilities. 
(2)  Wastewater containing fats, wax, grease or oils in excess of 100 mg/l or containing substances which may solidify or become viscous at temperatures between 32 degrees Fahrenheit and 150 degrees Fahrenheit (zero degrees and 65.6 degrees Celsius). 
(3)  A discharge of water or wastewater which in concentration or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer than 15 minutes, more than five times the average 24-hour concentration or flows during normal operation. 
(4)  Food wastes not properly shredded to such a degree that all articles will be carried freely under normal flow conditions with no particle greater than one-half inch in any dimension. 
(5)  Noxious or malodorous liquids, gases or solids. 
(6)  Wastewater with objectionable color not removed in the treatment process. 
(7)  Wastewater containing inert suspended solids in such quantities that would cause disruption to the wastewater treatment facilities. 
(8)  Radioactive wastes or isotopes in concentrations that exceed limits established by applicable state and federal regulations. 
(9)  Wastewaters with BOD or suspended solids levels that require additional treatment, except as may be permitted by specific written agreement with the city subject to section 58-61. 
(10)  Wastewater containing substances which cannot be treated to produce effluent quality required by the permit or which cause a violation of any applicable local, state or federal regulation. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. VI, § 3, 2-23-93) 
Sec. 58-64. - Pretreatment requirements or refusal of prohibited discharges by representative. 
(a)  In the event of discharges to the public sewer which contain substances or possess characteristics prohibited in section 58-62 or 58-63, or which, in the judgement of the representative, may have a deleterious effect to the treatment facility, receiving waters, soils, vegetation, or which create a hazard or nuisance, the representative may: 
(1)  Refuse to accept the wastes. 
(2)  Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the public sewer, pursuant to section 307(b) of the act and all addenda thereof. 
(3)  Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge. 
(4)  Require payment to cover all of the added costs of handling, treating and disposing of wastes not covered by existing taxes or sewer charges. 
(b)  If the representative permits the pretreatment or equalization of waste flows, the design, installation, maintenance and efficient operation of the facilities and equipment shall be at the owner's expense and shall be subject to review and approval by the city pursuant to the requirements of the MPCA. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. VI, § 4, 2-23-93) 
Sec. 58-65. - Dilution of discharges prohibited. 
    No user shall increase the use of process water or in any manner attempt to dilute a discharge as a partial or complete substitute for adequate treatment to achieve compliance with the limitations contained in this article, the national categorical pretreatment standards, and any state or local requirement. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. VI, § 5, 2-23-93) 
Sec. 58-66. - Grease, oil and sand interceptors. 
(a)  Grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be provided at the owner's expense when, in the opinion of the representative, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing floatable grease in excessive amounts, any flammable wastes, sand or other harmful ingredients. All interceptors shall be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. The owner shall be responsible for maintenance of interceptors, including proper removal and disposal of the captured materials by appropriate means, and shall maintain a record of dates and means of disposal which are subject to review by the representative. 
(b)  Any material removal and hauling must be performed by the owner's personnel or a currently licensed waste disposal firm and in compliance with all applicable laws and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. VI, § 6, 2-23-93) 
Sec. 58-67. - Control manholes. 
    Where required by the representative, industrial users shall install and maintain at their own expense a suitable structure or control manhole with such necessary meters and other testing equipment needed to facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of wastewater. The manhole will be safe and accessible at all times. The city may require submission of laboratory analyses to illustrate compliance with this article and any special conditions for discharge established by the city or responsible regulatory agency. All measurements, tests and analyses to which reference is made in this article shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater, published by the American Public Health Association, and kept for a period of one year. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. VI, § 7, 2-23-93) 
Sec. 58-68. - Accidental discharges; notice requirements. 
(a)  Where required by the representative, users shall provide protection from an accidental discharge of substances regulated by the article. Where necessary, facilities to prevent accidental discharges of prohibited materials shall be provided and maintained at the user's expense. Detailed plans and operating procedures of such facilities shall be submitted to the representative for review and approval prior to construction of the facility. Approval of such plans and operating procedures shall not relieve the user from the responsibility of modifying the facility as necessary to meet the requirement of this article. 
(b)  Users shall notify the representative immediately if a slug or accidental discharge of wastewater occurs in violation of this article. Notification will allow measures to be taken to minimize damage to the treatment facilities. Notification will not relieve users of liability for any expense, loss or damage to the treatment facilities, or for fines imposed on the city by any state or federal agency as a result of their actions. 
(c)  A notice shall be permanently posted on the user's bulletin board or other prominent place advising employees of the emergency notification procedure in the event of a slug or accidental discharge. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. VI, § 8, 2-23-93) 
Sec. 58-69. - Obstructions to flow. 
    No person shall permit any substance or matter which may form a deposit or obstruction of flow to be discharged into the public sewer. Whenever any service connection becomes clogged, obstructed, detrimental to the use of the public sewer, or unfit for the purpose of drainage, the owner shall make repairs as directed by the representative. Each day after 30 days that the owner neglects to make such repairs shall constitute a separate violation of this section. The representative may then cause the work to be done and recover related expenses from the owner or agent by an action in the name of the city. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. VI, § 9, 2-23-93) 
Sec. 58-70. - Assessment of costs for damages. 
    In addition to penalties that may be imposed for violation of any provision of this article, the city may assess against the user/owner the cost of repairing or restoring sewers and associated facilities damaged as a result of the discharge of prohibited wastes and collect the assessment as an additional charge for the use of the public sewer system. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. VI, § 10, 2-23-93) 
Sec. 58-71. - Agreements between city and industrial users for acceptance of certain wastes. 
    No statement contained in this article shall prevent any special agreement or arrangement between the city and any industrial user. Industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted by the facility for treatment, subject to adequate payment by the industrial user, provided that national categorical pretreatment standards and the city's NPDES and SDS permit limitations are not violated. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. VI, § 11, 2-23-93) 
Sec. 58-72. - Hauled wastewater. 
    Any person seeking to transport and subsequently discharge residential waste into the Watertown Wastewater Treatment Facilities (WWTF) shall comply with the applicable requirements specified in this section: 
(1)  Permit: Liquid waste haulers shall obtain a liquid waste disposal permit prior to discharging any waste at the WWTF and shall comply with applicable requirements of this chapter. 
(2)  Permit fee: An annual permit fee is due at time of issuance or reissuance of liquid waste hauler permit in the amount established by the city council resolution. 
(3)  Proof of insurance: The license waste hauler must maintain minimum insurance coverages as set forth in the license waste hauler permit. 
(4)  Proof of state permits: Liquid waste haulers must provide proof satisfactory to the city of appropriate licenses and/or permits from the State of Minnesota (MDEQ) and/or state or local health department permits. 
(5)  Load charge: Liquid waste haulers shall pay load charges to the city by the 10 th of every month unless other arrangements have been made with the city. Load charges are specified in the liquid waste hauler permit as established by the city council. 
(6)  Approved disposal sites: Liquid waste haulers shall discharge only at approved disposal sites as designated by the city. No load may be discharged without prior written approval of the city. The city may, but is not required to, collect samples of each hauled load. In addition, the city may require the hauler to provide samples and waste analysis of any load prior to disposal to ensure compliance with this chapter and the permit conditions. 
(7)  Approved liquid waste: The following wastes may be disposed of in the WWTF: domestic septage such as from home septic tanks, recreational vehicles, portable toilets, and type III marine sanitation devices. 
(8)  Disposal of unauthorized waste: No person may dispose of unauthorized waste, including but not limited to, food establishment septage, grease interceptor, industrial waste, grease, oil, sand or any substance or liquid that is not permitted by the liquid waste hauling permit into the WWTF. Disposal of unauthorized hauled waste will cause for immediate permit revocation. Revocation of the permit does not preclude the city from taking additional enforcement action including criminal prosecution. 
(9)  Permit suspended or denied: The city may suspend, revoke or deny a liquid waste permit application for the failure to comply with the requirements of this chapter, the conditions of the liquid waste hauling permit, or if there is a general disregard of the orderly, efficient and sanitary use of the city's WWTF. The city may deny a permit request or suspend a permit if there is an enforcement action or pending enforcement action being taken for failing to comply with this chapter, the liquid waste hauling permit conditions, or violation of any other environmental waste regulation. In the event an enforcement action is taken, the permit suspension may last a minimum of six months. To reinstate a permit at the end of the suspension period, the hauler must apply for a new permit. 
(10)  Load tickets: A load ticket completed by the hauler must be submitted to the city prior to disposal. The load ticket must contain the hauler's name, permit number, truck identification, the name and address from the originators of the hauled waste, and the volume and general characteristics of the waste. The form shall also be signed and certified that only domestic waste is being disposed, and that the load does not contain any prohibitive waste as stated in this article. 
(11)  No person shall undertake, authorize, or permit any disposal of waste in the WWTF which violates or is not in compliance with this chapter or the liquid waste hauling permit issued by the city, including all terms and conditions of the permit. 
(Ord. No. 357, § 3, 4-12-11) 
Secs. 58-73-58-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PRIVATE WASTEWATER DISPOSAL 

Sec. 58-91. - When authorized. 
    Where a public sewer is not available under the provisions of section 58-28, the building sewer shall be connected to a private wastewater disposal system complying with the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. IV, § 1, 2-23-93) 
Sec. 58-92. - Permit required; inspections. 
    Before beginning construction of a private wastewater disposal system, the owner shall obtain a written permit signed by the authorized representative. The permit shall not become effective until the installation is completed to the representative's satisfaction. A designated representative shall be allowed to inspect such system at any stage of construction. The applicant for the permit shall give notification when ready for the system's final inspection, and before any underground portions are covered. The inspection shall be made within 48 hours of the receipt of notice. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. IV, § 2, 2-23-93) 
Sec. 58-93. - Compliance with state and local specifications. 
    The type, capacities, location and layout of a private wastewater disposal system shall comply with all requirements of Minnesota Rules, chapter 7080 and applicable local ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. IV, § 3, 2-23-93) 
Sec. 58-94. - Maintenance by owner. 
    The owner shall operate and maintain the private wastewater disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times at no expense to the city. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. IV, § 4, 2-23-93) 
Sec. 58-95. - Connection to public sewer system. 
    When the public sewer becomes available to a property serviced by a private wastewater disposal system, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer within 30 days, in compliance with this article, and within 30 days private wastewater disposal systems will be cleaned of all sludge. The bottom shall be broken to permit drainage, and the tank or pit filled with suitable material. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. IV, § 5, 2-23-93) 
Sec. 58-96. - Additional requirements. 
    No statement contained in this division shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by the MPCA, the state department of health, or other responsible federal, state or local agencies. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. IV, § 6, 2-23-93) 
Secs. 58-97-58-105. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - RATES AND CHARGE SYSTEM 

Sec. 58-106. - Establishment of sewer service charge system. 
(a)  The city hereby establishes a sewer service charge system whereby all revenue collected from users of the wastewater treatment facilities will be used to pay all expenditures incurred for annual operation, maintenance, replacement and debt service on capital expenditure incurred in constructing the wastewater treatment facility. 
(b)  Each user shall pay its proportionate share of operation, maintenance and replacement costs of the treatment facility, based on the user's proportionate contribution to the total wastewater loading from all users. 
(c)  Each user shall pay debt service charges to retire local capital costs as determined by the city. 
(d)  Sewer service rates and charges to users of the wastewater treatment facility shall be determined in a sewer service charge system developed according to the provisions of section 58-107. The sewer service charge system shall be adopted by resolution upon enactment of the ordinance from which this article derives. Upon adoption, the sewer service charge system shall be published in the local newspaper and shall be effective upon publication. Subsequent changes in sewer service rates and charges shall be adopted by city resolution and shall be published in the local newspaper. 
(e)  Revenues collected for sewer service shall be deposited in a separate fund known as the "sewer service fund." Income from revenues collected will be expended to offset the costs of operation, maintenance and equipment replacement for the facility and to retire the debt for capital expenditure. The sewer service fund will function according to the provisions of division 6 of this article. 
(f)  Sewer service charges and the sewer service fund will be administrated in accordance with the provisions of section 58-125. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. IX, 2-23-93) 
Sec. 58-107. - Determination of sewer service charges. 
(a)  Classification of users. Users of the city wastewater treatment facility shall be assigned to one of the following classes: 
(1)  Residential. 
(2)  Nonresidential. 
(3)  Industrial. 
The assignment of users to these categories for the purpose of assessing user charges and debt service charges shall be the responsibility of the city. Assignment of users to user classes shall be based on the substantive intent of the definitions of the classes contained in this article. 
(b)  Operation, maintenance and replacement costs. Each user shall pay operation, maintenance and replacement costs in proportion to the user's contribution of wastewater flows and loading to the treatment plant, with the minimum rate for loading of BOD and TSS being the rate established for normal domestic strength wastewater (NDSW). Those industrial users discharging only segregated NDSW can be classified as nonresidential users for the purposes of rate determination. 
(c)  Calculation of billable wastewater flow charges for residential and nonresidential users. The charges for residential and nonresidential users assessed proportionally shall be determined according to billable wastewater flow. 
(1)  Residential users. Billable wastewater volume for residential users shall be calculated on monthly metered water usage. 
a.  Billable wastewater volume for the months of November through April shall be calculated on 100 percent of the metered water usage for those months. The monthly billable wastewater volumes for the months of November through April shall be based on meter readings as submitted by the residential user or an estimated volume as determined by the city. 
b.  Billable volume for the months of May through October shall be calculated at 100 percent of the average metered water usage for the months of November through April. 
(2)  Nonresidential users. Billable wastewater volume of nonresidential users shall be determined in the same manner as for residential users, except that if the city determines there are significant seasonal variations in metered water usage resulting in a proportionate increase in wastewater volume, the billable wastewater volume may then be: 
a.  Calculated on the basis of actual metered water usage throughout the year; or 
b.  Calculated on the basis of metered wastewater flow. 
The city may require nonresidential users to install such additional water meters or wastewater flow meters as may be necessary to determine billable wastewater volume. 
(d)  Determination of user charges. User charges for producers of normal domestic strength wastewater shall be determined as follows: 
(1)  Calculation of unit cost for treatment of normal domestic strength wastewater: 
Uomr = OM+R 
Tbwv  
Where: Uomr = Unit cost for operation, maintenance and equipment replacement in $/Kgal. OM+R = Total annual OM+R costs. Tbwv = Total annual billable wastewater flow in Kgal.  
(2)  Calculation of user charges: 
UC = Uomr * Bwv 
Where: UC = User charge. Uomr = Unit cost for operation, maintenance and replacement in $/Kgal. Bwv = Billable wastewater volume of a particular user in Kgal.  
(e)  Recovery of local construction costs. Local construction costs of the wastewater treatment facility will be recovered through a debt service charge calculated using monthly billable wastewater volume above 2,000 gallons and equivalent residential units, as follows: 
(1)  Calculation of monthly debt service unit cost per equivalent residential unit: 
Ueru =   Ceru   
12 * Teru  
Where: Ueru = Unit cost per equivalent residential unit in $/month/ERU. Ceru = Cost of annual debt service assigned to connections based on equivalent residential units. Teru = Total number of equivalent residential units.  
Equivalent residential units shall be assigned to system users consistent with the methods contained in this section within the following ERU assignment table (table 1). If a user is not categorized in the table, the city will assign the equivalent residential units to the user based on the provisions of this division in consideration of the definition provided in section 58-26. A request for determination should be made prior to issuance of a building permit or sewer service connection permit. A request for reevaluation of assigned equivalent residential units may be made to the city by individual users. Any reassignment will be based on clear violation of the substantive intent of the definition of ERU contained herein. 
Table 1. ERU Assignment Method 
Facility ERU assignment method Agricultural retail 1 ERU/10 employees Apartment complexes 
(common laundry area) 1 ERU/1.25 dwelling units Apartment complexes 
(individual laundry hookups) 1 ERU/dwelling unit Automobile service 1 ERU/2 service bays Bank 1 ERU/10 employees Barber shop 1 ERU/4 chairs Beauty salon 1 ERU/4 cutting stations Body repair shop 1 ERU/2 bays Bowling alley 1 ERU/3 alleys Car wash (self-service) 3 ERU's/stall Car wash (automatic) 6 ERU's/stall Churches 1 ERU/275 seats Clinic (medical) 1 ERU/exam room Cocktail lounge (bar, no food service) 1 ERU/23 seats Daycare (based on number of children licensed for) 1 ERU/14 children Dental office 1 ERU/chair Dry cleaners 1 ERU/each Elderly apartment housing 1 ERU/1.25 dwelling units Elderly assisted living facility 1 ERU/1.25 dwelling units Elderly board and lodging facility with special services 1 ERU/1.50 dwelling units Electrical appliance shop 1 ERU/3,000 sf (deduct mechanical rooms, elevator shafts, stairwells, restrooms and storage) Fire station (volunteer department force) 1 ERU/14 volunteers Fitness center/gym/dance/aerobics 1 ERU/2,060 sf plus one per 14 lockers or one per shower Funeral home (with allowed dwelling unit) 2 ERU's/each Funeral home (no allowed dwelling unit) 1 ERU/each General commercial and retail (facilities not explicitly named herein) 1 ERU/10 employees, plus 
1 ERU/allowed dwelling unit General office 1 ERU/2,400 sf (deduct mechanical rooms, elevator shafts, stairwells, restrooms and storage) Government buildings 1 ERU/each Laundromats 1 ERU/2 machines Library 1 ERU/each Manufactured housing 1 ERU/each Manufacturing 1 ERU/7,000 sf of assembly areas, 1 ERU/2,400 sf office space Motels and hotels 1 ERU/2 rooms Multiple-family housing units 1 ERU/dwelling unit Nursing home 1 ERU/3 beds Plumbing shop 1 ERU/7,000 sf of warehouse plus 1 ERU/2,400 sf office space Restaurants (fast food, disposable paper plates, glasses and silverware) 1 ERU/22 seats Restaurants (full service, washable silverware, glasses and dishes) 1 ERU/8 seats Schools (nursery to grade 7) 1 ERU/18 students Schools (grade 8 to grade 12) 1 ERU/14 students Service station (convenience center and gas pumping only) 1 ERU/each Service station (with service center and pumps) 1 ERU/each, plus

All fractional ERU's obtained by using the determination methods outlined herein shall be rounded to one full equivalent residential unit. 
(2)  Calculation of unit debt service cost for billable wastewater volume above 2,000 gallons per month usage: 
Uvol =    (Cds - Ceru)    
Tbwv - (24 * Conn)  
Where: Uvol = Unit cost for annual debt service in $/Kgal for use above 2,000 gallons per month. Cds = Total cost of annual debt service. Ceru = Cost of annual debt service assigned to connections based on ERU's. Tbwv = Total annual billable wastewater volume (Kgal). Conn = Total number of service connection in the sewer system.  
(3)  Calculation of debt service charge: 
DC = Ueru * ERU + Uvol * (bwv - 2) 
Where: DC = Debt service charge. Ueru = Unit cost per equivalent residential unit in $/month/ERU. ERU = Number of equivalent residential units for a particular user. Uvol = Unit cost for annual debt service in $/Kgal for use above 2,000 gallons per month. bwv = Monthly billable wastewater volume for a particular user in Kgal.  
(f)  Determination of sewer service charge. The sewer service charge for a particular connection shall be determined as follows: 
SSC = UC + DC 
Where: SSC = Sewer service charge. UC = User charge. DC = Debt service charge.  
(g)  Additional charges for industrial discharges. The sewer service charges established in this division will not prevent the assessment of additional charges to users who discharge wastes in concentrations greater than NDSW or of unusual character (industrial users). Special contractual agreements can be made with such users, subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  The user pay OM+R costs in proportion to the user's contribution of wastewater flows and loading to the treatment facility, and no user is charged at a rate inferior to the charge for normal domestic strength wastes. 
(2)  The sampling of wastewater shall be conducted in accordance with the techniques established in Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater, latest edition, published by the American Public Health Association. 
A study of unit costs of collection and treatment processes attributable to flow, BOD, TSS, and other significant loading shall be developed and used to determine the proportionate allocation of costs to flows and loading for industrial users. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. X, 2-23-93; Ord. No. 251, § 1, 1-27-04; Ord. No. 306, § 1, 7-24-07) 
Sec. 58-108. - Collection of delinquent accounts. 
    To collect delinquent sewer service charge accounts, the city may file a civil action suit or levy an assessment against the violator. Related attorneys fees fixed by court order shall also be collected. The violator shall be liable for interest on all unpaid balances at a rate of eight percent annually. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. XIII, § 3, 2-23-93) 
Secs. 58-109-58-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - SEWER SERVICE FUND 

Sec. 58-121. - Established; accounts. 
(a)  The city hereby establishes a sewer service fund as an income fund to receive all revenues generated by the sewer service charge system, and all other income dedicated to the operation, maintenance, replacement and construction of the wastewater treatment facility, including taxes, special charges, fees and assessments intended to retire construction debt. 
(b)  The city shall also establish the following accounts no later than 60 days prior to initiation of the wastewater facilities operation as income and expenditure accounts within the sewer service fund: 
(1)  Operation and maintenance account. 
(2)  Equipment replacement account. 
(3)  Debt retirement account. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. XI, § 1, 2-23-93) 
Sec. 58-122. - Disposition of revenue from sewer service charge system; transfer of funds. 
    All revenue generated by the sewer service charge system, and all other income pertinent to the treatment system, including taxes and special assessments dedicated to retire construction debt, shall be held by the city separate and apart from all other funds of the city. Funds received by the sewer service fund shall be transferred to the operation and maintenance account, the equipment replacement account, and the debt retirement account in accordance with state and federal regulations and the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. XI, § 2, 2-23-93) 
Sec. 58-123. - Operation and maintenance account. 
    Revenue generated by the sewer service charge system sufficient for operation and maintenance shall be held separate and apart in the operation and maintenance account. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. XI, § 3, 2-23-93) 
Sec. 58-124. - Equipment replacement account. 
    Revenue generated by the sewer service charge system sufficient to ensure adequate replacement throughout the useful life of the wastewater treatment facility shall be held separate and apart in the equipment replacement account and dedicated to paying replacement costs. Interest income generated by the equipment replacement account shall remain in the equipment replacement account. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. XI, § 4, 2-23-93) 
Sec. 58-125. - Administration of fund. 
(a)  The sewer service charge system and sewer service fund shall be administrated according to the provisions set out in this section. 
(b)  The clerk-treasurer shall maintain a proper system of accounts suitable for determining the operation and maintenance, equipment replacement and debt retirement costs of wastewater treatment facilities, and shall furnish the city council with a report of such costs annually in January. 
(c)  The city council shall annually determine whether or not sufficient revenue is being generated for the effective operation, maintenance, replacement and management of the wastewater treatment facility, and whether sufficient revenue is being generated for debt retirement. The city council will also determine whether the user charges are distributed proportionately to each user in accordance with section 58-106(b) of this article and section 104(b)(2)(A) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, as amended. 
The city shall thereafter, but not later than the end of the year, reassess, and as necessary revise, the sewer service charge system then in use, by resolution, to ensure the proportionality of the user charges and to ensure the sufficiency of funds to maintain the capacity and performance to which the facilities were constructed, and to retire the construction debt. 
(d)  In accordance with federal and state requirements, each user will be notified annually in conjunction with a regular billing of that portion of the sewer service charge attributable to operation, maintenance and replacement. 
(e)  In accordance with federal and state requirements, the city shall be responsible for maintaining all records necessary to document compliance with the sewer service charge system adopted. 
(f)  Bills for sewer service charges shall be rendered on a monthly basis succeeding the period for which the service was rendered and shall be due 30 days from the date of rendering. Any bill not paid in full after the due date will be considered delinquent. At that time the city shall notify the delinquent owner/occupant in writing regarding the delinquent bill and subsequent penalty. The penalty shall be computed as ten percent of the original bill. 
(g)  The owner of the premises shall be liable to pay for the service to such premises, and the service is furnished to the premises by the city only upon the condition that the owner of the premises is liable therefor to the city. 
(h)  Any additional costs caused by discharges to the treatment works of toxins or other incompatible wastes, including the cost of restoring wastewater treatment services, cleanup and restoration of the receiving waters and environs, and sludge disposal, shall be borne by the dischargers of such wastes, at no expense to the city. 
(Ord. No. 190, art. XII, 2-23-93) 
Secs. 58-126-58-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WATER 

Sec. 58-151. - Water to be metered. 
    Except in emergencies for extinguishing fires, no person except authorized city employees shall use water from the city municipal water supply system or permit water to be drawn therefrom, unless such water be metered by passing through a meter supplied or approved by the city. No person unauthorized by the city utility department shall connect, disconnect, take apart or in any manner change, or cause to be changed, or interfere with any such meter or the operation thereof. 
(Ord. No. 87, § 5, 12-16-75) 
Sec. 58-152. - Meters property of the city; fee. 
    The city shall establish a meter fee to be made to customers for water meters, and payment for the use of the meter fee shall be made in advance before delivery and installation of the meter. The amount of the fees shall be on file in the city offices. Such fees shall not be refunded upon change of ownership of the property served, but may be transferred to a subsequent owner if the meter is in good operating condition. All water meters shall be and remain the property of the city and may be removed, replaced or changed as to size and type by the city whenever deemed necessary. Meters shall be available for inspection and testing at reasonable times by authorized city personnel. 
(Ord. No. 87, § 6, 12-16-75) 
Sec. 58-153. - Meter maintenance. 
    The city shall maintain and repair all meters when rendered unserviceable through ordinary wear and tear and shall replace them if necessary. Where replacement, repair or adjustment of any meter is rendered necessary by the act, neglect, or carelessness of the owner or occupant of the premises, any expense caused to the city thereby shall be charged against and collected from the water consumer and water service may be discontinued until the cause is corrected and amount charged collected. 
(Ord. No. 87, § 7, 12-16-75) 
Sec. 58-154. - Meter reading and inspection. 
    City employees assigned for the purpose of meter reading shall have free access at reasonable hours of the day to all parts of every building and premises connected with the city water system for reading meters and inspections. The city may, at its option, use other methods of meter reading such as mailing of requests to users for self-reading and returning such readings to the city for billing. 
(Ord. No. 87, § 8, 12-16-75) 
Sec. 58-155. - Nonmetered water, estimated amount. 
    If it is not possible to meter water used in certain circumstances such as, but not limited to, temporary disconnected or defective meters or use of water from city hydrants with permission of the city, the clerk-treasurer may estimate the amount used during that period using any reasonable method for determining such amount, but in no event shall the charge be less than the minimum amount as established by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 87, § 18, 12-16-75) 
Sec. 58-155.1. - Testing of faulty meters. 
    Upon the written request of a property owner or a consumer of water on the property, the city will test the water meter supplying water to the subject property or premises. Prior to the test a deposit in an amount established by the city council shall be made with the city to cover the expenses of the test. The deposit will be returned if the meter is found not to be registering correctly according to American Water Works Association Standards. The city may also at its own expense test any meter at any time that it determines necessary or appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 315, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 58-155.2. - Faulty meters-Refunds of previously paid consumption charges. 
    If the testing of a meter shows that that it fails to meter correctly and may have registered more water usage than actually consumed, the charge for water consumed shall be on the basis for the corresponding period of the previous year under the same or similar water usage conditions and any excess charge will be refunded to the consumer or otherwise equitably adjusted. 
(Ord. No. 315, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 58-155.3. - Temporary connection to hydrants. 
    The city may permit water to be drawn temporarily from a fire hydrant by attaching a meter/valve provided by the city. The meter/value and the amount of water drawn will be billed to the user according to the city's fee schedule. 
(Ord. No. 315, § 1, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 58-156. - Turning on water after service has been disconnected. 
    A service charge which is established by resolution of the city council shall be made for turning on water where service has been turned off for nonpayment of water charges, failure to repair a leak, discontinuance of service or any other cause. 
(Ord. No. 87, § 11, 12-16-75) 
Sec. 58-157. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 208, § 2, adopted Sept. 23, 1997, repealed § 58-157, which pertained to water service fees, rates and charges and derived from Ord. No. 87, § 9, adopted Dec. 16. 1975. For similar provisions see § 58-8. 
Sec. 58-158. - Deficiency in supply of water and shutting off water for repairs or emergencies. 
    The city shall not be liable for any deficiency or failure in the supply of water to consumers, whether occasioned by shutting the water off for the purpose of making repairs or connections, or from any other cause whatsoever. In case of fire, or alarm of fire or other emergency, water may be shut off to insure a supply for firefighting, or in making repairs or construction of new water works. In such events, water may be shut off at any time and kept off so long as necessary. 
(Ord. No. 87, § 15, 12-16-75) 
Sec. 58-159. - Outdoor water conservation. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to promote outdoor water consumption conservation measures, to conserve water resources, and to assist the City of Watertown in effective utilization of its annual water appropriation permit limits established by the Minnesota Department of Natural Resources. 
    A reduction in the level of outdoor water consumption demand during peak demand periods will assist in maintaining sufficient amounts of water storage for fire fighting, and reduce the urgency for the construction of additional storage facilities, wells and water filter facilities. 
(b)  Conservation measures; time of day conservation. To conserve water resources and prevent the wasteful and harmful effects of irrigation and sprinkling during mid-day hours, no person shall irrigate or sprinkle using the public water supply or a private well water source between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. on any day of any week. This conservation measure applies to established lawns, vegetation, shrubs, trees and gardens. 
(c)  Implementation of emergency conservation measures; odd/even conservation and temporary ban.
